[[File:Khartoum Resolution Signatories.svg|alt=Map of Khartoum Resolution Signatories|thumb|{{Color box|#BB6733||}} Arab League in 1967
{{Color box|#346733||}} Signatories
{{Color box|#3467C2||}} Signatories that later recognized Israel ]] {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2016}} The '''Khartoum Resolution''' of 1 September 1967 was issued at the conclusion of the [[1967 Arab League summit]] convened in the wake of the [[Six-Day War]], in [[Khartoum]], the capital of [[Sudan]]. The summit lasted from 29 August to 1 September and was attended by eight Arab heads of state: [[Egypt]], [[Syria]], [[Jordan]], [[Lebanon]], [[Iraq]], [[Algeria]], [[Kuwait]], and [[Sudan]].{{cite web|title=The Khartoum The joint resolution passed by eight the member states of the Arab League: Egypt, Syria, Jordan, Lebanon, Iraq, Algeria, Kuwait and Sudan. Resolutions|url=https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Peace/three_noes.html|work=[[American-Israeli Cooperative Enterprise]]|publisher=[[Jewish Virtual Library]]|accessdate=8 June 2012}} The resolution called for: a continued state of belligerency with [[Israel]], ending the [[1967 Oil Embargo|Arab oil boycott]] declared during the [[Six-Day War]], an end to the [[North Yemen Civil War]], and economic assistance for [[Egypt]] and [[Jordan]]. It is famous for containing (in the third paragraph) what became known as the "Three No's": "no peace with Israel, no recognition of Israel, no negotiations with it..."{{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/Features/In-Thespotlight/This-Week-In-History-The-Arab-Leagues-three-nos|title=This Week in History: The Arab League Three No's|work=[[Jerusalem Post]]|accessdate=4 December 2017}} == Text of the resolution == #The conference has affirmed the unity of Arab states, the unity of joint action and the need for coordination and for the elimination of all differences. The Kings, Presidents and representatives of the other Arab Heads of State at the conference have affirmed their countries' stand by an implementation of the Arab Solidarity Charter which was signed at the third Arab summit conference in Casablanca. #The conference has agreed on the need to consolidate all efforts to eliminate the effects of the aggression on the basis that the occupied lands are Arab lands and that the burden of regaining these lands falls on all the Arab States. #The Arab Heads of State have agreed to unite their political efforts at the international and diplomatic level to eliminate the effects of the aggression and to ensure the withdrawal of the aggressive Israeli forces from the Arab lands which have been occupied since the aggression of 5 June. This will be done within the framework of the main principles by which the Arab States abide, namely, no peace with Israel, no recognition of Israel, no negotiations with it, and insistence on the rights of the Palestinian people in their own country. #The conference of Arab Ministers of Finance, Economy and Oil recommended that suspension of oil pumping be used as a weapon in the battle. However, after thoroughly studying the matter, the summit conference has come to the conclusion that the oil pumping can itself be used as a positive weapon, since oil is an Arab resource which can be used to strengthen the economy of the Arab States directly affected by the aggression, so that these States will be able to stand firm in the battle. The conference has, therefore, decided to resume the pumping of oil, since oil is a positive Arab resource that can be used in the service of Arab goals. It can contribute to the efforts to enable those Arab States which were exposed to the aggression and thereby lost economic resources to stand firm and eliminate the effects of the aggression. The oil-producing States have, in fact, participated in the efforts to enable the States affected by the aggression to stand firm in the face of any economic pressure. #The participants in the conference have approved the plan proposed by Kuwait to set up an Arab Economic and Social Development Fund on the basis of the recommendation of the Baghdad conference of Arab Ministers of Finance, Economy and Oil. #The participants have agreed on the need to adopt the necessary measures to strengthen military preparation to face all eventualities. #The conference has decided to expedite the elimination of foreign bases in the Arab States. ==Interpretations== Commentators have frequently presented the resolution as an example of Arab [[wikt:rejectionism|rejectionism]]. [[Efraim Halevy]], Guy Ben-Porat, [[Steven R. David]], [[Julius Stone]], and [[Ian Bremmer]] all agree the Khartoum Resolution amounted to a rejection of Israel's [[right to exist]].{{cite web|last=Halevy |first=Efraim |title=Israel's Hamas Portfolio |url=http://israelcfr.com/documents/issue6_hamas.pdf |publisher=[[Israel Council on Foreign Relations]] |accessdate=8 June 2012 |authorlink=Efraim Halevy |quote=Indeed, twenty years later, after two successive wars, the Arab world rejected Israel's right to exist at the infamous Khartoum Conference of 196[7] – 'the three NOs': no to recognition, no to negotiation, and no to peace were uttered in response to Israel's appeal to negotiate without any preconditions. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120225221835/http://israelcfr.com/documents/issue6_hamas.pdf |archivedate=25 February 2012 |df= }}{{cite book|last= Ben-Porat|first=Guy|title= Global Liberalism, Local Populism: Peace and Conflict in Israel/Palestine and Northern Ireland|year=2006|publisher= [[Syracuse University Press]]|location=[[Syracuse, New York]]|isbn= 0-8156-3069-7|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=o0EVZoyteO8C&pg=PA145|accessdate=8 June 2012|page=145|chapter= Chapter 7: Israel, Globalization, and Peace|quote= Convening in Khartoum shortly after the war, Arab states declared their refusal to negotiate with Israel or to recognize its right to exist.}}{{cite book|last=David|first=Steven R.|title=Contemporary Israel: Domestic Politics, Foreign Policy, and Security Challenges|year=2009|publisher=[[Westview Press|WestView Press]]|location=[[Boulder, Colorado]]|isbn=978-0-8133-4385-3|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aOywsZizLi0C&pg=PA559|authorlink=Steven R. David|editor=[[Robert Freedman (political scientist)|Freedman, Robert O.]]|accessdate=8 June 2012|page=559|chapter=Chapter 13: Existential Threats to Israel|quote=Following Israel's success, in what became known as the Six Day War, the Arab states reinforced their refusal to accept Israel's existence when, in a conference in Khartoum, Sudan, they declared they would not negotiate with Israel, make peace with Israel, or recognize its right to exist.}}{{cite book|last=Stone|first=Julius|title=The Arab-Israeli Conflict|year=1975|publisher=[[Princeton University Press]]|location=[[Princeton, New Jersey]]|isbn=0691010668|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-xxWAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA336|authorlink=Julius Stone|editor=Moore, John Norton|accessdate=8 June 2012|page=336|chapter=Chapter 39: Between Ceasefires in the Middle East|quote= The Arab states, denying Israel's 'right to exist', continued after Khartoum to insist on 'no recognition, no negotiation, no peace', demanding complete Israeli withdrawal from}}{{cite book|last=Bremmer|first=Ian|title=The J Curve: A New Way to Understand Why Nations Rise and Fall|year=2006|publisher=[[Simon & Schuster]]|location=[[New York, NY]]|isbn=0-7432-9371-1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MIU14x1yEZkC|authorlink=Ian Bremmer|accessdate= 8 June 2012|page=209|chapter=Chapter Five: The Right Side of the J Curve|quote=Immediately after the Six-Day War, Arab leaders—including those of the Palestine Liberation Organization—agreed in Khartoum they would not make peace with Israel, would not negotiate with Israel, would not even recognize Israel's right to exist.}} The [[Palestine Liberation Organization]] (PLO) itself enlisted the Khartoum Resolution to advocate against acceptance of Israel's right to exist as articulated in [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 242]].{{cite book|title=The Encyclopedia of the Arab-Israeli Conflict, Vol. 1|year=2008|publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]]|location=[[Santa Barbara, California]]|isbn=978-1-85109-841-5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YAd8efHdVzIC&pg=PA1289|editor=[[Spencer C. Tucker|Tucker, Spencer C.]]|accessdate= 8 June 2012|page=1289|quote=The PLO disagreed entirely with the provisions whereby Arab nations were expected to recognize Israel's right to exist, claiming that these not only ran counter to the Arab states' earlier Khartoum Summit Conference declaration but were also 'fundamentally and gravely inconsistent with the Arab character of Palestine, the essence of the Palestinian cause and the right of the Palestinian people to their homeland.'}} [[Benny Morris]] wrote that the Arab leaders "hammered out a defiant, rejectionist platform that was to bedevil all peace moves in the region for a decade," despite an Israeli offer on June 19, 1967 "to give up Sinai and the Golan in exchange for peace."{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/234104996|title=Righteous victims : a history of the Zionist-Arab conflict, 1881–1999|last=Morris|first=Benny|date=|publisher=Vintage Books|year=2001|isbn=9780679744757|location=|pages=346|oclc=234104996}} [[Odd Bull]] of the [[UNTSO]] opined in much the same manner in 1976.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/490839078|title=War and peace in the Middle East the experiences a views of a U.N. observer|last=Bull|first=Odd|publisher=Leo Cooper|year=1976|isbn=9780850522266|location=|pages=126|oclc=490839078}} [[Avi Shlaim]] has argued that Arab spokesmen interpreted the Khartoum declarations to mean "no formal peace ''treaty'', but not a rejection of peace; no ''direct'' negotiations, but not a refusal to talk through third parties; and no ''de jure'' recognition of Israel, but acceptance of its existence as a state" (emphasis in original). Shlaim states that the conference marked a turning point in Arab-Israeli relations, noting that Nasser urged Hussein to seek a "comprehensive settlement" with Israel. Shlaim acknowledges that none of this was known in Israel at the time, whose leaders took the "three no's" at face value.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/59510046|title=The iron wall : Israel and the Arab world|last=Shlaim|first=Avi|date=|publisher=Penguin|year=2001|isbn=9780140288704|location=|pages=258–259|oclc=59510046}} Fred Khouri argued that "the Khartoum conference cleared the way for the Arab moderates to seek a political solution and to offer, in exchange for their conquered lands, important concessions short of actually recognizing Israel and negotiating formal peace treaties with her.” {{Cite book|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/arab-israeli-dilemma/oclc/634263471?|title=The Arab-Israeli dilemma|last=Khouri|first=Fred|date=|publisher=Syracuse University Press|year=1987|isbn=|location=|pages=312–314|oclc=634263471}} In the event, indirect negotiations between Israel, Jordan and Egypt eventually opened through the auspices of the [[Jarring Mission]] (1967–1973), and secret direct talks also took place between Israel and Jordan, but neither avenue succeeded in achieving a meaningful settlement, setting the stage for a new round of conflict. ==See also== *[[Arab–Israeli conflict]] *[[International law and the Arab-Israeli conflict]] ==Footnotes== {{reflist|2}} {{Arab–Israeli diplomacy}} [[Category:Arab–Israeli conflict]] [[Category:Six-Day War]] [[Category:1967 in Sudan]] [[Category:Resolutions (law)]] [[Category:1967 in international relations]] [[Category:1967 documents]]

[[File:Lent Bumps 2005 Day3.jpg|thumb|{{Camb|TR}} 1st Women about to overbump Girton in the women's 1st division on day 3 of the 2005 Lent Bumps.]]
The '''Lent Bumps''' (also Lent Races, Lents) are a set of [[Sport rowing|rowing]] races held annually on the [[River Cam]] in [[Cambridge]]. They began in 1887, after separating from the [[May Bumps]], which are bumping races held in mid-June. Prior to the separation there had been a single set of annual bumps dating from its inception in 1827.<ref name="bumps">''The Bumps:An Account of the Cambridge University Bumping Races 1827-1999'', John Durack, George Gilbert & Dr John Marks, 2000, {{ISBN|0-9538475-1-9}}</ref> The races are open to all college boat clubs from the [[University of Cambridge]], the University Medical and Veterinary Schools and [[Anglia Ruskin Boat Club]]. The Lent Bumps take place over five days (Tuesday to Saturday) at the end of February /start of March and are run as [[bumps race]]s.
The most recent in the series was the [[Lent Bumps 2018]], held from 27 February to 3 March 2018. On Wednesday 28 February three of the divisions were cancelled because of snow and ice on the towpath, then all racing was cancelled on Thursday 1 March, and the two lower divisions on Friday 2 March.
== Structure == {{main|Bumps race}} The races are run in divisions, each containing 17 crews. The number of crews in each bottom division varies yearly depending on new entrants.<ref>http://www.cucbc.org/mays/gor</ref> Each crew consists of eight rowers and one [[coxswain]]. Unlike the [[May Bumps]], rowers trialling for places in [[Rowing (sport)|university crews]] are not allowed to take part in the Lents. A total of 121 crews took part in 2012, totalling around 1100 participants. There are currently four divisions for men's crews (referred to as M1, M2 ... M4) and three divisions for women's crews (similarly W1–W3). The divisions represent an overall race order, with Division 1 at the top. The ultimate aim is to try to finish ''Head of the River'' (also said as gaining the 'Headship'), i.e. first position in Division 1.
At the start, signalled by a cannon, each crew is separated by a distance of about 1½ boat lengths (approximately 30 m or 90 ft). Once the race has begun, a crew must attempt to catch up with the crew ahead of it and ''bump'' (physically touch or overtake it) before the crew behind does the same to them. A crew which bumps or is bumped must pull to the side of the river to allow other crews to continue racing. A crew which neither bumps the crew ahead nor is bumped by the crew behind before crossing the finishing post is said to have ''rowed over''. Any crew which bumps then swaps places with the crew that it bumped in the following day's racing. A crew which rows over stays in the same position. Crews finishing at the top of a division, the ''sandwich boat'', row at the bottom of the next division to try to move up a division. The process is repeated over four days, allowing crews to move up or down in the overall order of boats. The finish order of one year's Lent Bumps is then used as the starting order of the following year's races.
The leading men's and women's crews of the Lent Bumps go on to race the leading Oxford [[Torpids]] men's and women's crews at the [[Henley Boat Races]] around Easter.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Light Blue men's and women's Lightweight crews race Oxford from Phyllis Court to Temple Island this spring|url=https://www.alumni.cam.ac.uk/events/henley-boat-races-2017|publisher=Cambridge University Alumni Events|accessdate=28 March 2017}}</ref> <!-- == 2013 Finishing positions (2014 Starting positions) == === Men's 1st Division ===

Lent Bumps were cancelled from 1915 to 1918 due to war, and in 1895 and 1963 due to ice. The Lents in 1888 were not completed due to the death of an oarsman. When the races ceased, {{Camb|JE}} were in 1st position.<ref name="bumps"/> The [[Lent Bumps 2001]] were not completed due to an outbreak of [[2001 UK foot and mouth crisis|Foot and Mouth disease]] in the UK. The outbreak closed the towpath along the river, where all of the umpiring for the bumps takes place. When the races were abandoned on Friday 2 March 2001, {{Camb|EM}} were in 1st position.
In 1919, college 1st VIIIs did not race as it was the first race after [[World War I]]. The start order for the 1920 races was the finish order for the 1914 races.<ref name="bumps"/> Prior to 1946 {{Camb|TR}} were two separate rowing clubs: 1st Trinity and 3rd Trinity, hence both separate and combined titles.<ref name="tr">http://www.firstandthird.org/ First and Third Trinity Boat Club website</ref>

page.title: List of 2006 FIFA World Cup controversies

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} The [[2006 FIFA World Cup]] generated various controversies, including onfield disputes, critiques of official decisions, and team salary issues. Most centered on specific refereeing decisions, which led many of the world's media to claim that the referees were spoiling the World Cup. Numerous World Cup records were also set by controversial calls, including [[#Three yellow cards issued (Croatia vs. Australia, group stage)|Graham Poll's three-card error]] and [[#Portugal vs. Netherlands (Second round)|Valentin Ivanov's record number of cards in a single match]].
FIFA's "Fair Play" agreement also came under intense scrutiny during the tournament, particularly during the [[#Portugal v Netherlands (Second round)|second-round match between Portugal and Netherlands]]. <!-- Note: This article is incomplete and in need of expansion. Please expand this article where possible and provide [[Wikipedia:Verifiability|verifiable]] references where necessary. -->
== Refereeing ==
=== Errors ===
==== Three yellow cards issued (Croatia vs. Australia, group stage) ==== The deciding game for the Group F runners-up place, [[2006 FIFA World Cup Group F#Croatia vs Australia|Croatia vs. Australia]], saw English referee [[Graham Poll]] mistakenly issue three yellow cards to Croatian [[Josip Šimunić]] before sending him off. Šimunić was shown a yellow card by Poll in the 61st minute for a foul on Australian Harry Kewell.<ref>{{cite news| url = http://wc2006.telegraph.co.uk/Document.aspx?id=8C8E2B20-81D5-4697-805E-B934B40A6F4D| date = 24 June 2006| title = Red card for Poll after clanger| last = Davies| first = Christopher| accessdate =3 July 2006|work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London}}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> In the 90th minute, Poll held up a yellow card in front of Šimunić for a foul, but did not follow it with a red card, as is required upon a second yellow card.<ref>{{cite news| url = https://www.thestar.com/NASApp/cs/ContentServer?pagename=thestar/Layout/Article_Type1&c=Article&cid=1151013012313&call_pageid=1044529386722&col=1044529386490| date = 23 June 2006| title = Soccer Notes: Ref gives 3 yellows|work=Toronto Star| accessdate =3 July 2006| location=Toronto}}</ref> In the 93rd minute, after Poll had blown the final whistle, Šimunić approached Poll angrily and gave him a push. Poll thus issued Šimunić with a 3rd yellow card and also showed him the red card.<ref>{{cite news| url = http://www.miami.com/mld/miamiherald/sports/soccer/14882044.htm| date = 23 June 2006| title = Third time not the charm| accessdate =3 July 2006| publisher = MiamiHerald.com| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20060701214103/http://www.miami.com/mld/miamiherald/sports/soccer/14882044.htm| archivedate= 1 July 2006| deadurl= yes}}</ref>
Questions were raised as to why Poll's assistants [[Philip Sharp (football referee)|Phil Sharp]] and [[Glenn Turner (referee)|Glenn Turner]], and fourth official [[Kevin Stott]], had also failed to realise the error. Poll later denied any blame should be placed upon the other officials saying, "I was the referee, it was my error and the buck stops with me".<ref name="pollbows">{{cite news|url=http://wc2006.telegraph.co.uk/Document.aspx?id=05242562-5F1B-4C0A-944A-D253E5EDAB10 |date=30 June 2006 |title=Emotional Poll bows out |last=Davies |first=Christopher |accessdate=3 July 2006 |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London}}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes}}</ref> Poll reported that the officials had felt "disbelief" upon hearing of the error in the dressing room after the game. He and the other officials consequently reviewed the DVD of the game, and Poll realised that his "dream was over".<ref name="pollbows"/>
[[Football Federation Australia]] chief executive [[John O'Neill (sport administrator)|John O'Neill]] later said that "Australia could have had grounds for a very strong appeal should Croatia have won the match".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://dailytelegraph.news.com.au/story/0,20281,19572813-5001028,00.html |title=Aussies would have protested loss |date=24 June 2006 |accessdate=4 July 2006 |last=Hand |first=Gus |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=UK |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060711104411/http://www.dailytelegraph.news.com.au/story/0%2C20281%2C19572813-5001028%2C00.html |archivedate=11 July 2006}}</ref> Poll also explained the reason for his mistake by saying that he "incorrectly noted down the name of the Australia number three Craig Moore when booking Šimunić for the second time and failed to realise his error"<ref name="pollsenthome">{{cite news| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/world_cup_2006/5108722.stm| date = 28 June 2006| title = Ref Poll sent home from World Cup| accessdate =3 July 2006|publisher=BBC Sport| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20060626065509/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/world_cup_2006/5108722.stm| archivedate= 26 June 2006 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> (Šimunić is Australian-born, hence speaks English with an Australian accent, probably causing the mistake).<ref>{{cite web| url = https://www.theroar.com.au/2018/05/31/stuttgart-will-always-craziest-game-australias-footballing-history/| date = 31 May 2018| title = Stuttgart will always be the craziest game in Australia's footballing history| last = Tuckerman| first = Mike|website=The Roar| accessdate =27 June 2018</ref><ref>{{cite web| url = https://www.smh.com.au/sport/soccer/documentary-helps-josip-simunic-continue-his-fight-to-clear-his-name-after-fifa-ban-20160204-gmleu8.html| date = 5 February 2016| title = Documentary helps Josip Simunic continue his fight to clear his name after FIFAban| last = Polkinghorne| first = David|work=[[Sydney Morning Herald]]| accessdate =27 June 2018</ref>
FIFA Referees Committee President Angel Maria Villar Llona defended Poll but had to concede that an error had occurred. In a statement he remarked, "Thursday evening's 2–2 draw between Croatia and Australia in Stuttgart saw referee Graham Poll make an error".<ref name="pollsenthome"/> As a result of his error, Poll and his assistants did not progress to the second stage of the tournament. Despite encouragement from FIFA president [[Sepp Blatter]], and chief executives of the Football Association and Premier League, Poll retired from refereeing international tournaments. Poll explained his decision to retire was a result of the "pain and agony" and "sleepless nights" that resulted from his mistake and the fear of it happening again.<ref name="pollbows"/>
=== Disputed decisions ===
==== Argentina vs. Côte d'Ivoire (Group stage) ==== Argentina was awarded a corner kick when one goal ahead in their game against Côte d'Ivoire. The kick, taken by [[Juan Román Riquelme]], found Argentine defender, [[Roberto Ayala]], who headed it towards goal. It was diverted by goalkeeper [[Jean-Jacques Tizié]]'s hands and bounced off the right goalpost before moving at least partially into the goal. Tizié fumbled the ball before returning it back into play, sparking protests from the Argentine players to Belgian referee [[Frank De Bleeckere]].<ref>{{cite news| title = The first step: Argentina holds off Ivory Coast 2–1 in opener| url = http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2006/soccer/specials/world_cup/2006/06/10/argentina.ivory.coast.ap/| date = 10 June 2006| accessdate =4 July 2006|work=Sports Illustrated}}{{Dead link|date=August 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref>
De Bleeckere looked to his assistant for help in the decision, but no confirmation could be made. TV replays reached no verdict either as to whether it was a goal.<ref>{{cite news| url = http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/sports/html/20060611T220000-0500_106766_OBS_BLATTER_PAYS_TRIBUTE_TO_WORLD_CUP_REFEREEING_SO_FAR_.asp| title = Blatter pays tribute to World Cup refereeing so far| date = 12 June 2006| accessdate =4 July 2006| publisher = The Jamaican Observer|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060629230824/http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/sports/html/20060611T220000-0500_106766_OBS_BLATTER_PAYS_TRIBUTE_TO_WORLD_CUP_REFEREEING_SO_FAR_.asp|archivedate = 29 June 2006}}</ref> Ayala was furious at referee Bleeckere for failing to award the goal and Argentine striker, [[Hernán Crespo]] later said, "It would have been a lot easier if that had counted."<ref>{{cite news| url = http://msnbc.msn.com/id/13247652/| title = Argentina strikes first in toughest group| date = 15 June 2006|publisher=MSNBC| accessdate =4 July 2006}}</ref>
==== Australia vs. Japan (Group stage) ==== In the first-round game of Australia versus Japan, Egyptian referee [[Essam Abd El Fatah]] awarded a 26th-minute goal by [[Shunsuke Nakamura]] to the Japanese despite a protest from Australian goalkeeper [[Mark Schwarzer]].<ref>{{cite news| url = http://www.smh.com.au/news/aussie-update/disputed-goal-rocks-socceroos/2006/06/12/1149964471236.html| title = Unbelievable win for Socceroos| date = 13 June 2006| last = Lynch| first = Michael| accessdate =4 July 2006|work=Sydney Morning Herald| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20060629001130/http://www.smh.com.au/news/aussie-update/disputed-goal-rocks-socceroos/2006/06/12/1149964471236.html| archivedate= 29 June 2006| deadurl= no}}</ref> Schwarzer appeared to have been impeded upon by Japanese forward [[Atsushi Yanagisawa]] as he had come forward to punch the ball clear.<ref name="cahilldouble">{{cite news |url=http://today.reuters.co.uk/news/newsArticle.aspx?type=sportsNews&storyID=2006-06-12T150023Z_01_L12411190_RTRUKOC_0_UK-SOCCER-WORLD-AUSTRALIA.xml |title=Cahill's late double delights Australia |last=Palmer |first=Justin |date=12 June 2006 |accessdate=4 July 2006|publisher=Reuters.co.uk}}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes}}</ref> Japanese striker [[Naohiro Takahara]] then collided with Schwarzer, leaving him unable to prevent the ball rolling into the goal.<ref name="hiddinkapology">{{cite news |url = http://news.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=106167 |title = Hiddink apologises for FIFA scuffle |date = 13 June 2006 |accessdate = 4 July 2006 |publisher = ninemsn |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060708170806/http://news.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=106167 |archivedate = 8 July 2006 |deadurl = yes |df= dmy-all}}</ref>
Schwarzer told reporters later that El Fatah had apologised to him for his mistake and had told Australian captain [[Mark Viduka]] that he was grateful "that God was on his side because the result went [Australia's] way in the end."<ref name="refapologizes">{{cite news| url = http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2006/soccer/specials/world_cup/2006/06/12/ref.apologizes/| title = Ref apologizes to Aussies for bad call| date = 12 June 2006| accessdate =4 July 2006|work=Sports Illustrated| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20060616181547/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2006/soccer/specials/world_cup/2006/06/12/ref.apologizes/| archivedate= 16 June 2006 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Viduka told reporters "it was obvious that he made a mistake but everybody makes a mistake."<ref name="refapologizes"/> Abdul-Fatah denied issuing an apology however, and said that "FIFA's refereeing committee... agreed unanimously that Japan's goal against Australia was correct," and would have awarded a penalty against Australia had the ball not gone in, as Takahara was pushed by [[Craig Moore]] into Schwarzer.<ref>{{cite news| url = http://worldcup.filbalad.com/english/News.asp?NewsID=24777| author = Omar Shoeb| title = Abdul-Fattah: I did not apologize to the Aussies| date = 13 June 2006| accessdate =5 July 2006| publisher = FilBalad |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071223133633/http://worldcup.filbalad.com/english/News.asp?NewsID=24777 |archivedate = 23 December 2007}}</ref>
Australian coach [[Guus Hiddink]] chose to "slightly, but not totally, apologise" for an incident off-field where he pushed an official off-balance in a scramble to see the television replay of the foul. Hiddink said he believed it was an obvious foul, but also that Schwarzer "can defend himself even more" against such incidents.<ref name="hiddinkapology"/>
FIFA communications director Markus Siegler told the press later that a penalty should have been awarded to Japan for a foul on Japanese midfielder [[Yūichi Komano]] by [[Tim Cahill]]. Siegler said "it was a clear mistake of the referee."<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/world-cup-2006/refereeing-mistake-cost-japan-a-penalty-says-top-fifa-official/2006/06/14/1149964612063.html |title= Refereeing mistake cost Japan a penalty, says top FIFA official |date=15 June 2006 |website=smh.com.au |publisher=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |accessdate=3 September 2016}}</ref> Had a yellow card been shown to Cahill, who scored the deciding goal for Australia minutes later, he would have been sent off, with the score at 1–1.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://today.reuters.co.uk/news/newsArticle.aspx?type=sportsNews&storyID=2006-06-14T125120Z_01_L14363777_RTRUKOC_0_UK-SOCCER-WORLD-JAPAN-PENALTY.xml&archived=False |title=Referee should have given Japan penalty, says FIFA |date=14 June 2006 |accessdate=4 July 2006 |publisher=Reuters.co.uk}}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes}}</ref> The Japanese coach [[Zico]] expressed frustration at FIFA's comments, saying that El Fatah had apologised for the mistake to the Australians but had not apologised for the error which FIFA admitted to.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://worldcup.sportinglife.com/football/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=soccer/06/06/15/WORLDCUP_Japan_Nightlead.html |title=Zico frustration at FIFA comments |last=Church |first=Michael |date=15 June 2006 |publisher=sportinglife.com |accessdate=4 July 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930050220/http://worldcup.sportinglife.com/football/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=soccer%2F06%2F06%2F15%2FWORLDCUP_Japan_Nightlead.html |archivedate=30 September 2007 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> [[Japan Football Association]] filed an official complaint against the Egyptian referee, who was sent home along with English referee Graham Poll.<ref>{{cite news| url = http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,20867,19631780-2722,00.html| title = Penalty referee given plum quarter-final| date = 30 June 2006| accessdate =4 July 2006| last = Lusetich| first = Robert|work=The Australian}}{{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
====England vs. Trinidad and Tobago (Group stage)====
[[Peter Crouch]] pulled Trinidad and Tobago defender [[Brent Sancho]]'s dreadlocks while scoring the first goal.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/archive/2006/06/200849131333899731.html|title=Sancho fumes at Crouch 'foul'|website=www.aljazeera.com|access-date=2018-07-13}}</ref>
==== France vs. Korea Republic (Group stage) ==== In the 31st minute of the game between France and Korea Republic, the French midfielder [[Patrick Vieira]] had a header at goal which appeared to be saved by Korean goalkeeper [[Lee Woon-Jae]] from behind the goal line. Mexican referee [[Benito Archundia]] and his linesmen did not believe the ball had passed the line, and no goal was awarded.<ref>{{cite news| url = https://int.soccerway.com/news/2006/June/18/koreans-earn-draw-against-france/| title = Koreans earn draw against France| last = Roorda| first = Jonathan| publisher = Soccerway.com| date = 18 June 2006| accessdate =4 July 2006| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20060703054513/http://www.soccerway.com/news/2006/June/18/koreans-earn-draw-against-france/| archivedate= 3 July 2006| deadurl= no}}</ref> The game resulted in a last minute 1–1 draw, shocking the French. French coach [[Raymond Domenech]] believed that France "scored a second time, but the referee did not recognize that."<ref>{{cite news| url = http://www.mercurynews.com/mld/mercurynews/sports/special_packages/world_cup/14851525.htm| title = What's French word for 'uninspiring'?| publisher = MercuryNews.com| date = 19 June 2006| accessdate =4 July 2006| last = Jones| first = Grahame L.| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060621144531/http://www.mercurynews.com/mld/mercurynews/sports/special_packages/world_cup/14851525.htm| archivedate= 21 June 2006| deadurl= no}}</ref> Television replays showed that the goal should have been awarded.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://today.reuters.co.uk/news/newsArticle.aspx?type=worldFootballNews&storyID=2006-06-19T084333Z_01_L19777729_RTRIDST_0_SPORT-SOCCER-WORLD-KOREA-PICTURE.XML |title=World-Refereeing controversy still following Koreans |last=Rogers |first=Iain |publisher=Reuters.co.uk |date=19 June 2006 |accessdate=4 July 2006}}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes}}</ref> French player [[Thierry Henry]] claimed the team was "really upset" when they saw the ball had passed the goal-line as "if he (the referee) had given us the valid goal, that would not have offered the Koreans the opportunity to come back into the match."<ref>{{cite news|url = http://www.clubcall.com/index.jsp?storyID=9471|title = Henry furious at refereeing display |date=19 June 2006 |accessdate = 4 July 2006 |publisher = clubcall |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071008062539/http://www.clubcall.com/index.jsp?storyID=9471 |archivedate = 8 October 2007 |df = dmy-all}}</ref> However, it should also be noted that the corner kick leading to the header should have been a goal kick, as the ball had gone out of bounds off a French player.{{citation needed|date=February 2010}} In addition, there appeared to be a whistle on the play for a foul on France, which would have negated the goal anyway.
The controversy revived questions over the possibility of goal-line technology use at the World Cup. A FIFA spokesperson, Markus Siegler, ruled out the short term likelihood saying that "its introduction depends on a system being developed that is 100 percent reliable".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://today.reuters.co.uk/news/newsArticle.aspx?type=worldFootballNews&storyID=2006-06-19T110333Z_01_L19788729_RTRIDST_0_SPORT-SOCCER-WORLD-KOREA-PICTURE.XML&pageNumber=0&imageid=&cap=&sz=13&WTModLoc=NewsArt-C1-ArticlePage2 |title=World-Goal-line technology not yet an option, says FIFA |last=Collett |first=Mike |date=19 June 2006 |accessdate=4 July 2006 |publisher=Reuters.co.uk}}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes}}</ref> French goalkeeper [[Fabien Barthez]] voiced opposition to video replays during a game as "it's a shame to stop the play."<ref name="Barthez">{{cite news| url = http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Soccer/WorldCup/Groups/G/2006/06/19/1641368-ap.html| archive-url = https://archive.is/20130115060522/http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Soccer/WorldCup/Groups/G/2006/06/19/1641368-ap.html| dead-url = yes| archive-date = 15 January 2013| title = Barthez: No video replays| date = 19 June 2006| publisher = SLAM! Sports| accessdate =4 July 2006}}</ref> Barthez said that he'd like to see more referees with "one in each half, and one behind each goal."<ref name="Barthez"/>
==== Togo vs. Switzerland (Group stage) ==== Near the end of the first half, Paraguayan referee [[Carlos Amarilla]] assumed that Togo's [[Emmanuel Adebayor]] had taken a dive in the penalty area, whereas most replays implied his heels had been clipped by Patrick Muller. The website Sport Network discusses the incident as follows: "Referee Carlos Amarilla caused controversy in the thirty-fifth minute when he somehow failed to give a penalty after Adebayor was hacked down by Patrick Muller. The Arsenal man had cut inside and seemed ready to unleash a shot at the Swiss goal, until Muller's trailing leg took Adebayor down."<ref>{{cite news| url = http://www.sportnetwork.net/main/s459/st98802.htm| date = 19 June 2006| title = Switzerland 2 Togo 0 – Match Report| accessdate =5 July 2006| publisher = Sport Network}}</ref>
==== Korea Republic vs. Switzerland (Group stage) ==== Referee [[Horacio Elizondo]] allowed [[Alexander Frei]]'s 77th-minute second goal for the Swiss even though one of the [[Assistant referee (association football)|assistant referees]] had flagged for offside.
Elizondo waved for play to continue after a cross from [[Xavier Margairaz]] ball was deflected into Frei's path by a South Korean defender and, although the lineman flagged for offside, the Argentine official overruled the decision and allowed the Swiss goal to stand. The South Korean players and head coach, [[Dick Advocaat]] protested, but referee Elizondo ignored their protest, and gave a [[Penalty card#Yellow card|yellow card]] to South Korean player [[Choi Jin-cheul]]. Replay later showed that Elizondo had made the correct decision, as Frei had been onside when Margairaz had played the ball.<ref>{{cite news |url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AnTNhHr0EA0| date = 23 June 2006| title = 2006 World Cup Korea vs Switzerland| accessdate =30 May 2012 | publisher = Youtube}}</ref><!--
Earlier in the game the South Koreans thought they had won a penalty early in the second half when the ball bounced up off the pitch hitting the hand of [[Patrick Müller]], but the incident was seen by the referee as accidental.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=191963&cc=4716| date = 23 June 2006| title = Switzerland 2–0 South Korea: Swiss march on| accessdate =5 July 2006 | publisher = ESPN}}</ref> The result cut little ice with the losers. "The defenders saw the linesman had raised his flag so we stopped playing," playmaker Park Ji-sung told Reuters. "But the referee continued play." I asked the linesman why he put his flag up but he just answered (me) that I should carry on. He did nothing. I'm very upset about the situation." South Korean players protested angrily against Elizondo after Frei's controversial second goal effectively killed off any hope they had of reaching the last 16. -->
==== Ghana vs. United States (Group stage) ==== In the last moments of the first half, German referee [[Markus Merk]] awarded a penalty kick to [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]], which led to Ghana's winning goal and qualification to the Second round, and to the elimination of the [[United States men's national soccer team|United States]] from the tournament. The British newspaper ''[[Financial Times]]'' described the incident as follows: "The match turned on the worst of refereeing decisions. Germany's Markus Merk was standing in a perfect position when USA defender [[Oguchi Onyewu]] won a header against the fabulously monikered [[Razak Pimpong]]. But inexplicably Merk blew for a penalty because of a non-existent push."<ref>{{cite news| url = http://www.ft.com/cms/s/c5fd4f84-0225-11db-a141-0000779e2340.html| date = 22 June 2006| title = Second wind lifts Ghana| accessdate =5 July 2006|work=Financial Times}}</ref> The [[BBC]] agreed with this view in its match report: "Merk added one more twist to the first half, with a controversial penalty award. He penalised Onyewu, who appeared to win a clean header as Pimpong collapsed dramatically".<ref>{{cite news| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/world_cup_2006/4853408.stm| date = 22 June 2006| title = Ghana 2–1 USA| accessdate =5 July 2006|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
==== Croatia vs. Australia (Group stage) ==== The game between Australia and Croatia to decide the Group F qualifiers saw a number of controversial decisions made by English referee, [[Graham Poll]]. It was during this game that Poll made his 3-yellow card blunder (see [[2006 FIFA World Cup controversies#Three yellow cards issued (Croatia vs. Australia, group stage)|above]]). In the 7th minute, as Australian captain [[Mark Viduka]] approached the goal, attempting to score, Croatian [[Josip Šimunić]] wrestled him away from the ball.<ref>{{cite news| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/world_cup_2006/4853428.stm| title = Croatia 2–2 Australia|publisher=BBC Sport| date = 22 June 2006| accessdate =4 July 2006| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20060626065259/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/world_cup_2006/4853428.stm| archivedate= 26 June 2006| deadurl= no}}</ref> The Australians appealed for a penalty, however Poll ruled that there was no foul.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://today.reuters.com/news/newsArticle.aspx?type=sportsNews&storyID=2006-06-22T194902Z_01_SP322520_RTRUKOC_0_US-SOCCER-WORLD-CROATIA-HALF.xml&archived=False |title = Croatia and Australia drawing 1–1 at half time |publisher = Reuters |date = 22 June 2006 |accessdate = 4 July 2006}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes}}</ref> In the 75th minute Croatian defender, [[Stjepan Tomas]] made a handball which mirrored his penalised 38th minute error, however it was not sighted by the referee and a corner rather than a penalty was awarded.<ref>{{cite news| url = http://tvnz.co.nz/view/page/497100/763306| title = Aussie advance, Italy next| publisher = tvnz.co.nz| date = 23 June 2006| accessdate =4 July 2006|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071010051624/http://tvnz.co.nz/view/page/497100/763306 |archivedate = 10 October 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url = http://home.skysports.com/worldcup/article.aspx?hlid=397593&CPID=4&clid=575&lid=4161&title=AUSSIES+THROUGH+DESPITE+SCARE |title = Aussies rule in Stuttgart |publisher = Sky Sports |date = 22 June 2006 |accessdate = 4 July 2006 |last = Livie |first = Alex}}{{dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=Broccoli and Coffee |fix-attempted=yes}}</ref> To add to the game's controversy, the 79th-minute goal by Australian striker [[Harry Kewell]] appeared to have scored whilst in an offside position.<ref>{{cite news| url = https://int.soccerway.com/news/2006/June/22/kewell-equalizer-sends-aussies-forward/| title = Kewell equalizer sends Aussies forward| date = 22 June 2006| accessdate =4 July 2006| last = Sharp| first = Stephen}}</ref> In addition, an apparent goal to Australia in the last second of the match was not allowed due to the referee accidentally delayed blowing the full-time whilst fumbling for his whistle, which allowed play to continue.
==== Ukraine vs. Tunisia (Group stage) ==== Tunisia players and supporters claim that the Paraguayan referee [[Carlos Amarilla]] failed to award Tunisia a penalty kick in the second half and then mistakenly awarded one to Ukraine, which when converted by [[Andriy Shevchenko]] resulted in the 1–0 win and qualification by Ukraine to the second round. At the time Tunisia was playing with 10 men since [[Ziad Jaziri]] was sent off for his second yellow card in the last minute of the first half. The German magazine [[Der Spiegel#Spiegel Online|Spiegel Online]] described the turn of events this way: "Tunisia went close on 65 minutes after [[Hamed Namouchi|Namouchi]] was hacked down on the edge of the box. [[Anis Ayari|Ayari]]'s left footed free kick deflected off [[Andriy Voronin|Voronin]] in the Ukrainian wall and crept just over the bar. Replays suggested the ball hit Voronin's elbow and Tunisia could feel aggrieved not to have been awarded a penalty. Then almost immediately the action switched to the other end when Shevchenko stumbled into the penalty area only to be brought down by [[Karim Haggui|Haggui]]. This time replays suggested Shevchenko fell over his own feet but Amarilla pointed to the spot and Shevchenko made no mistake with the penalty kick. It was tough luck for the Tunisians with two dodgy decisions costing the team badly and with only ten men left on the field the game looked beyond them."<ref>{{cite news| url = http://service.spiegel.de/cache/international/0,1518,423304,00.html| title = Ukraine Overcomes Tunisia|work=Der Spiegel | date = 23 June 2006| accessdate =5 July 2006}}</ref>
==== Portugal vs. Netherlands (Second round) ==== {{Main|Battle of Nuremberg (2006 FIFA World Cup)}} Referee [[Valentin Valentinovich Ivanov|Valentin Ivanov]] set a new record for the number of red cards issued in a World Cup match with four, and tied the record for yellow cards with 16.<ref name="soccernet_PORvNED">{{cite news|title=Portugal triumphs in game marred by fouls|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=372541|agency=Associated Press|date=25 June 2006|accessdate=11 July 2006}}</ref> FIFA president Sepp Blatter said of Ivanov, "I consider that today the referee was not at the same level as the participants, the players. There could have been a yellow card for the referee," although he later recanted, saying, "I regret what I said about his actions in the match between Portugal and the Netherlands."<ref>{{cite news|title=World-Blatter regrets criticism of referee Ivanov|url=http://worldcup.reuters.co.uk/netherlands/news/usnL04777073.html|publisher=Reuters|date=10 July 2006|accessdate=11 July 2006}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> The managers also blamed each other for not playing fairly; [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]]'s [[Luiz Felipe Scolari]] said, "FIFA talks about fair play. There was no fair play,"{{Citation needed|date=November 2009}} while the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]]' [[Marco van Basten]] responded, "If you talk about fair play, you should watch yourself first... [Portugal was] a bit more experienced with all these tricks and all this time wasting."<ref name="soccernet_PORvNED" />
Ivanov criticized both teams, reportedly saying, "They are known for time wasting and hitting from behind. I was unpleasantly surprised by seeing such things from the Dutch. More so, they were the instigators."<ref name="hughes_PORvsNEd">{{cite news|title=World Cup saga: Crime and punishment|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2006/06/28/sports/wcrefs.php|first=Rob|last=Hughes|work=International Herald Tribune|date=28 June 2006|accessdate=11 July 2006}}</ref>
In the 7th minute, Portugal's [[Cristiano Ronaldo]] left the match with an injury after being tackled in the thigh by [[Khalid Boulahrouz]]. ''International Herald Tribune'' writer Rob Hughes wrote that he had not seen "a more cynical and brutal attempt to kick a player out of a match than what [Boulahrouz] did to [Ronaldo]," and that he should have been red carded on two occasions, but only received a yellow card.<ref name="hughes_PORvsNEd" /> Boulahrouz was sent off in the 63rd minute after receiving his second yellow card for an elbow to [[Luís Figo]]'s face.
In the 60th minute, Figo received a yellow card despite head-butting Dutchman [[Mark van Bommel]], usually a red card offence, as stated by [[Misconduct (football)|Law 12]] of "The Laws of Football" – "A player shall be sent off if he/she is guilty of violent conduct." Figo did not receive further sanctions and was cleared to play in the subsequent quarter-final match against [[England national football team|England]] as he had been shown the yellow card during the match. Van Bommel said of the decision, "Figo head butted me and that is not a yellow card. I blame the referee, it was a clear red card."<ref>{{cite news|title=FIGO WILL HEAD INTO FIGHT WITH ENGLAND |url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/tm_objectid=17296715&method=full&siteid=66633&headline=figo-will-head-into-fight-with-england--name_page.html |last=Casey |first=Ed |publisher=The Daily Record |date=26 June 2006 |accessdate=7 July 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060629045628/http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/tm_objectid%3D17296715%26method%3Dfull%26siteid%3D66633%26headline%3Dfigo-will-head-into-fight-with-england--name_page.html |archivedate=29 June 2006 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
==== Italy vs. Australia (Second round) ==== In the 50th minute, Spanish referee [[Luis Medina Cantalejo]] showed Italy's [[Marco Materazzi]] a straight red card for a challenge on Australia's [[Marco Bresciano]]. The replays show Materazzi deliberately foul Bresciano outside of the box, denying him an opportunity to score; although [[Gianluca Zambrotta]] could recover. This forced [[Italy national football team|Italy]] to play with ten men for most of the second half.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/world_cup_2006/4991534.stm|title=Italy 1-0 Australia|date=26 June 2006|via=news.bbc.co.uk}}</ref>
Furthermore, the referee awarded a penalty kick for [[Italy national football team|Italy]] in the final seconds of injury time, after [[Australia national football team|Australia]]'s [[Lucas Neill]] challenged [[Fabio Grosso]], causing Grosso to stumble and go to ground.<ref name="Italy-Australia">{{cite web|title=Golden goal: Fabio Grosso for Italy v Germany (2006)|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2014/dec/05/sp-golden-goal-fabio-grosso-italy-germany-2006|publisher=The Guardian|author=Nick Miller|date=5 December 2014}}</ref> With the score 0–0 and Italy playing with ten men, the penalty resulted in a win by Italy when converted by [[Francesco Totti]], advancing Italy to the quarter-finals.<ref name="Italy-Australia"/> In 2010, Grosso, according to an Australian sports site, said that he didn't stay on his feet because he was exhausted and "didn't have the strength to go forward", he said he "felt contact, so I went down" and "maybe I accentuated it a little bit", but insisted that after reviewing the replay that Neill did commit a foul.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/sport/world-cup-diver-fabio-grosso-admits-laying-it-on/story-e6frf9if-1225854490153?nk=76833d0fd8c12c454571dfc59f6ec261|title="World Cup 'diver' Fabio Grosso admits laying it on," Melbourne Herald Sun 10 April 2010}}</ref>
==== Brazil vs. Ghana (Second round) ==== Brazil striker [[Adriano Leite Ribeiro|Adriano]] put the ball in the net in the 46th minute, but was in an offside position. However, the referee's assistant kept his flag down, and Slovak referee [[Ľuboš Micheľ]], awarded the goal. The [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]] described it like so: "Brazil... scored the next goal, albeit with a fair bit of controversy. Adriano scored on a breakaway in first-half injury time, using his left thigh to knock in a pass from the right wing from captain [[Cafu]]. However, replays showed Adriano was in an offside position when he touched the ball into the net."<ref name="brazilghanacbc">{{cite news|title=Ronaldo, Brazil beat brave Ghana |url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/worldcup2006/storyview.html?/story/worldcup2006/national/2006/06/27/brazil-ghana-worldcup.html |date=27 June 2006 |publisher=CBC |location=Canada |accessdate=5 July 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060708164036/http://www.cbc.ca/sports/worldcup2006/storyview.html?%2Fstory%2Fworldcup2006%2Fnational%2F2006%2F06%2F27%2Fbrazil-ghana-worldcup.html |archivedate= 8 July 2006 |deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name=brazilghanambm>{{cite news| title = Brazil v. Ghana minute-by-minute report| url = http://football.guardian.co.uk/worldcup2006/minbymin/0,,1788429,00.html| date = 27 June 2006|work=The Guardian |location=London | accessdate =20 July 2006}}</ref>
==== Spain vs. France (Second round) ==== At the 83rd minute, with the score at 1–1, referee [[Roberto Rosetti]] called a foul against [[Spain national football team|Spain]]'s [[Carles Puyol]]. [[France national football team|France]]'s [[Thierry Henry]] went down holding his face, although Puyol appeared to hit him in the chest. [[Patrick Vieira]] scored from the resulting free kick and France won the match 3–1. "For me it wasn't a foul, if anything it was a foul by (Henry) because he came from behind and collided with me," Puyol said, "but referees can get things wrong."<ref>{{cite news| url = http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=372761&cc=5901| date = 27 June 2006| title = Ref made crucial mistake, says Spain's Puyol| accessdate =7 July 2006| publisher = Reuters}}</ref> Spain coach [[Luis Aragonés]] also called the foul "non-existent". But Henry said, "Puyol came up to me afterwards and apologised so how is that cheating?" He also told reporters, "Look at the replay, their left-back was going to take the ball and Puyol came across me and blocked me. If that's basketball that's a good block, but we're not playing basketball. In my head I'm not a guy who does go down or cheats."<ref>{{cite news| url = http://football.guardian.co.uk/worldcup2006/story/0,,1807677,00.html| date = 28 June 2006| title = In my head I'm not a guy who does go down or cheats, Henry claims | last = Ingle| first = Sean| accessdate =7 July 2006|work=The Guardian |location=London}}</ref> Television announcer and former [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]] international [[Ruud Gullit]] said of the play, "I am a little bit disappointed. It shows that cheating works."<ref>{{cite news| url = http://www.tribalfootball.com/article.php?id=2707| date = 28 June 2006| title = France star Henry blasts: I'm no CHEAT! | accessdate =7 July 2006| publisher = tribalfootball.com|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060915093149/http://tribalfootball.com/article.php?id=2707 |archivedate = 15 September 2006}}</ref>
==== Portugal vs. France (Semi-finals) ====
It was reported [[Zinedine Zidane]] turned to the Uruguayan referee [[Jorge Larrionda]] and the two talked for a few moments. The outcome of the discussion must not have satisfied the number 10 of the Bleus, which turned and, murmured the insult directed to Larrionda in Spanish: "hijo de puta" (son of a bitch).<ref name="Round of 16">{{cite web|title=Selfish Zidane has fooled Fifa|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2006/jul/20/newsstory.sport7|publisher=theguardian.com|author=Paul Doyle|date=20 July 2006}}</ref><ref name="Zidane y Jorge Larrionda">{{cite web|language=es|title=Zidane y Materazzi tendrán otro round|url=https://www.eluniverso.com/2006/07/14/0001/15/A0B3E4FAC947499BB9B80C8776E421A5.html|publisher=eluniverso.com|date=14 July 2006}}</ref>
==== Italy vs. France (Final) ==== {{main|2006 FIFA World Cup Final}} [[File:Zinedine zidane wcf 2006.jpg|thumb|[[Zinedine Zidane]] converted a controversial penalty and was sent off for a headbutt in the [[2006 FIFA World Cup Final]]]] [[Zinedine Zidane]] opened the scoring in the 7th minute by converting a controversial penalty spot kick, which glanced off the underside of the crossbar and into the goal. The penalty was awarded after [[Florent Malouda]] went down inside the Italian penalty area under a challenge from Italian defender [[Marco Materazzi]]. The call was somewhat controversial—as it was put by an [[Associated Press]] report posted in the ESPN website "Malouda stumbled – many might say dived – in the penalty area and Elizondo immediately signaled a penalty kick".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/story/373590/italy-wins-fourth-world-cup-title|title=Italy wins fourth World Cup title|website=ESPNFC.com}}</ref> However, the slow-motion replay proved the referee right.<ref name="Final">{{cite web|title=TUTTO VERO! CAMPIONI DEL MONDO |url=https://issuu.com/shepard052/docs/gazzettadellosport|publisher=La Gazzetta dello Sport|page=5|author=Antonello Capone|date=10 July 2006|language=it}}</ref>
Italy then equalized at the 19th minute with a header by Materazzi himself and went on to win the title on penalty shoot out. The controversy surrounding the penalty was however overshadowed by the discussion surrounding [[Zinedine Zidane]]'s sending off by the end of extra-time for headbutting the Italian player in the chest.
=== Other issues ===
==== Officiating less-prominent teams, general concern ==== Match referees have faced accusations of bias from the media and team representatives for allegedly favouring larger and better-established teams at the finals, at the expense of less established football nations.<ref name="officialbiastheage">{{cite news| title = Australia creating Cup history – thanks to refs| url = http://www.theage.com.au/news/aussie-update/australia-creating-cup-history-8212-thanks-to-refs/2006/06/20/1150701554788.html| first = Tim | last = Colebatch|work=The Age | date = 21 June 2006| accessdate =5 July 2006| location=Melbourne, Australia}}</ref>
After the Australian team was knocked out of the tournament as a result of a controversial penalty given against defender [[Lucas Neill]] in their [[2006 FIFA World Cup knockout stage#Italy vs Australia|Second round match against Italy]], Australian assistant coach [[Graham Arnold]] was quoted as saying, "We are a small footballing nation that gets no favours. All we ask for is a fair go, and I don't think we received it over the four games."<ref name="ausitalylatimes">{{cite news | title = The Sins of 2002 Cast Shadow on Aussie Loss| url = http://articles.latimes.com/2006/jun/27/sports/sp-soccer27| last = Jones| first = Grahame L.|work=Los Angeles Times| date = 27 June 2006| accessdate =5 July 2006}}</ref> Likewise, after going down to [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] in their second round match, [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]]'s head coach [[Ratomir Dujković]] stated that "the referee might as well have been wearing a yellow shirt under his own".<ref>{{cite web| title = World Cup refs must crack down on elbowing says Blatter| url = http://www.bangkokpost.com/breaking_news/breakingnews.php?id=105573| publisher = TurkishPress.com| accessdate =12 August 2006}}</ref>
One basis for these claims has been the irregular balance of fouls sanctioned by referees between traditional powers and emerging teams. As of 27 June, the top eight [[2006 FIFA World Cup seeding|seeded teams]] have a combined net surplus of 93 more fouls sustained than committed with an average of 3.1 per match, according to statistics published on FIFA's website.<ref name="officialbiasfifaworldcupyahoo">{{cite web| title = 2006 World Cup Statistics detail: Team Disciplinary| url = http://fifaworldcup.yahoo.com/06/en/w/stats/detail.html?section=tdc| publisher = FIFAWorldCup.com| accessdate =5 July 2006| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060706095441/http://fifaworldcup.yahoo.com/06/en/w/stats/detail.html?section=tdc| archivedate= 6 July 2006| deadurl= no}}</ref>
On average, as of 27 June, the team with the highest fouls count of the finals have been debutants; [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]], with a 1.95 ratio between fouls committed and fouls sustained, [[Tunisia national football team|Tunisia]] with a ratio of 1.76 fouls committed/sustained, and [[Australia national football (soccer) team|Australia]] with a 1.75 ratio.
By contrast, the teams with fewer fouls committed have been traditional powerhouses [[Italy national football team|Italy]], [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] and [[Spain national football team|Spain]] – with respective averages of 0.66, 0.67 and 0.75 in fouls committed/sustained ratios.
On the other hand, the teams that committed the least fouls (less than 50 in three games) were Trinidad and Tobago, Costa Rica, Côte d'Ivoire, South Korea, Paraguay, Poland and Japan (the latter with just 38 fouls). Also, of the 5 teams most judged wrongly offside, four were in [[2006 World cup draw#Seeds|"Pot A"]], which therefore seeds them in the [[2006 FIFA World Cup seeding|top 8]] (Italy, Argentina, France and Brazil) and the other emerging European side Ukraine. Of the teams that were judged to be in an offside position incorrectly on no occasion in the first three games, only one (Mexico) was seeded into "Pot A".<ref>{{cite web |title = WebFocus Active Reports – On the Ball statistics |url = http://www.informationbuilders.co.uk/ontheball/wcuk.htm |publisher = Information Builders Inc. |accessdate = 14 July 2006 |archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20060715193356/http://www.informationbuilders.co.uk/Ontheball/wcuk.htm |archivedate = 15 July 2006 |deadurl = yes |df = dmy-all}}</ref>
While these statistics could be used to support claims of bias, they could also indicate that some teams are rougher and that the stronger teams are more disciplined, and their success is due to their not committing excessive fouls. Additionally it should be considered that a team in possession is more likely to sustain a foul than a defending team, and therefore the successful teams are likely to sustain more fouls.
FIFA president Sepp Blatter told before the tournament that referees should protect big star players: "What has been clearly said to referees is 'please protect the physical integrity of the players', and that means protecting the big stars".<ref name="blatter_protect">{{cite news |title=World Cup refs must crack down on elbowing says Blatter |url=http://archive.turkishpress.com/news.asp?id=127092 |agency=Agence France-Presse |date=6 June 2006 |accessdate=10 July 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930181454/http://archive.turkishpress.com/news.asp?id=127092 |archivedate=30 September 2007 |df=dmy}}</ref>
==== Player and referee communication, Australia vs. Brazil (Group stage) ==== According to Football Federation Australia (FFA) officials, the referee [[Markus Merk]] refused to talk to Australian captain [[Mark Viduka]] when approached during the game to explain certain refereeing decisions. Although many fans believed this to be irregular, the FIFA Laws of the Game clearly state: "The captain of a team has no special status or privileges under the Laws of the Game but he has a degree of responsibility for the behaviour of his team." – (Additional Instructions for the Referee)
This was part of the evidence used by the FFA to help defend Harry Kewell's after-match argument with Merk, which (pending a FIFA enquiry) threatened his participation in Australia's following match against Croatia. The enquiry later cleared the player of any wrongdoing, due to inconsistent reports between the officials, "despite photographs and television replays showing Kewell striding purposefully towards Merk, mouthing off and pointing his finger at him – the sort of anti-referee histrionics FIFA usually frowns heavily upon."<ref name="kewellcleared">{{cite news |title = Kewell cleared by FIFA |url = http://www.theworldgame.com.au/home/index.php?pid=st&cid=72441 |publisher = [[Australian Associated Press]] |date = 20 June 2006 |accessdate = 5 July 2006 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071011085356/http://www.theworldgame.com.au/home/index.php?pid=st&cid=72441 |archivedate = 11 October 2007 |df = dmy-all}}</ref>
==== Record card tally, Portugal vs. Netherlands (Second round) ==== This second-round game created some controversy due to the record number of bookings given by referee [[Valentin Valentinovich Ivanov|Valentin Ivanov]]. He gave a total of 16 yellow cards and 4 red cards. On this occasion, FIFA president Sepp Blatter publicly criticised his performance.<ref name="AP_Pye">{{cite news| title = Throwing cautions to the wind, yellow and red cards flow at World Cup| author = John Pye| url = https://sports.yahoo.com/sow/news;_ylt=A9FJqLGbHaBErxUBLhUmw7YF?slug=ap-wcup-fifa-redcards|agency=Associated Press| date = 26 June 2006| accessdate =5 July 2006}}</ref>
In an interview to Russian press, Ivanov stated that he "had been warned of the Portuguese harsh tactics but was surprised that the Dutch started it". This sentence generated an official protest of the Portuguese federation with FIFA.
==== Blue background for Argentine shooters, Germany vs. Argentina (Quarter final) ==== German goalkeeper [[Jens Lehmann]] wore a sky blue shirt during the penalty shoot-outs. An advertisement placed directly behind the goal had white characters on sky blue background, and three people standing behind it were also dressed in sky blue and white shirts. Argentine fans claim that this was intentionally made to distract Argentine players at the penalty kicks.<ref name="arg_ger_penalty">{{cite news| url = http://www.26noticias.com.ar/index.php?p=notadetalle&pp=index&idNota=16418| title = Alemania ganó con trampa en los penales a la Argentina | accessdate =1 March 2007| publisher = 26 Noticias| language = Spanish}}</ref>
Furthermore, a fight broke out between both teams after the end of the penalty shootout.
=== Defence of referees === On summing up the progress of the tournament at the conclusion of the group stage, Sepp Blatter spoke in defence of FIFA's officiating in the tournament, stating "... referees are only human, and they make mistakes. We have to reduce the number of mistakes, but we're all still searching in vain for perfection."<ref name="FIFAwc_Blatter">{{cite news| title = Halfway stage: FIFA President sums up| url = http://fifaworldcup.yahoo.com/06/en/060623/1/84vg.html| date = 23 June 2006| accessdate =5 July 2006}}</ref> Despite Blatter's statement, both Ivanov and Poll, referees at the center of the two largest controversies, were not included on the twelve-team list of officials selected by FIFA to referee the final eight matches of the competition.<ref name="FIFA_release_officials">{{cite news| title = Twelve refereeing trios for last eight matches| url = http://fifaworldcup.yahoo.com/06/en/060628/1/8ds8.html| publisher = [[FIFA]]| date = 28 June 2006| accessdate =5 July 2006}}</ref>
== Player disputes == <!-- This section is to be completed -->
===Togo===
Following months of confusion over who would be managing the African debutants Togo, [[Otto Pfister]] was only confirmed in the job the day before their opening match against South Korea. Pfister had previously resigned as coach of the team. The players threatened to boycott the final group match against France due to pay disputes.<ref name="IHT_Togo">{{cite news| title = World Cup: Amid coaching chaos, first victory is elusive for Togo| author = Peter Berlin| url = http://www.iht.com/articles/2006/06/13/sports/wctogo.php|work=International Herald Tribune| date = 13 June 2006| accessdate =5 July 2006| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060616103224/http://www.iht.com/articles/2006/06/13/sports/wctogo.php| archivedate= 16 June 2006| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name="Ind_Togo">{{cite news |title = Fifa threat ends Togo players' strike |author = Phil Shaw |url = http://sport.independent.co.uk/football/internationals/article1090366.ece |work = The Independent |location = London |date = 19 June 2006 |accessdate = 5 July 2006 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060708121346/http://sport.independent.co.uk/football/internationals/article1090366.ece |archivedate = 8 July 2006 |deadurl = yes |df = dmy-all}}</ref>
== Fair-play agreements == FIFA and the World Cup Organization have every team member and coach sign a "Fair-play agreement".
===Portugal vs. Netherlands (Second round) === {{main|Battle of Nuremberg (2006 FIFA World Cup)}} [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]] had possession of the ball when the game was interrupted by the referee to assist injured Portuguese defender [[Ricardo Carvalho]]. Under fair play conduct, when the game restarted, the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]] should have either not disputed the ball release or taken the ball without challenge and returned it to Portugal, however teams are not bound by the "Fair Play Agreement" signed before the tournament and no penalty can arise from such a situation. Instead, Dutch defender [[Johnny Heitinga]] kept possession, and was subsequently tackled from behind by [[Deco]], who received a yellow card.<ref name="reuters_deco">{{cite news | title = No appeal from Portugal so Deco misses England game| url = http://fifaworldcup.yahoo.com/06/en/060627/7/8bul.html| publisher = Reuters| date = 27 June 2006| accessdate =11 July 2006}}</ref> He received a second yellow card in the 78th minute for time wasting and was sent off, earning a ban for the quarter-final match against [[England national football team|England]].
Portugal coach [[Luiz Felipe Scolari]] accused Dutch coach [[Marco van Basten]] of encouraging his players to play on, and said, "The Portuguese Football Federation, on the basis of the FIFA Fair Play documents, will put in a request to overturn the card for Deco."<ref name="reuters_deco"/><ref>{{cite news |title=Portugal press case for Deco to face England |url=http://football.guardian.co.uk/worldcup2006/story/0,,1806875,00.html |last=Taylor |first=Chris|work=The Guardian |location=London |date=26 June 2006 |accessdate=7 July 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060721045444/http://football.guardian.co.uk/worldcup2006/story/0%2C%2C1806875%2C00.html |archivedate=21 July 2006|deadurl=no}}</ref> However, Portugal did not officially file the appeal, and FIFA spokesman Markus Siegler told the press, "There was a phone call from Portugal and they were clearly told 'forget it'."<ref name="reuters_deco"/>
==Discipline== {{main|2006 FIFA World Cup disciplinary record}} Certain matches attracted attention due to the high number of cards.
The Italy – USA match had three red cards with De Rossi of Italy in particular given marching orders for elbowing an opponent. This match was second only to the encounter between the Netherlands and Portugal (which had four, as well as 16 yellows). A Croatian player was also sent off after having (mistakenly) been given three yellow cards by referee Graham Poll.
==Fan issues== {{see also|Leeuwenhosen}} Some Dutch fans were forced to take off their trousers branded with the logo of [[Bavaria beer]], as Budweiser was the official beer of the tournament.<ref>[http://www.worldfootballinsider.com/Story.aspx?id=33443 INSIDER World Cup Diary - Bavaria Repeats Ambush Marketing; N.Korea Fans Watched.] June 16, 2010.</ref><ref>[http://www.wsc.co.uk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5072 Scramble for sponsorship for 2010,] [[When Saturday Comes]].</ref> Rather than leave the stadium, they proceeded to watch the match in their underclothes.
==Crime==
===Hooliganism=== While the [[German Federal Police|German Police]] expressed satisfaction in their ability to contain and deal with [[Football hooliganism|hooliganism]], speculation was rife that a number of potential flashpoints existed which could cause widespread public disorder. With a number of routes into the country, amongst them the open land borders which are a consequence of the [[Schengen agreement]], apprehension of known troublemakers and organisers of disturbances looked to be a very real problem. However, during the World Cup, Germany suspended its rules granting passport-free travel to EU citizens. As an illustration of this, on 8 June, German police apprehended 9 English hooligans attempting to enter the country via the [[Czech Republic|Czech]] border. Britain has a particularly stringent policy of restricting foreign travel of known football hooligans during periods where the England team are involved. 3,500 banning orders were served, and by 8 June all but 150 had surrendered their passports. On 9 June [[Channel 4 News]] in the UK reported that although there had been no violence, England fans in [[Frankfurt]] had been kicking footballs at the windows of the city's 600-year-old [[Römer (Frankfurt am Main)|Römer]] city hall building, although local police decided not to take action over this minor incident and the staff at the Mayor's office apparently took the attempted [[vandalism]] in good humour. On the day of England's first match against Paraguay two England fans were arrested for having swastikas and [[Schutzstaffel|SS]] insignia painted on their bodies. The two were flown back to England to appear in court; one was found guilty and banned from attending football matches until 2008, while the other was not banned as the symbol (the double-[[sig rune]] of the SS) was painted on his back, and he may not have been able to see it or known what it was. The court heard that the fan found guilty also had a letter J on his arm, believed to be a slight to Jews, but claimed not to know its meaning.<ref name="thislancashire">{{cite web|url=http://www.thisislancashire.co.uk/news/localnews/display.var.793030.0.supporters_arrested_in_germany_face_court.php|title=Supporters arrested in Germany face court|website=This Is Lancashire}}</ref> There was also concern over hooligans among the 300,000 Polish fans who travelled to Germany for the tournament.<ref>[http://today.reuters.co.uk/news/newsArticle.aspx?type=footballNews&storyID=2006-06-06T161321Z_01_L06386914_RTRIDST_0_SPORT-SOCCER-WORLD-POLAND-FANS.XML About 300,000 Poles may go to finals, says minister]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes}}, ''[[Reuters]]'', 6 June 2006</ref> This supposition was borne out as clashes between rival groups of supporters culminated in the arrest of 429 prior to and in the wake of the game between Germany and Poland in [[Dortmund]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://football.guardian.co.uk/worldcup2006/story/0,,1797760,00.html |work=The Guardian |location=London | title=Police arrest around 200 fans after city centre trouble | first=Paul | last=Kelso | date=15 June 2006 | accessdate=22 April 2010}}</ref><ref>[https://www.tagesschau.de/vignettetosophora102-vignette_cid-5624788.html Aktuelle Nachrichten – Inland Ausland Wirtschaft Kultur Sport – ARD Tagesschau<!-- Bot generated title -->]{{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120217093930/http://www.tagesschau.de/vignettetosophora102-vignette_cid-5624788.html |date=17 February 2012}}</ref>
On 14 June, [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] news in the UK reported that up to that date 7 England fans had been arrested, one for a "serious offence".
===Racism=== It was claimed that "foreign-looking" people should not visit some areas in the former East Germany,<ref>[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/12888810/ "Neo-Nazis ready to crash World Cup"] [[MSNBC]]. Retrieved 7 June 2006</ref> after one newspaper reported that [[Nazi-Skinheads|neo-Nazi skinheads]] were planning violence against foreigners. Germany contains a small but vocal neo-Nazi minority who have engaged in violent attacks against the country's immigrants, as well as foreign visitors, since the fall of the [[Berlin Wall]] and subsequent German reunification. According to German police, neo-Nazi hate crime was on the rise and had increased significantly over the preceding few months.<ref>https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5445314 [[NPR]]</ref><ref>http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1197825,00.html ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''</ref>
Two human rights organizations, the [[Africa Council]], based in Berlin, and the [[International League of Human Rights]] advised black and Asian fans to avoid certain areas of eastern Germany during the World Cup.<ref>[http://www.csmonitor.com/2006/0530/p07s02-woeu.html – "Tarnished German image on World Cup eve"] 2006-05-30 ''[[The Christian Science Monitor]]''. Retrieved 7 June 2006</ref><ref>[https://www.usatoday.com/sports/soccer/worldcup/2006-05-24-security-germany_x.htm "Germany to beef up patrols during World Cup"] 2006-05-24 ''[[USA Today]]''. Retrieved 7 June 2006</ref>
The far-right [[National Democratic Party of Germany|NPD]], an organisation which the German government unsuccessfully tried to ban in 2001, had planned to march through [[Gelsenkirchen]] on 10 June, a day after [[Ecuador]] met [[Poland]] in the city's new purpose-built stadium. This march had first been banned by the German police, but later permitted by the Gelsenkirchen Administrative Court. Other far-right marches were planned for [[Frankfurt]] and Herne during the competition, although these were subsequently banned.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?art_id=qw1149782222609B226|title=IOL: Police ban far-right marches during World Cup<!-- Bot generated title -->}}</ref>
[[FIFA]] announced that at the World Cup, teams could have points deducted for racist remarks by players and officials. A "Football Against Racism" logo covered each field's center circle until kickoff at all World Cup matches. Prior to every quarter-final match, the captains read a "declaration against racism" over the PA system.
The [[European Union]] launched a campaign against racism before the World Cup. [[Friso Roscam Abbing]], spokesman for the EU Justice and Home Affairs Commissioner indicated that the campaign also targeted prostitution rings and human trafficking.
===Trafficking of women=== {{See also|Prostitution in Germany}}
Some international human rights groups (like the [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe]] (PACE), the [[Nordic Council]] and [[Amnesty International]]) expressed concern that there would be an increase in the [[trafficking in human beings|trafficking of women]] up to and during the World Cup. PACE and Amnesty claimed that 30,000 women and girls might become the subject of slavery for the purposes of forced prostitution during the World Cup. They called upon the German authorities to monitor sex venues during the World Cup and provide support for the victims of trafficking.<ref>[http://www.amnestyusa.org/news/document.do?id=ENGACT770082006 Amnesty International: Public Statement – "Red card to trafficking during World Cup"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060816165726/http://www.amnestyusa.org/news/document.do?id=ENGACT770082006 |date=16 August 2006}} [[Amnesty International]]. Retrieved 7 June 2006</ref><ref>[http://assembly.coe.int/main.asp?Link=/documents/workingdocs/doc06/edoc10881.htm Council of Europe: Parliamentary Assembly – "Stop trafficking in women before the FIFA World Cup"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060614015447/http://assembly.coe.int/main.asp?Link=%2Fdocuments%2Fworkingdocs%2Fdoc06%2Fedoc10881.htm |date=14 June 2006}}. Retrieved 7 June 2006</ref><ref>[http://www.norden.org/webb/news/news.asp?id=6112&lang=6 "World Cup concerns Nordic Council "]. Retrieved 7 June 2006</ref><ref>[http://www.indcatholicnews.com/traworldcu458.html Independent Catholic News – "Appeal to stop trafficked women being sold for sex at World Cup"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060518155902/http://www.indcatholicnews.com/traworldcu458.html |date=18 May 2006}} ''[[Independent Catholic News]]''. Retrieved 7 June 2006</ref>
According to German police, there was no noticeable increase in forced prostitution during the World Cup. While there was a significant influx of (legal and illegal) prostitutes to Germany before the World Cup, most of those were reported to have left within the first two weeks. Police officials from several cities quoted prostitutes saying that business actually decreased.<ref>German language article [http://www.spiegel.de/panorama/0,1518,425462,00.html "Flaute in den Bordellen"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060823113157/http://www.spiegel.de/panorama/0,1518,425462,00.html |date=23 August 2006}} (''lull in the brothels'') from German weekly ''[[Der Spiegel]]''</ref>
===Computer cracking=== FIFA's [[Information technology|IT]] provider [[Avaya]] indicated that it expected, and was prepared for, the [[denial-of-service attack]]s which were unsuccessfully launched at the IT network for the [[2002 FIFA World Cup|2002 World Cup]]. No successful attacks were launched on the German World Cup system.
