{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Use British English|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox administration | article_title = May premiership | image = Tallinn Digital Summit. Handshake Theresa May and Jüri Ratas (37357846742) (cropped).jpg | upright = yes | alt = | caption = [[Theresa May]] in 2017 | office = [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]] | monarch = [[Elizabeth II]] | cabinet = {{unbulleted list | [[First May ministry|1st May ministry]] | [[Second May ministry|2nd May ministry]] }} | term_start = {{start date|2016|7|13|df=yes}} | term_end = | predecessor = [[Premiership of David Cameron|Cameron premiership]] | successor = | location = [[10 Downing Street]] | party = [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] }} {{Theresa May sidebar}} The '''premiership of Theresa May''' began on 13 July 2016, when [[Theresa May|May]] accepted Queen [[Elizabeth II]]'s invitation to form a government. This followed the resignation of May's predecessor as Prime Minister, [[David Cameron]], who resigned in the [[Aftermath of the United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016|aftermath of the European Union membership referendum]].
==Leadership election== In [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016|a referendum held on 23 June 2016]], Britain voted to [[United Kingdom withdrawal from the European Union|withdraw from the European Union]], with a result of 52% for withdrawal and 48% for remaining within the union. [[David Cameron]], who as prime minister had campaigned to remain within the European Union, announced on 24 June 2016, immediately following the announcement of the referendum results, that he would resign from his post.<ref name="BBC11JUL">{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-36768148 | title=Theresa May to succeed Cameron as UK PM on Wednesday | publisher=BBC News | date=11 July 2016 | accessdate=11 July 2016}}</ref> Following the first stages of a [[Conservative Party (UK) leadership election, 2016|Conservative Party leadership election]], Home Secretary [[Theresa May]]'s only remaining competitor, [[Andrea Leadsom]], withdrew from the race on 11 July 2016. Following this announcement, [[David Cameron]] said that he would step down from his post on 13 July.<ref name="BBC11JUL" /> Cameron formally tendered his resignation to Queen [[Elizabeth II]] on that day, who subsequently appointed [[Theresa May]] as his successor.<ref name="BBC16J">{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-36778350 | title=David Cameron says being PM 'the greatest honour' in final Downing Street speech | publisher=BBC News | date=13 July 2016 | accessdate=13 July 2016}}</ref><ref name="GD13JUL">{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jul/13/theresa-may-becomes-britains-prime-minister | title=Theresa May becomes Britain's prime minister | work=The Guardian | date=13 July 2016 | accessdate=13 July 2016}}</ref>
==Early days== After being appointed by [[Monarchy of the United Kingdom|Queen]] [[Elizabeth II]] on 13 July 2016, May became the United Kingdom's second female Prime Minister,<ref>{{cite news|last=McKenzie |first=Sheena |url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/07/13/europe/theresa-may-david-cameron-british-prime-minister/index.html |title=Theresa May becomes new British Prime Minister |publisher=CNN |date=13 July 2016 |accessdate=13 July 2016}}</ref> after [[Margaret Thatcher]], and the first female UK Prime Minister of the 21st century.<ref name="BBC11July">{{cite news |title=Theresa May to succeed Cameron as United Kingdom Prime Minister on Wednesday |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-36768148 |accessdate=11 July 2016 |publisher=BBC |date=11 July 2016}}</ref> May told the media on 11 July 2016 that she was "honoured and humbled" to be the party leader and to become prime minister.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-36768148 |title=PM-in-waiting Theresa May promises 'a better Britain' |publisher=BBC News |date=11 July 2016 |accessdate=11 December 2016}}</ref>
Responding to some calls for a general election (reported by the news media) to confirm her mandate, "sources close to Mrs May" said there would be no such election, according to the [[BBC]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-36769898 |title=Tributes for David Cameron at his final cabinet as UK PM |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=12 July 2016 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=12 July 2016}}</ref> In a speech after her appointment, May emphasised the term Unionist in the name of the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]], reminding all of "the precious, precious bond between England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-northern-ireland-36789572 |title=Theresa May: Word unionist 'very important to me' |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=13 July 2016 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=14 July 2016}}</ref> By 15 July 2016, May had travelled to Edinburgh, Scotland to meet with first minister [[Nicola Sturgeon]], to reinforce the bond between Scotland and the rest of the country. "This visit to Scotland is my first as prime minister and I'm coming here to show my commitment to preserving this special union that has endured for centuries," she explained.<ref name="auto">{{cite news |last=Stewart |first=Heather |date=14 July 2016 |title=Theresa May's decisive reshuffle draws line under Cameron era |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jul/14/theresa-mays-decisive-reshuffle-draws-line-under-cameron-era |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London, UK |accessdate=15 July 2016}}</ref> After the meeting at [[Bute House]], May offered the following comment about Scotland's role in the negotiations about the UK's exit from the EU. "I'm willing to listen to options and I've been very clear with the first minister today that I want the Scottish government to be fully engaged in our discussion."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-scotland-politics-36800536 |title=Theresa May and Nicola Sturgeon meet for Brexit talks |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=15 July 2016 |website=BBC News – Scotland Politics |publisher=BBC |accessdate=15 July 2016}}</ref>
In August 2016, May launched an investigation aimed at identifying and reducing racism in the public sector.<ref>{{cite web|author=27 August 2016 at 3:08 am |url=http://www.itv.com/news/2016-08-27/may-orders-public-service-audit-to-reveal-racial-inequality/ |title=May orders public service audit to reveal racial inequality – ITV News |publisher=Itv.com |date=27 August 2016 |accessdate=9 November 2016}}</ref>
May triggered [[Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union]] to [[Brexit|leave the EU]] in March 2017.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/13b17624-7057-11e6-9ac1-1055824ca907.html |title=Theresa May ignores calls for Brexit delay |newspaper=Financial Times |date=1 September 2016 |accessdate=11 December 2016 |subscription=yes}}</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/mar/29/theresa-may-triggers-article-50-with-warning-of-consequences-for-uk May triggers article 50 with warning of consequence for UK] ''[[The Guardian]]''</ref>
As part of the government's plan to curb [[childhood obesity]], May took steps to reduce sugar content of foods though many experts feel that too little is being done.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-37108767 |title=Childhood obesity: Plan attacked as 'weak' and 'watered down' – |publisher=BBC News |date=18 August 2016 |accessdate=9 November 2016}}</ref> Notably there are widespread calls for curbing advertising of unhealthy foods to children and banning promotions of unhealthy food (such as multipacks and buy one get one free) in supermarkets, restaurants, cafes and take-aways.<ref>{{cite web|author=Sarah Boseley |url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/aug/18/childhood-obesity-strategy-wasted-opportunity-campaigners |title=Childhood obesity: UK's 'inexcusable' strategy is wasted opportunity, say experts | Society |work=The Guardian |date=18 August 2016 |accessdate=9 November 2016}}</ref>
===Health Service=== Consultation will start over cost saving, streamlining and reduction of some services in the [[National Health Service]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-37186455 |title=NHS cuts 'planned across England' – |publisher=BBC News |date=26 August 2016 |accessdate=9 November 2016}}</ref> Critics fear cuts that could put lives at risk<ref>{{cite web|author=Diane Taylor |url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/aug/26/plan-to-transform-nhs-could-led-to-downgrade-of-major-london-hospitals |title=Plan to 'transform' NHS could lead to downgrade of major London hospitals | Society |work=The Guardian |date=26 August 2016 |accessdate=9 November 2016}}</ref> though the review is about more than reducing costs. An article in ''[[The Guardian]]'' suggests possible benefits from the review but fears secrecy within the NHS is hindering effective public discussion.<ref>{{cite web|author=Anonymous NHS manager |url=https://www.theguardian.com/healthcare-network/views-from-the-nhs-frontline/2016/aug/26/nhs-plans-bring-benefits-barred-telling-public-sustainability-transformation-plans |title=NHS plans could bring benefits but we're barred from telling the public | Healthcare Professionals Network |work=The Guardian |date=26 August 2016 |accessdate=9 November 2016}}</ref> Liberal Democrat [[Norman Lamb]] accepted the review makes sense in principle but stated "While it is important that the NHS becomes more efficient and sustainable for future generations, redesign of care models will only get us so far – and no experts believe the Conservative doctrine that an extra £8bn funding by 2020 will be anywhere near enough."<ref>{{cite web|author=Peter Walker, Heather Stewart and Diane Taylor |url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/aug/26/alarm-at-nhs-plans-for-closures-and-cuts-to-tackle-growing-deficit |title=NHS plans 'not just about closures', bosses insist | Society |work=The Guardian |date=26 August 2016 |accessdate=9 November 2016}}</ref>
===David Cameron=== In September 2016, [[David Cameron]] resigned as an MP, saying that he did not want to be a "distraction" for the new PM.<ref name="resign-mp-bbc">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-37342152|title=David Cameron quits as Conservative MP for Witney|publisher=BBC News|date=12 September 2016|accessdate=12 September 2016}}</ref> Toby Helm wrote in ''[[The Observer]]'' in September 2016 that May is seen as less right wing than Cameron,<ref>{{cite web|author=Toby Helm |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/sep/17/theresa-may-prime-minister-prepared-to-risk-it-all |title=Theresa May, the prime minister prepared to risk it all | Politics |work=The Guardian |date=17 September 2016 |accessdate=9 November 2016}}</ref> but she is also seen as quite right wing by Rebecca Glover in ''[[The Independent]]'', especially on immigration.<ref>{{cite news|author=Rebecca Glover |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/theresa-may-conservative-party-leader-shes-no-progressive-conservative-a7109121.html |title=Don't be fooled by Theresa May – she's no progressive Conservative |work=The Independent |date=29 June 2016 |accessdate=9 November 2016}}</ref>
===Grammar schools=== In September 2016, May announced that she would end a ban on new [[grammar school]]s.<ref>{{cite web|author=Heather Stewart and Peter Walker |url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2016/sep/09/theresa-may--end-ban-on-new-grammar-schools |title=Theresa May to end ban on new grammar schools | Education |work=The Guardian |date=9 September 2018 |accessdate=9 November 2016}}</ref> A ''[[BBC]]'' article suggests grammar schools would be dumbed down while other secondary schools in the area would suffer.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-37431235 |title=Grammar schools expansion 'could dumb them down' – BBC News |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=23 September 2016 |accessdate=9 November 2016}}</ref> Jon Coles of United Learning, which runs 60 schools is unconvinced more grammar schools will raise standards.<ref>{{cite web|last=Jeffreys |first=Branwen |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-37513737 |title=Academy boss says grammar plans may leave children behind – BBC News |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=30 September 2016 |accessdate=9 November 2016}}</ref> Poor children and children from families that are 'just about managing' tend to miss out on grammar school places.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-38251413 |title=Children of 'just managing families left out by grammars' - BBC News |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=23 February 2017}}</ref> None of the top ten nations with the best education has UK style grammar schools selecting at age 11.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bush |first=Stephen |url=http://www.newstatesman.com/politics/uk/2016/12/face-it-none-worlds-best-education-systems-include-grammar-schools |title=Face it: none of the world's best education systems include grammar schools |publisher=Newstatesman.com |date=11 December 2016 |accessdate=23 February 2017}}</ref> The [[Royal Society]] commissioned research from the [[Education Policy Institute]] which shows disadvantaged pupils do worse overall in science and maths in regions with selective education.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-38343307 |title=Grammars 'will not boost poorest pupils' science grades' - BBC News |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=23 February 2017}}</ref> A cross party [[Select Committee]] of MP's described the issue of grammar school expansion as an unnecessary distraction, cast doubt on the claim grammar schools improve social mobility and many speakers emphasized the need to tackle [[Education in the United Kingdom#Funding|funding problems effect on the whole of schooling]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Coughlan |first=Sean |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-38956439 |title=Grammars 'unnecessary distraction', say MPs - BBC News |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=23 February 2017}}</ref> Following the outcome of the [[United Kingdom general election, 2017|2017 General Election]], May's grammar school policy was not included in the [[Queen's Speech]], and is unlikely to be pursued.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Coughlan|first1=Sean|title=Queen's Speech: Grammar school expansion abandoned|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-40354365|website=BBC News Education|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=7 July 2017}}</ref>
===Child poverty=== The 'Child Poverty Unit' has been merged with the 'Department of Work and Pensions' leading to fears that [[child poverty]] will be less of a priority under May. This runs counter to May's pledge to govern for everyone and fight the injustice of being born poor. In 2014–2015 28% of UK children were poor.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bush |first=Stephen |url=http://www.newstatesman.com/politics/uk/2016/12/government-must-not-give-eliminating-child-poverty |title=The government must not give up on eliminating child poverty |publisher=Newstatesman.com |date=21 December 2016 |accessdate=23 February 2017}}</ref> The [[Child Poverty Action Group]] fears restricting the Child Poverty Unit to one department will reduce its effectiveness. The [[Institute for Fiscal Studies]] projects a 50% increase in child poverty by 2020 due to benefit cuts and 'sluggish wages'.<ref>{{cite web|author=Peter Walker Political correspondent |url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/dec/20/fears-after-government-abolishes-civil-services-child-poverty-unit |title=Fears after government abolishes civil service's child poverty unit | Society |publisher=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=23 February 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Rob Merrick Deputy Political Editor |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/theresa-may-child-poverty-unit-axe-whitehall-department-work-pensions-dwp-prime-minister-a7486131.html |title=Theresa May accused of abandoning fight against child poverty, after axing Whitehall unit devoted to it |publisher=The Independent |date=20 December 2016 |accessdate=23 February 2017}}</ref>
===Ministerial appointments=== {{main article|First May ministry}} May also appointed new Cabinet members, in "one of the most sweeping government reshuffles for decades"<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-wrapup-idUSKCN0ZU1HE |title=May builds new-look Brexit cabinet to steer EU divorce |last1=Holton |first1=Kate |last2=Pitas |first2=Costas |date=14 July 2016 |agency=Reuters |accessdate=14 July 2016}}</ref> described as "a brutal cull" by ''[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]'' since several prominent members, including six of Cameron's ministers, were removed from their posts.<ref>{{cite news |last=Hughes |first=Laura |date=14 July 2016 |title=Theresa May appoints Justine Greening and Liz Truss after mass cull of old government sees Michael Gove and Nicky Morgan axed |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/07/14/theresa-mays-cabinet-reshuffle-who-will-join-boris-johnson-and/ |newspaper=The Telegraph |location=London, UK |accessdate=14 July 2016}}</ref> The early appointments were interpreted both as "centrist and conciliatory," an effort to reunite the party in the wake of the UK's [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016|vote to leave the European Union]], and as "a shift to the right," according to ''[[The Guardian]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jul/13/theresa-may-becomes-britains-prime-minister|title=Theresa May appeals to centre ground but cabinet tilts to the right|first=Heather|last=Stewart|date=13 July 2016}}</ref> Robert Peston of ''[[ITV News]]'' specifically labelled her new Cabinet as right wing.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.itv.com/news/2016-07-14/may-appoints-right-wing-cabinet-for-left-wing-agenda/ |title=May appoints right wing cabinet for left wing agenda |last=Peston |first=Robert |date=14 July 2016 |website=ITV News |publisher=ITV |accessdate=15 July 2016 |quote=Her rhetoric is more left-wing than Cameron's was, her cabinet is more right wing than his was. It is not at all clear how this tension will play out.}}</ref>
May abolished the [[Department for Energy and Climate Change]] in a move widely criticised by [[Greenpeace]] which expressed concern the new government failed to see the threat from climate change, [[Friends of the Earth]] which said climate change is happening now while the new government lowers its priority, also by other more impartial people and groups.{{clarify|reason=The structure of this sentence makes this sentence difficult to understand.|date=July 2016}} Climate change is included in the scope of a new [[Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/environment/climate-change-department-killed-off-by-theresa-may-in-plain-stupid-and-deeply-worrying-move-a7137166.html|title=Climate change department killed off by Theresa May|date=14 July 2016}}</ref>
Upon becoming Prime Minister, May appointed former Mayor of London [[Boris Johnson]] to [[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs|Foreign Secretary]], former [[Secretary of State for Energy and Climate Change]] [[Amber Rudd]] to [[Home Secretary]], and former [[Shadow Home Secretary]] [[David Davis (British politician)|David Davis]] to the newly created office of "[[Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union|Brexit Secretary]]."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/0/who-is-david-davis-a-profile-of-britains-new-minister-for-brexit/ |title=Who is David Davis? A profile of Britain's new 'Brexit Secretary' |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=14 July 2016 |accessdate=9 November 2016}}</ref> Her choice of Boris Johnson for foreign secretary raised eyebrows,<ref>{{cite web |title= Boris Johnson is foreign secretary: The world reacts |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-36790977 |publisher= BBC News |date= 14 July 2016 |accessdate= 17 July 2016 }}</ref> and drew some criticism from the press.<ref>{{Cite news |author= Editorial |date= 17 July 2016 |title= The Observer view on the Labour party |url= https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/jul/17/observer-view-on-labour-party |newspaper= The Observer |accessdate= 17 July 2016 }}</ref> [[Liam Fox]] and [[Philip Hammond]], both of whom had previously served as [[Secretary of State for Defence]] (Fox in 2010–11 and Hammond in 2011–14), with Hammond having served as Foreign Secretary in 2014–16, were appointed to the newly created office of [[Secretary of State for International Trade|International Trade Secretary]] and [[Chancellor of the Exchequer|Chancellor]], respectively.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/theresa-may-gets-set-for-u-k-leadership-with-brexit-top-of-agenda-1468390512|title=U.K.'s Theresa May Readies Brexit Team With Boris Johnson in Key Cabinet Post|first1=Jenny|last1=Gross|first2=Jason|last2=Douglas|date=13 July 2016|via=Wall Street Journal}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Walker |first=Peter |date=14 July 2016 |title=Women get key jobs as Theresa May sacks four senior ministers |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/07/14/theresa-mays-cabinet-reshuffle-who-will-join-boris-johnson-and/ |newspaper=The Telegraph |location=London, UK |accessdate=14 July 2016}}</ref> Replacing [[Michael Gove]], [[Elizabeth Truss]] was made Justice Secretary, the "first female Lord Chancellor in the thousand-year history of the role".<ref>{{cite news |last=Walker |first=Peter |date=14 July 2016 |title=Theresa May appoints Justine Greening and Liz Truss after mass cull of old government sees Michael Gove and Nicky Morgan axed |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/07/14/theresa-mays-cabinet-reshuffle-who-will-join-boris-johnson-and/ |newspaper=The Telegraph |location=London, UK |accessdate=14 July 2016}}</ref> [[Andrea Leadsom]], who was energy minister and May's primary competitor for party leader, was made the new [[Secretary of State for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs]].<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Andrea Leadsom appointed environment secretary |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/blog/live/2016/jul/14/theresa-may-cabinet-reshuffle-boris-johnson-philip-hammond-rules-out-emergency-budget |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London, UK |date=14 July 2016 |accessdate=14 July 2016}}</ref> However, former Northern Ireland Secretary [[Theresa Villiers]] resigned from Cabinet after May offered her a post which was "not one which I felt I could take on".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-northern-ireland-36793163 |title=Theresa Villiers to be replaced as Northern Ireland secretary |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=14 July 2016 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=14 July 2016}}</ref>
May jointly appointed [[Fiona Hill]] and [[Nick Timothy]] on 14 July as her joint [[Downing Street Chief of Staff|Downing Street Chiefs of Staff]].<ref name="Nick Timothy: Theresa May’s political ‘brain’">{{cite web|last1=Parker|first1=George|title=Nick Timothy: Theresa May’s political ‘brain’|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/29fa0986-49cf-11e6-b387-64ab0a67014c.html|website=[[Financial Times]]|accessdate=15 July 2016}}</ref> Both had been political advisers to her at the Home Office before both working outside the government for a brief period before coming to work on her leadership campaign.<ref name="Beware the aides of May!">{{cite web|last1=Hardman|first1=Isabel|title=Beware the aides of May! The people who'll really run the new government|url=http://www.spectator.co.uk/2016/07/mays-man-influence/|website=The Spectator|accessdate=15 July 2016}}</ref><ref name="Press Release: Downing Street political advisers">{{cite web|title=Press Release: Downing Street political advisers|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/downing-street-political-advisers|website=[[Gov.uk]]|accessdate=15 July 2016}}</ref> The three ministers with new roles who will negotiate the UK out of the EU had all espoused the Leave vote: David Davis, Brexit secretary, Liam Fox, overseas trade secretary and Boris Johnson, foreign secretary.<ref name="auto" />
===First overseas trips=== [[File:Theresa May foreign trips.png|thumb|300px|World map highlighting countries visited by Theresa May during her premiership]] [[File:Davos 2017 - Special Address by Theresa May, Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.webm|thumb|left|May addressing the [[World Economic Forum]] in 2017]] On 20 July, May attended her first [[Prime Minister's Questions]] since taking office, then afterwards made her first [[List of international prime ministerial trips made by Theresa May|overseas trip as prime minister]], visiting [[Government of Germany|Berlin]] for talks with German Chancellor [[Angela Merkel]]. During the visit, May said that she would not trigger [[Article 50 of the Treaty of Lisbon|Article 50]] before 2017, suggesting it would take time for the UK to negotiate a "sensible and orderly departure" from the EU. May also announced that in the wake of the referendum, Britain would relinquish the [[presidency of the Council of the European Union]] that the UK had been scheduled to hold in the second half of 2017.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-36841066 |title=Brexit: Theresa May says talks won't start in 2016 |publisher=BBC News |date=20 July 2016 |accessdate=20 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Rowena |last=Mason |first2=Philip |last2=Oltermann |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/jul/20/angela-merkel-backs-theresa-mays-plan-not-to-trigger-brexit-this-year |title=Angela Merkel backs Theresa May's plan not to trigger Brexit this year |newspaper=The Guardian |date=20 July 2016 |accessdate=20 July 2016}}</ref>
On 4 September, May attended the [[2016 G20 Hangzhou summit]], the first since the UK's [[Withdrawal from the European Union by the United Kingdom|withdrawal from the European Union]]. May sought to use the summit to emphasise her commitment to making the UK a "global leader in free trade" She also faced questions over the decision to delay planned Chinese investment in [[Hinkley Point C]].<ref>{{cite web|title=G20: Theresa May faces Brexit trade pressure|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-37269916|website=BBC News Politics|publisher=BBC|accessdate=4 September 2016}}</ref>
On 21 January 2017, following the [[inauguration of Donald Trump|inauguration]] of [[Donald Trump]] as US President, the [[White House]] announced that May would meet the President on 27 January, making her the first foreign leader to meet Trump since he took office on 20 January.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-38707524 |title=Theresa May to meet Donald Trump on Friday – White House |publisher=BBC News |date=21 January 2017 |accessdate=21 January 2017}}</ref>
==Policies==
===Foreign policy=== The [[First May ministry|May Ministry]] delayed the final approval for the [[Hinkley Point C nuclear power station]] in July 2016, a project which May had objected to when she was Home Secretary.<ref>{{cite web|author=Graham Ruddick |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/jul/29/hinkley-point-c-why-has-government-delayed-final-approval |title=Why have ministers delayed final approval for Hinkley Point C? |work=The Guardian |date=29 July 2016 |accessdate=9 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Daniel Boffey |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/jul/30/theresa-may-delayed-hinkley-point-chinese-beijing-vince-cable |title=Theresa May 'raised objections to project as home secretary' |work=The Guardian |date=30 July 2016 |accessdate=9 November 2016}}</ref> Her [[Special advisers (UK government)|political adviser]] [[Nick Timothy]] wrote an article in 2015 to oppose People's Republic of China's involvement in sensitive sectors. He said that the government was "selling our [[national security]] to China" without [[rational]] concerns and "the Government seems intent on ignoring the evidence and presumably the advice of the security and intelligence agencies."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.conservativehome.com/thecolumnists/2015/10/nick-timothy-the-government-is-selling-our-national-security-to-china.html |title=Nick Timothy: The Government is selling our national security to China |publisher=Conservative Home |date=20 October 2015 |accessdate=9 November 2016}}</ref>
Politicians and human rights activists have been urging Theresa May's government to vote against Saudi Arabian retention of the membership of the [[United Nations Human Rights Council|UN Human Rights Council]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Allan Hennessy |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/saudi-arabia-un-human-rights-council-theresa-may-expel-she-should-enough-a7199066.html |title=Theresa May should expel Saudi Arabia from the UN Human Rights Council, but that's not enough to absolve the UK |work=The Independent |date=19 August 2016 |accessdate=9 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Jon Stone |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/saudi-arabia-human-rights-un-united-nations-uk-british-elected-behead-a7140501.html |title=British government refuses to rule out re-electing Saudi Arabia to UN human rights council |work=The Independent |date=16 July 2016 |accessdate=9 November 2016}}</ref> [[Amnesty International]]'s UK Foreign Policy Programme Director Polly Truscott said: "Rather than turning a blind eye to Saudi Arabia’s continuing bully tactics, the UK should publicly hold the Saudi authorities to account for its appalling human rights record and the ongoing [[Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen#Reports of war crimes|war crimes in Yemen]] and should stop selling weapons to Saudi as a matter of urgency."<ref>{{cite news|author=Joe Watts |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/saudi-arabia-human-rights-council-theresa-may-abuses-yemen-executions-a7198346.html |title=Theresa May urged to vote against Saudi Arabia remaining on Human Rights Council over abuses |work=The Independent |date=18 August 2016 |accessdate=9 November 2016}}</ref> May defended selling arms to Saudi Arabia stating that close ties with the country "keep people on the streets of Britain safe".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Merrick|first1=Rob|title=Theresa May claims selling arms to Saudi Arabia helps 'keep people on the streets of Britain safe'|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/arms-sales-saudi-arabia-theresa-may-staunch-defence-keep-people-streets-britain-safe-a7230836.html|accessdate=5 June 2017|work=The Independent|date=7 September 2016}}</ref>
===Economic policy and austerity programme=== Prior to her premiership, May outlined plans to backtrack on the longstanding government plan to achieve a surplus by 2020, following the UK's [[Withdrawal from the European Union by the United Kingdom|withdrawal from the European Union]]. With uncertainty surrounding the economic outlook, [[Chancellor of the Exchequer]] [[Philip Hammond|Phillip Hammond]] has suggested that the government's [[Autumn Statement]] may be used to "reset" economic policy.<ref>{{cite web|title=Chancellor may 'reset' economic policy in Autumn Statement|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-36864099|website=BBC News Business|publisher=BBC|accessdate=4 September 2016}}</ref>
On 2015, while May was Home Secretary, a 18% funding cut in the police force had taken place with the loss of around 20,000 police officers. Before the [[2017 Manchester Arena bombing]] and after the [[November 2015 Paris attacks|Paris attacks]], she was warned by a Manchester senior police officer that the cuts on the force and [[community policing]] risked terror attacks in the city due the lack of resources to do proper intelligence and anti-terrorist measures.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bienkov|first1=Adam|title=Theresa May was warned by Manchester police officer that cuts risked terror attack in the city|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/theresa-may-warned-by-manchester-police-that-cuts-risked-terror-attack-2017-5?r=UK&IR=T|accessdate=26 May 2017|work=Business Insider|date=26 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Waugh|first1=Paul|title=Theresa May’s Police Cuts Exposed By Manchester Bombing Army Deployment - Police Federation|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/theresa-may-army-deployment-manchester-bombing-police-federation-police-cuts-steve-white_uk_5925d9f0e4b062f96a336e5f|accessdate=26 May 2017|work=Huffington Post|date=24 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Police cuts: Terror response warning to home secretary|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-34875077|accessdate=26 May 2017|work=BBC|date=20 November 2015}}</ref>
In May's and Hammond's 2017 budget continued government policies of freezing benefits.<ref>[http://www.newstatesman.com/politics/welfare/2017/03/what-welfare-changes-did-philip-hammond-make-his-budget-2017 What welfare changes did Philip Hammond make in his Budget 2017?] ''[[New Statesman]]''</ref>
===European Union=== May has not given MPs a vote over the [[European Union]] despite in 2007 calling for MPs to have the right of veto over European talks.{{Citation needed|date=February 2017}} [[Nicky Morgan]] stated "in 2016 MPs aren't asking for a veto but they do want a say and we hope the Prime Minister will remember her earlier words". [[Anna Soubry]] and [[Nick Clegg]] also called for more parliamentary involvement.<ref>{{cite news|author=Ashley Cowburn |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/theresa-may-brexit-article-50-brussels-negotiating-strategy-brussels-a7386156.html |title=Brexit: Theresa May urged to ‘remember her words’ after calling for MPs right to veto European talks in 2007 |work=The Independent |date=29 October 2016 |accessdate=9 November 2016}}</ref> In November 2016, the [[High Court of Justice|High Court]] ruled in [[R (Miller) v Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union]] that parliament must vote on the decision to leave the EU but May appealed to the [[Supreme Court of the United Kingdom|Supreme Court]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-37857785 |title=Brexit court defeat for UK government – |publisher=BBC News |date=3 November 2016 |accessdate=9 November 2016}}</ref> [[Nicola Sturgeon]], Scottish [[First Minister of Scotland|First Minister]] has joined the case as have representatives of Wales and Northern Ireland. Sturgeon feels the [[Scottish Parliament]] should also consent to the UK triggering of Article 50. She says she will not seek to prevent England and Wales leaving but wants to preserve Scotland's place in the EU.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-37909299 |title=Scottish government seeks to intervene in Brexit case – |publisher=BBC News |date=3 November 2016 |accessdate=9 November 2016}}</ref> In the end the Supreme Court required a vote in the UK parliament.
May was accused of not having a plan if Brexit talks break down. There are fears if talks fail Britain could be left trading under [[World Trade Organization|WTO]] rules which it is feared would seriously damage jobs and livelihoods in Britain and Europe. May's ministers have repeatedly promised to walk away from a bad final deal but, it is argued, have no plans for how to manage without a deal.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/mar/11/brexit-trigger-article-50-theresa MPs slam Theresa May over lack of a plan if Brexit talks collapse] ''[[The Guardian]]''</ref> [[Ivan Rogers]] described May's Brexit strategy as “an accident waiting to happen”. He said completing Brexit was “guaranteed” to take a decade and alleged May's unrealistic hopes of a trade deal made to order meant a car crash in the next few months was “quite likely”.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/nov/25/phil-hogan-ireland-eu-commissioner-brexit-chaos Irish warn Theresa May: change course or risk Brexit chaos] ''[[The Observer]]''</ref>
===Workers' representatives=== In July 2016 May said that she planned to have workers represented on company boards, saying "If I'm prime minister ... we're going to have not just consumers represented on company boards, but workers as well."<ref name="theguardian1">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/nils-pratley-on-finance/2016/jul/11/theresa-may-plan-workers-boardroom-reform-extraordinary-tories |title=Theresa May's plan to put workers in boardrooms is extraordinary | Politics |work=The Guardian |date=11 July 2016 |accessdate=23 February 2017}}</ref> May aimed to put workers' and consumers' representatives on boards to make them more accountable.<ref>{{cite web|author=Sean Farrell |url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/oct/02/theresa-may-tory-conference-workers-on-boards |title=Workers on boards: the idea is not going away | Business |work=The Guardian |date=2 October 2016 |accessdate=23 February 2017}}</ref> [[Nils Pratley]], a journalist at ''[[The Guardian]]'', wrote in July "Fundamental principles of Britain's boardroom governance are being rethought. It is a very welcome development. In the more enlightened quarters of the UK corporate world, they can see that boardroom pay has eroded trust in business."<ref name="theguardian1"/> Workers' representatives it appeared, would have made UK companies more like those in Germany and France.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stephanie Baker |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/theresa-may-board-corporate-plan-germany-france-productivity-economics-a7132221.html |title=Theresa May's plan to put workers on boards is borrowed from Germany and France |work=The Independent |date=12 July 2016 |accessdate=23 February 2017}}</ref> May was accused of backtracking in November 2016 when she said that firms would not be forced to adopt the proposal, saying "there are a number of ways in which that can be achieved".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-38044015 |title=Theresa May bids to reassure business on Brexit 'cliff-edge' – |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=23 February 2017}}</ref>
===Response to Donald Trump's Muslim ban=== Theresa May was strongly criticised in the United Kingdom<ref name="ip2">{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/muslim-ban-exemption-donald-trump-theresa-may-fall-out-a7552321.html|title= Pressure grows on May as a million people sign anti-Trump petition over 'Muslim ban'|date=29 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-38784199|title=Theresa May fails to condemn Donald Trump on refugees|date=28 January 2017|via=bbc.com}}</ref><ref name="bi1">{{cite web|url=http://nordic.businessinsider.com/theresa-may-critisied-for-not-condemning-donald-trump-muslim-ban-2017-1?r=US&IR=T|title=Theresa May is at heart of a political storm over her 'weak' response to Trump's Muslim ban|work=[[Business Insider]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/petition-to-cancel-trump-visit-to-uk-hits-1-million-signatures/article33822031/|title=British PM Theresa May faces tough lesson over Trump's U.S. entry ban}}</ref> by members of all major parties, including her own, for refusing to condemn [[Donald Trump]]'s [[Executive Order 13769]] (colloquially known as the "Muslim ban")<ref name="ip2" /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/donald-trump-theresa-may-muslim-ban-latest-boris-johnson-commons-statement-white-house-a7554261.html|title=Boris Johnson faces accusations that Theresa May was told the 'Muslim ban' was coming|date=30 January 2017}}</ref><ref name="bi1" /> as well as for inviting Trump to a state visit with [[Queen Elizabeth II]].<ref name="McCann-Tele1Feb">{{cite news|last1=McCann|first1=Kate|title=Theresa May rejects calls to block Donald Trump's state visit in fierce exchange with Jeremy Corbyn|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/02/01/theresa-may-rejects-calls-block-donald-trumps-state-visit-fierce/|accessdate=2 February 2017|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=1 February 2017}}</ref>
More than 1.8 million signed an official parliamentary [[e-petition]] which said that "Donald Trump's well documented misogyny and vulgarity disqualifies him from being received by Her Majesty the Queen or the Prince of Wales,"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://europe.newsweek.com/donald-trump-muslim-ban-protest-petition-sign-number-signatures-state-visit-550048|title=A petition to stop Donald Trump's planned visit to the U.K. has surpassed a million signatures}}</ref> and Labour leader [[Jeremy Corbyn]] said in [[Prime Minister's Questions]] (PMQs) that Trump should not be welcomed to Britain "while he abuses our shared values with his shameful Muslim ban and attacks on refugees' and women's rights"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-38805196|title=Trump state visit plan 'very difficult' for Queen|date=31 January 2017|via=bbc.com}}</ref> and said that Trump should be banned from the UK until the bar on Muslims entering the US is lifted.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/01/nationwide-protests-uk-trump-muslim-ban-170131014554397.html|title=Nationwide protests in the UK over Trump's Muslim ban}}</ref><ref name="McCann-Tele1Feb" />
[[Sayeeda Warsi, Baroness Warsi|Baroness Warsi]], former chair of the Conservatives, accused May of "bowing down" to Trump, who she described as "a man who has no respect for women, disdain for minorities, little value for LGBT communities, no compassion clearly for the vulnerable and whose policies are rooted in divisive rhetoric."<ref name="independent17">{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/baroness-warsi-cabinet-minister-theresa-may-donald-trump-travel-ban-muslim-immigration-uk-state-a7552631.html|title=Ex Cabinet minister tells Government to consider cancelling Trump state visit|date=30 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/donald-trump-travel-ban-muslims-theresa-may-families-torn-apart-a7553016.html|title=Theresa May will find herself as hated as Trump if she keeps sacrificing our ethics for trade deals|date=30 January 2017}}</ref> London Mayor [[Sadiq Khan]] and the Conservative leader in Scotland, [[Ruth Davidson]], also called for the visit to be cancelled.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nordic.businessinsider.com/theresa-may-says-donald-trump-visit-will-go-ahead-despite-petition-against-it-2017-1|title=May says Trump state visit will go ahead no matter how many people sign a petition against it}}</ref><ref name="independent17" />
===Executive pay=== May is considering forcing companies to reveal the difference between what their CEOs are paid and what their ordinary workers are paid.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-38120604 |title=Executive pay: Companies could be forced to reveal pay gap – |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=23 February 2017}}</ref>
===Environment=== Following the impact of ''[[Blue Planet II]]'' in 2017, the May administration outlined plans to approve further green policy. A particular focus has been on plastic and its impact on the environment. In March 2018, May announced plans for a plastic deposit scheme modelled on a similar policy in Norway to boost recycling. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-43563164|title=Drinks bottles and can deposit return scheme proposed|date=27 March 2018|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref>
==2017 general election== {{main|United Kingdom general election, 2017|Second May ministry}} On 18 April 2017, in a surprise statement made outside 10 Downing Street, May announced that she was to seek parliamentary approval for an early election to be held. She explained that, following the country's decision last summer to leave the European Union, she had "only recently and reluctantly come to this conclusion" and that although she had "said that there should be no election until 2020", that she had "concluded that the only way to guarantee certainty and stability for the years ahead is to hold this election and seek your support for the decisions I must take."<ref>{{cite news|title=Theresa May's general election statement in full|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-39630009|accessdate=19 April 2017|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=18 April 2017}}</ref> May previously indicated through a [[spokesperson]] she had no plan for a general election, the spokesperson stated, “There isn’t going to be one. It isn’t going to happen. There is not going to be a general election.” She denied there would be an election many times.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blogs.spectator.co.uk/2017/04/five-times-theresa-may-no-10-ruled-snap-general-election/#|title=Five times Theresa May ruled out a snap general election - Coffee House|date=18 April 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/apr/18/labour-jeremy-corbyn-time-to-fight-theresa-may|title=Labour is in deep trouble, but it’s our only defence against a Tory landslide|date=18 April 2017|publisher=|via=The Guardian}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/apr/18/the-many-times-theresa-may-ruled-out-an-early-election|title=The many times Theresa May ruled out an early election|first=Matthew|last=Weaver|date=18 April 2017|publisher=|via=The Guardian}}</ref> On 19 April 2017 MPs gave May the two-thirds [[super-majority]] required to call the [[snap election]] she had called for. MPs voted 522 in favour and 13 against, giving the go-ahead for the election to be held on 8 June 2017.<ref>{{cite news|title=General election campaigning begins as MPs back June poll|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-39643804|accessdate=19 April 2017|work=BBC News|issue=19 April 2017|publisher=BBC}}</ref>
[[File:Theresa May 2017 election speech outside 10 Downing Street.jpg|thumb|May making a speech outside 10 Downing Street following the 2017 general election]] As of 9 June 2017 the Conservative Party lost seats and Labour gained seats. The Conservatives remained the largest single party but without an absolute majority. In the immediate aftermath of the election, it was unclear if Theresa May would continue as Prime Minister.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/jun/09/what-is-a-hung-parliament-and-what-happens-now What is a hung parliament and what happens now?] ''[[The Guardian]]''</ref> May stated that she would have an informal understanding with the DUP to keep the Conservatives in government.
On 10 June 2017 10 Downing Street issued a statement that a [[Conservative–DUP agreement]] was reached in principle.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/election-2017-40236152|title=Election 2017: DUP agrees 'confidence' deal with Tories|date=10 June 2017|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref> A few hours later, the statement was retracted when it was claimed that it had been "issued in error" and that talks between the Conservative Party and DUP were still ongoing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/dup-tory-deal_uk_593ce995e4b0c5a35ca037cd?cop|title=Theresa May Mocked Mercilessly For 'Omnishambles' After DUP Deal Statement 'Issued In Error'|date=11 June 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
On 11 June 2017 former [[Chancellor of the Exchequer]], [[George Osborne]], described May as a "dead woman walking".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/06/11/theresa-may-dead-woman-walking-george-osborne-says-dup-deal/|title=Cabinet reshuffle: Michael Gove appointed Environment Secretary in shock return to frontline politics|publisher=}}</ref>
==Second term== {{Incomplete section|date=November 2018}} The [[Grenfell Tower fire]], [[Windrush scandal]], [[Universal Credit]] and [[Brexit]] all caused problems for May's government.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/long_reads/theresa-may-uk-prime-minister-two-years-brexit-tory-dup-deal-conservative-cabinet-boris-johnson-a8434761.html Two years after coming to power, Theresa May's premiership is the most shambolic for a century] ''[[The Independent]]''</ref> The UK government is struggling with [[Brexit]] and cannot easily reach an agreement that is acceptable to the Conservative party, to Conservative MP's or to the cabinet. How to manage the border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic is one major problem.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/oct/14/david-davis-calls-on-ministers-to-rebel-against-brexit-deal David Davis calls on ministers to rebel against Brexit deal] ''[[The Guardian]]''</ref>
Potential candidates for a future general election are reluctant to put their names forward. Suspected reasons include being demoralized by May's premiership and lack of confidence that the Conservatives can win.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/general-election-conservative-party-candidates-shortage-theresa-may-leadership-brexit-mps-a8582296.html Conservatives hit by candidate shortage for general election because activists 'demoralised' by Theresa May] ''[[The Independent]]''</ref>
Following the announcement of May's controversial draft withdrawal agreement, the deal received widespread criticism and at least 23 Conservative MP's proceeded to submit a letter demanding a [[Motions of no confidence in the United Kingdom|vote of no confidence]] (a total 48 letters from MP's are needed trigger one).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/5455723/u-k-prime-minister-vote-no-confidence-brexit/|title=U.K. Prime Minister Faces Possible No Confidence Vote After Presenting E.U. Brexit Deal|last=|first=|date=|website=Time|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=17 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/nov/16/the-tory-mps-known-to-have-sent-a-letter-of-no-confidence-in-may|title=The Tory MPs known to have sent a letter of no confidence in May|last=staff|first=Guardian|date=2018-11-16|website=the Guardian|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=17 November 2018}}</ref> In addition to this, 4 ministers, including cabinet members [[Esther McVey]] and [[Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union|Brexit Secretary]] [[Dominic Raab]] resigned over the deal.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/5455476/uk-cabinet-resign-raab-mcvey-brexit/|title=2 U.K. Cabinet Ministers Resign, Throwing Brexit Plan Into Turmoil|last=|first=|date=|website=Time|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=17 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/11/15/resignation-watch-cabinet-ministers-whove-resigned-brexit-deal1/|title=Resignation watch: Cabinet ministers who've resigned over the Brexit deal - and who could still go|last=Mikhailova|first=Anna|date=15 November 2018|work=The Telegraph|access-date=15 November 2018|last2=Yorke|first2=Harry|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref> However, a poll of 505 Conservative councillors found that a majority wanted MPs to back the prime minister, despite the fact that more were against the deal than for it.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-46250607|title=May: Ousting me won't help Brexit|last=|first=|date=18 November 2018|work=BBC News|access-date=18 November 2018|language=en-GB}}</ref>
==International issues== {{See also|List of international prime ministerial trips made by Theresa May}} ===Brexit=== Following Cabinet agreement for May's proposals on Brexit, [[David Davis (British politician)|David Davis]] resigned from his government position on 8 July 2018.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Rayner |first1=Gordon |title=David Davis resigns as Brexit secretary |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/politics/2018/07/08/david-davis-resigns-brexit-secretary/ |accessdate=8 July 2018 |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=8 July 2018}}</ref><ref name="resignation">{{cite news |title=Brexit Secretary David Davis resigns |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-44761056 |work=BBC News |date=9 July 2018}}</ref> Following that, [[Steve Baker (politician)|Steve Baker]] also resigned. On the same day it was reported that Theresa May was facing the threat of a leadership contest amid mounting anger from Brexiteers over her government's Brexit policy.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/brexit-latest-theresa-may-leadership-challenge-plan-tories-mps-chequers-jacob-rees-mogg-a8437706.html|title=Theresa May faces leadership challenge threat from Tory Brexiteers|publisher=}}</ref> Conservative Party backbencher [[Andrea Jenkyns]] called on for the Prime Minister to be replaced. saying “Theresa May's premiership is over”.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2018/07/top-uk-brexit-officials-resign-in-blow-to-theresa-may.html|title=Top Brexit Officials Resign in Blow to Theresa May|first=Margaret|last=Hartmann|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/brexit/2018/0709/977344-brexit-british-government/|title=May to fight any leadership challenge|date=9 July 2018|publisher=}}</ref> [[Boris Johnson]] also later resigned as [[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs|Foreign Secretary]] on 9 July 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/jul/09/boris-johnson-resigns-as-foreign-secretary-brexit|title=Boris Johnson resigns as foreign secretary over May's Brexit plans|last=|first=|date=|website=The Guardian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> ===Policy regarding foreign capital punishment=== In July 2018, it was announced The UK government said it will not object to the United States seeking the death penalty for two suspected British members of ISIL. Waiving its long-standing objection to foreign executions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-07-23/britain-will-not-block-death-penalty-for-is-suspects:-reports/10027240|title=Britain would not block death penalty for IS 'Beatle' suspects|date=23 July 2018|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/07/22/uk-drops-death-penalty-guantanamo-opposition-opens-door-execution/|title=Sajid Javid tells US: We won't block death penalty for Isil 'Beatles'|first=Ben|last=Riley-Smith|date=22 July 2018|publisher=|via=www.telegraph.co.uk}}</ref>

{{for|the Canadian soccer team|ProStars FC}} {{lead too short|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox television | show_name = ProStars | image = Prostars title.jpg | caption = "''ProStars,'' it's all about helping kids." | genre = [[Animation]] | camera = | picture_format = | audio_format = | based_on = an idea created by Douglas Booth | creator = Andy Heyward
Douglas Booth | developer = Rob Humphrey

[[Susan Silo]] | narrated = | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | endtheme = | country = United States | location = | language = English | network = [[NBC]] | first_aired = September 14, 1991 | last_aired = December 7, 1991 | num_seasons = 1 | num_episodes = 13 | list_episodes = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = | website = }} '''''ProStars''''' is a cartoon television show featured on [[Saturday morning cartoon]]. It was produced by [[DIC Entertainment|DiC]] and aired on [[NBC]] from September 14 to December 7, 1991. Three famous and popular professional athletes from the 1990s appear in the show in live action and as fictional super hero characters: '''[[Michael Jordan]]''', '''[[Wayne Gretzky]]''' and '''[[Bo Jackson]]'''. ==Overview== ===Synopsis=== Originally intended to air on [[ESPN]], the show centers on [[Michael Jordan]], [[Bo Jackson]] and [[Wayne Gretzky]] fighting crime, helping children, and often protecting the environment as well. These three were chosen to represent the pinnacle of [[Major professional sports leagues in the United States and Canada#Big Four leagues|all four major American professional sports]] in the early 1990s. While Jordan and Gretzky are broadly associated with their respective sports, Jackson was included since he could represent both [[American football|football]] and [[baseball]] and was a high-profile celebrity off the field as well. A reference to his "[[Bo Knows]]" [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] ad-campaign was worked into almost every episode. ===Live-action sequences=== The stars appear in live-action sequences before the show, in which they would tell kids about the upcoming episode, and often answer questions from kids at the conclusion. Normally this is done solely by Gretzky and Jackson—often in separate sound stages and edited to appear as if talking to each other. Jordan's filmed bits were almost always one line or two, and not part of the skits before the episode. Most of the live-action parts by the athletes dealt with things such as morality. In one episode they explained ghosts stating that even they get scared sometimes, and that fear is a normal human emotion. In an episode with robot athletes, they explained how such an idea will never come to reality, as it goes against the dedication men put into their sport. However, during the animated segments of ''ProStars'', their animated counterparts were voiced by [[voice actor]]s instead of their actual selves. ===Theme music=== When the show first came out, the original theme song, "We Are ProStars", was an homage to the song "[[We Will Rock You]]", by the rock group, [[Queen (band)|Queen]] (see links below). In later episodes, the song was slowed down, and the chorus was reduced to 'ProStars! Show staaaars! The lyrics also reference the "[[Bo Knows]]" ad campaign, including the line "Bo knows everything." ==Characters== Each character on ''ProStars'' has one stand-out character trait, especially the ProStars themselves: * '''[[Michael Jordan]]''' (voiced by [[Dorian Harewood]]): He is the leader of the troupe. He is exceptionally smart and talented with complicated contraptions, and he encourages children to study [[mathematics]] and the sciences. * '''[[Wayne Gretzky]]''' (voiced by [[Townsend Coleman]]): He typically plays the role of comic relief. Inexplicably, his mind is always on food. * '''[[Bo Jackson]]''' (voiced by [[Dave Fennoy]]): He provides the proverbial "muscle" for the heroes. He is immensely strong, and has a bit of a mean streak. His strength often approaches [[superhuman]] levels, such as in the series opening, when he uses a gigantic tree trunk like a club against a logging robot. * '''Mom''' (voiced by [[Susan Silo]]): A quasi-[[Yiddish]] and [[Jewish mother]] stereotype, she is the [[Q (James Bond)|Q]] to the ProStars' [[James Bond]]. She constantly invents wacky gadgets loosely based on sports equipment for the heroes to use. The ProStars spend all their free time in ''Mom's Gym'', and possibly live there as well. It also serves as the ProStars' "headquarters". * '''Denise''' (voiced by [[Diana Barrows]]): She is an attractive young apprentice to Mom. She wants to help the ProStars, yet she rarely makes an impact. * '''The Neighbor''': He is a hapless man who wears glasses and happens to live in the same neighborhood as the ProStars' headquarters. By sheer misfortune, he happens to fall victim to the malfunctions of the ProStars' machines, such as when he is buried in snow after their climate machine goes awry. In another episode, he takes a vacation to the [[Himalayas]], and he enjoys the isolation and confidence that he is far away from any mishaps the ProStars could unleash, only to find the ProStars are also in the area stopping a villain there. ===Villains=== In nearly every episode the ProStars would get a message by [[teleconference]] from a child explaining the situation such as a little boy from an island in the [[South Sea Islands|South Seas]] who said his village's treasures were being stolen by Short John Silver. Most of the villains were standard cartoon fare and had often done villainous acts akin to cartoons of the early 1990s (such as ''[[Captain Planet and the Planeteers|Captain Planet]]'' and ''[[Free Willy (TV series)|Free Willy]]''), namely environmental irresponsibility such as [[strip mining]], coastal pollution, or deforestation of the [[rainforest]]. Other times, a villain might hold a child for ransom, such as a [[mad scientist]] named Dr. Lobe who demanded the ProStars play his line of robot athletes in order to release a little girl he kidnapped. Episodes also touched upon kids in gangs, where an Australian village is being held captive by Gargantus' [[Outlaw motorcycle club|motorcycle gang]] and a little girl's brother joins the gang thinking they are macho to which Michael Jordan tells the little girl she cannot stop having faith or love in her brother. One episode dealt with the [[larceny]] of the [[Stanley Cup]] committed by Clockwork Delaronge (which is a personal issue for Wayne Gretzky as his name is carved on it four times) and he tells kids of the history and prestige of the award. ==Episodes== # '''The Slugger Returns''' - The ProStars come to the aid of Jimmy Hanks when his father "Slugger" Hanks is captured by a [[mad scientist]] named Clockwork Delaronge who is using remote-controlled [[robot]]s including one of dead baseball star Cleets Robinson as part of a plot to capture the Commissioner of Baseball. # '''Short John's Revenge''' - A [[Piracy|pirate]] supervillain named Short John Silver sails into an idyllic Caribbean Island, imprisons the inhabitants, and steals the ancient pirate treasure they had discovered. # '''The Perbots of Dr. Lobe''' - A [[mad scientist]] named Dr. Lobe proposes a competition to the ProStars to compete against his Perbots for the fate of a girl named Jill. # '''Knightmare Riders''' - The ProStars travel to Scotland to save a community from the Ghost Riders of Sir Vitus. This is a cover-up by the evil Carlotta to drive away the golfers so that she can excavate the Golden Throne of Sir Vitus. # '''Valley of the Snow Falcon''' - Ice Mancuso, an unscrupulous [[engineer]], intends to conceal diamond masks at a mysterious kingdom in the Himalayas. With the help of a young princess and a mysterious Snow Falcon, the ProStars jump into action to save the kingdom. # '''Brazil Nuts''' - Captain Nemo Ipanema is destroying the Brazilian rainforest as a side to his mining operation designed to secure the world's supply of Amazonite for his own egomaniacal use. # '''Block Busters''' - Paulie Sludger, a corrupt businessman, frightens a block center population with the intent of purchasing the neighborhood for his toxic waste dumping operation. # '''Gargantus and the Highway of Doom''' - A girl named Sheila calls the ProStars to Australia when Gargantus and his [[Outlaw motorcycle club|motorcycle gang]] are terrorizing an Australian village and forcing the inhabitants to build his castle. The worst part of it is that her brother Keith has joined up with Gargantus. # '''Rustler's Rodeo''' - Dusty Boots intends to win the prize money for a rodeo contest and pay off the debt owed by his family so that he can buy back the family ranch. But a [[gangster]] who intends to buy out the ranch for himself has complicated matters by kidnapping Dusty's horse. # '''Roll to Victory''' - When a local basketball charity is at risk of being closed down due to cheap shot tactics by the Pontiac Hoods led by Doug, it's up to the ProStars to stop them. # '''A Bite of the Big Apple''' - The ProStars search for an archeologist whose family has not heard from him since he began a dig along the River of No Return. # '''Clockwork Catastrophe''' - Clockwork Delaronge has returned. This time, he has stolen the famous Stanley Cup. It is up to the ProStars to skate into action and get it back. # '''The Final Cut''' - In this clip episode, Mom challenges the ProStars on their efficiency, prompting them to prove her wrong by showing her their past adventures. ==Principal cast== * [[Diana Barrows]] - Denise * [[Townsend Coleman]] - Wayne Gretzky * [[Dave Fennoy]] - Bo Jackson * [[Dorian Harewood]] - Michael Jordan * [[Susan Silo]] - Mom ===Additional voices=== {{col-start}} {{col-2}} * [[Charlie Adler]] - Froggy (ep. 8) * [[Marv Albert]] - Rodeo Announcer (ep. 9) * [[Jack Angel]] - * [[William Callaway|Bill Callaway]] - * [[Brian Cummings]] - Doug (ep. 10) * [[Jim Cummings]] - * [[Debi Derryberry]] - * [[Pat Fraley]] - * [[Mike Fratello]] - * [[Ben Ganger]] - * [[Ellen Gerstell]] - * [[Dan Gilvezan]] - * [[Edan Gross]] - * [[Whitby Hertford]] - * [[Dana Hill]] - Keith (ep. 8) * [[Jerry Houser]] - {{col-2}} * [[Robert Ito]] - * [[Richard Karron]] - * [[Art Kimbro]] - * [[David Lander]] - * [[Katie Leigh]] - * [[Sherry Lynn]] - * [[Tress MacNeille]] - Carlotta (ep. 4) * [[Candi Milo]] - * [[Robert Morse]] - * [[Rob Paulsen]] - * [[Hal Rayle]] - * [[Neil Ross]] - * [[Ron Rubin (voice actor)|Ron Rubin]] - * [[Justin Shenkarow]] - * [[R. {{Politics of Australia sidebar}} The '''Proposed Australian constitutional referendum, 2013''' refers to an Australian referendum which was planned, and then abandoned, in 2013.
==History== The referendum was proposed to change s 96 of the [[Constitution of Australia]] to allow the [[Commonwealth of Australia]] to directly fund [[Local government in Australia|local councils]].<ref name=BS>[http://www.businessspectator.com.au/news/2013/6/24/politics/local-govt-referendum-planned Local govt referendum planned] Business Spectator, 24 June 2013</ref> Similar referendums failed to pass in [[Australian referendum, 1974 (Local Government Bodies)|1974]] and [[Australian referendum, 1988 (Local Government)|1988]].
The proposed constitutional alteration was passed by both Houses of Parliament as the '''''Constitution Alteration (Local Government) 2013'''''.<ref>[http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/cth/bill_em/cag2013433/memo_0.html ''Constitution Alteration (Local Government) 2013'', Explanatory Memorandum]</ref>
The "yes" campaign was supported by both the government and opposition leader [[Tony Abbott]].<ref name=BS/>
The federal government allocated $10 million to the "yes" campaign, but just $500,000 to the "no" campaign. The difference in funding led seven senators from the Coalition to vote against the referendum bill in the [[Australian Senate|Senate]], although it passed by 46 votes to eight.<ref name=BS/>
Section 128 of the Constitution requires a proposed constitutional amendment be submitted to the electors in a [[Referendums in Australia|referendum]] no less than two months but no later than six months after passage. The referendum was originally planned to be held on the same day as the [[Australian federal election, 2013|2013 federal election]], originally set for 14 September 2013. However, on 4 August, Prime Minister [[Kevin Rudd]] changed the general election date to 7 September,<ref name=ABC>[http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-08-04/rudd-announces-september-7-election-date/4863864 Prime Minister Kevin Rudd calls September 7 federal election], [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]], 4-Aug-2013</ref> and Local Government Minister [[Catherine King (politician)|Catherine King]] announced that the referendum would be held on a later date.<ref name=ABC/>
The Australian Labor Party was defeated at the 7 September 2013 federal election, and in October 2013 the Abbott Coalition government announced it would not proceed with the referendum.<ref name=kills_off>[http://www.news.com.au/national/abbott-government-kills-off-local-government-referendum/story-e6frfkp9-1226750784515 Abbott Government kills off local government referendum], news.com.au, October 31, 2013</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} * [http://www.gtcentre.unsw.edu.au/resources/referendums/2013-local-government-referendum-faqs 2013 Local Government Referendum - FAQs] Gilbert + Tobin Centre of Public Law, [[University of NSW]]
