'''Total: 2,371–4,735+ killed''' | notes = | campaignbox = }} {{Campaignbox Sinai insurgency}} {{Campaignbox Terrorism in Egypt}} {{Campaignbox Islamist unrest in Egypt (2013–present)}} {{Egyptian crisis (2011–14)}} The '''Sinai insurgency''' is an ongoing conflict in the [[Sinai Peninsula]], [[Egypt]], between Islamist militants and Egyptian security forces, which has included attacks on civilians.{{cite web|url=https://www.theage.com.au/world/egypt-launches-airstrikes-after-deadly-mosque-attack-20171125-gzstmg.html|title=Egypt launches air strikes after deadly mosque attack|first=Farid|last=Farid|date=25 November 2017|website=The Age}} The insurgency began after the start of the [[Egyptian Crisis (2011–present)|Egyptian Crisis]], which saw the overthrow of longtime [[Egypt]]ian president [[Hosni Mubarak]] in the [[Egyptian revolution of 2011]].{{cite news|last1=Awad|first1=Marwa|title=Egypt army operation nets militants in Sinai-sources|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/commoditiesNews/idAFL5E7JG1SE20110816|accessdate=12 September 2017|work=AF}} The Sinai insurgency initially consisted of militants, largely composed of local [[Bedouin]] tribesmen, who exploited the chaotic situation in Egypt and weakened central authority to launch a series of attacks on government forces in Sinai. In 2014, elements of the [[Ansar Bait al-Maqdis]] group pledged allegiance to the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] (ISIL) and proclaimed themselves [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant – Sinai Province|Sinai Province]], and a part of ISIL. Security officials say militants based in Libya have established ties with the Sinai Province group''The Age'', 16 February 2015: [http://www.theage.com.au/world/egypt-strikes-back-at-islamic-state-militants-after-beheading-video-killing-dozens-20150216-13ghv2.html Egypt strikes back at Islamic State militants after beheading video, killing dozens] and have blamed the porous border and ongoing civil war for the increase in sophisticated weapons available to the Islamist groups.{{cite news|last1=Mazel|first1=Zvi|title=ISIS in Sinai: the Libyan connection|url=http://www.jpost.com/Middle-East/ISIS-in-Sinai-the-Libyan-connection-482149|accessdate=17 July 2017|work=The Jerusalem Post|date=21 February 2017}} The Egyptian authorities have attempted to restore their presence in the Sinai through both political and military measures. Egypt launched two military operations, known as [[Operation Eagle]] in mid-2011 and then [[Operation Sinai (2012)|Operation Sinai]] in mid-2012. In May 2013, following an abduction of Egyptian officers, violence in the Sinai surged once again. Following the [[2013 Egyptian coup d'état]], which resulted in the ousting of Egyptian president [[Mohamed Morsi]], "unprecedented clashes" have occurred.{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/75792/Egypt/Politics-/Clashes-in-Sinai-over-Morsi-removal.aspx|title=Clashes in Sinai over Morsi removal|publisher=Ahram Online|date=5 July 2013|accessdate=5 July 2013}} The fallout suffered by the locals as a result of the insurgency in Sinai ranges from militant operations and the state of insecurity to extensive military operations and the demolishing of hundreds of homes and evacuating thousands of residents as Egyptian troops pressed on to build a buffer zone meant to halt the smuggling of weapons and militants from and to the [[Gaza Strip|Gaza strip]]. A report, compiled by a delegation from the state-funded National Council for Human Rights (NCHR), stated that most of the displaced families share the same grievances of palpable government negligence, unavailability of nearby schools for their sons and the lack of health services.{{cite news|title=Sinai population still striving for basic rights as unrest continues: Report|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/125077/Egypt/Politics-/Sinai-population-still-striving-for-basic-rights-a.aspx|accessdate=12 March 2015|agency=Ahram Online|date=12 March 2015}} Since the start of the conflict, dozens of civilians were killed either in military operations or kidnapped and then beheaded by militants. In November 2017, more than 300 [[Sufism|Sufist]] worshippers were killed and over 100 injured in an attack on a mosque west of the city of Al-Arish. ==Background== [[Sufism]] was previously dominant in the region before militant jihadi ideas began to take hold.{{cite web|url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/news/mapping-jihadi-groups-sinai|title=Mapping jihadi groups in Sinai|publisher=Egypt Independent|date=10 August 2013|accessdate=26 October 2013}} The Sinai peninsula has long been known for its lawlessness, having historically served as a smuggling route for weapons and supplies. Security provisions in the [[Egypt–Israel Peace Treaty]] of 1979 have institutionalized a diminished security presence in the area, enabling militants to operate with a freer hand. Moreover, the limited government-directed investment and development in Sinai has discriminated against the local Bedouin population, a population that values tribal allegiance over all else. The combination of Sinai's harsh terrain and lack of resources have kept the area poor and hence ripe for militancy.{{cite web|url=http://www.lebanonwire.com/1305MLN/13052212STR.asp|title=Analysis: Egypt Tackles Increased Sinai Militancy|publisher=Lebanonwire.com|date=22 May 2013|accessdate=3 September 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130728054203/http://www.lebanonwire.com/1305MLN/13052212STR.asp|archivedate=28 July 2013|df=dmy-all}} Following the January 2011 uprising that toppled [[Hosni Mubarak]]'s regime, the country became increasingly destabilized, creating a security vacuum in the Sinai peninsula. Radical Islamic elements in Sinai exploited the opportunity, using the unique environment, in launching several waves of attacks upon Egyptian military and commercial facilities. According to ''[[The Economist]]'', the conflict also involves local armed Bedouin "who have long-standing grievances against the central government in Cairo" and that "they are barred from joining the army or police; they find it hard to get jobs in tourism; and they complain that many of their lands have been taken from them". ==Timeline== {{main|Timeline of the Sinai insurgency}} ===2011–2012=== Since the 2011 uprising against the Mubarak regime in Egypt, there has been increasing instability in the Sinai Peninsula. In addition the collapse of the Libyan regime increased the quantity and sophistication of weapons being smuggled into the area. The situation provided local Bedouin with an opportunity to assert their authority, leading to clashes with Egyptian security forces, but the cause of violence soon transitioned to salafi jihadism. Hard-line militant Muslims used Sinai as a launch-point for attacks against Israel and turned on the Egyptian state.,{{cite news|title=Sinai Peninsula – from Buffer Zone to Battlefield |url=http://www.css.ethz.ch/publications/pdfs/CSSAnalyse168-EN.pdf |accessdate=4 April 2016 |date=February 2015 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150418131034/http://www.css.ethz.ch/publications/pdfs/CSSAnalyse168-EN.pdf |archivedate=18 April 2015 |df= }} focusing on Egypt's security establishment and the Sinai's [[Arab Gas Pipeline]].{{cite news|last=Awad|first=Marwa|title=Egypt army operation nets militants in Sinai-sources|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFL5E7JG1SE20110816|accessdate=19 August 2011|newspaper=[[Reuters|Reuters Africa]]|date=16 August 2011|location=Cairo}} ====Operation Eagle==== {{main|Operation Eagle}} In August 2011, Operation Eagle was launched, in an effort to restore law and order, driving Islamist insurgents and criminal gangs out of North Sinai's urban centers.{{cite news|last=Khaled |first=Osama |title=Special forces deployed to Sinai to restore security |url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/485461 |accessdate=19 August 2011 |newspaper=[[Almasry Alyoum]] |date=11 August 2011 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} As well as, attempting to sever the link between militant groups in the Sinai and Gaza, by augmenting its control over the Gaza border crossing. The operation had limited success, and a week into the operation, Salafi jihadists carried out the biggest [[2011 southern Israel cross-border attacks|cross-border attack on Israel]] in the post-Mubarak period. ====Operation Sinai==== {{Main|August 2012 Sinai attack|Operation Sinai (2012)}} On 5 August 2012, an [[August 2012 Sinai attack|attack on the Rafah barracks]] shook the Egyptian military and population. Only a month into his term, President [[Mohamed Morsi]] sacked the longstanding defence minister and promoted General al Sisi to take his place. Operation Sinai was launched, aimed at eliminating armed Islamist groups, protecting the Suez Canal, and destroying the tunnel network connecting the Sinai with the Gaza Strip.{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/49906/Egypt/Politics-/UPDATED-Egyptian-troops-strike-hard-in-North-Sinai.aspx|title=UPDATED: Egyptian troops strike hard in North Sinai after multiple attacks|publisher=Al Ahram|accessdate=1 October 2012}} During the operation, 32 militants and suspects were killed and 38 arrested, while 2 civilians had been killed by early September 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/regions/middle-east/egypt/120908/egypt-army-kills-32-sinai-offensive-gaza|title=Egypt Army kills 32, arrests 38 more in Sinai offensive|publisher=GlobalPost|date=8 September 2012|accessdate=13 August 2013}} ===2013–2014=== Since the [[2013 Egyptian coup d'état|July 2013 coup]], against President Mohamed Morsi, a Muslim Brotherhood leader, the Egyptian military and security services in particular have been targeted by Sinai-based violent Islamist groups. In an increase in violence security forces came under near daily attack throughout July to August 2013. In 2013, the new authorities adopted a more aggressive strategy, leading to mass arrests and hard security measures. Over the few months leading to 2014, the Egyptian army gained the upper hand in the battle against militias that have found safe haven in the peninsula. After isolating and largely clearing the populated northeastern Sinai, the army put many militant factions on the defensive, most notably Ansar Bait al-Maqdis. However, one thousand armed militiamen are still sheltering in the main stronghold in Jabal Halal, as well as Jabal Amer area.{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtoninstitute.org/policy-analysis/view/the-new-triangle-of-egypt-israel-and-hamas|title=The New Triangle of Egypt, Israel, and Hamas|publisher=Washington Institute|date=12 January 2014|accessdate=18 July 2014}} In November 2014, the situation in the Sinai was thrust into the spotlight with [[October 2014 Sinai attacks|deadliest attack]] on the security forces since 2011, and the group responsible [[Ansar Bayt al-Maqdis]] pledging allegiance to the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] (ISIL) forming the [[Sinai Province (Militant Group)|Sinai Province]]. In the wake of the attack on the security forces, the government declared state of emergency, imposing a curfew and establish a buffer zone in the Sinai's border area with Gaza. ==== May ==== =====May 2013 hostage crisis===== On May 2013, a number of Egyptian Army police officers were taken hostage by armed tribesmen in the Sinai peninsula, with their videos released on the internet begging for their lives. As a response, Egypt's government had built up security forces in northern Sinai as part of an effort to secure the release of six policemen and a border guard kidnapped by suspected militants. On 20–21 May, Egyptian troops and police, backed by helicopter gunships, conducted a sweep through a number of villages in northern Sinai, along the border with Israel.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2013/05/21/more-troops-and-equipment-arrive-in-egypt-sinai-as-hostage-crisis-continues/|title=More troops and equipment arrive in Egypt's Sinai as hostage crisis continues|date=21 May 2013|accessdate=18 July 2014|agency=Associated Press}} The officials said the forces came under fire from gunmen in vehicles, triggering the clashes. The clashes left one gunman dead by 21 May. The hostages were released on 22 May after talks between the captors and Bedouins.{{Cite news|title=Suspect in kidnapping of Egyptian security men arrested|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/05/30/us-egypt-sinai-suspect-idUSBRE94T0L120130530|agency=Reuters|date=30 May 2013|accessdate=30 May 2013}} One suspect in the kidnapping was arrested on 30 May 2013. ==== July ==== =====July 2013 escalation following Morsi ousting===== Since President Mohamed Morsi's ouster on 3 July by Sisi, there has been an increase in violence by armed Bedouin and Islamists. Attacks on security forces have been witnessed almost daily since his ouster — leading many to link the militants there to the Muslim Brotherhood, the Islamist group from which Morsi hails.{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-202_162-57599074/egypt-bloodletting-rages-with-islamic-militants-killing-25-police-in-sinai-peninsula/|title=Egypt bloodletting rages with Islamic militants killing 25 police in Sinai Peninsula|publisher=CBS News|date=19 August 2013|accessdate=3 September 2013}} In response, Egypt launched a major military operation in Sinai against the militants, bringing in two additional battalions.{{cite web|author=Christa Case Bryant|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2013/0812/Militants-dig-in-as-Egypt-cracks-down-on-jihadi-sandbox-in-Sinai|title=Militants dig in as Egypt cracks down on jihadi sandbox in Sinai|publisher=CSMonitor.com|accessdate=3 September 2013}} In the two weeks following 3 July 39 terrorist attacks occurred in North Sinai. In the resulting clashes between armed groups and security forces, 52 gunmen and civilians and six security personnel died.{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/0/76802/Egypt/0/Sinai,-Egypts-unsolved-problem.aspx|title=Sinai, Egypt's unsolved problem - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online|publisher=English.ahram.org.eg|accessdate=3 September 2013}} On 15 July, witnessed the highest civilian casualties, when a bus transporting workers to the army-operated Al-Arish Cement Company was attacked. Five were killed and 15 were wounded. On 16 July, attacks resulted in some of the most intense army engagement, concentrated at Al-Masa'id, Al-Joura, and the Central Security camp at Al-Ahrash. Security operations have been largely confined to the 40-kilometre area between Al-Arish and Sheikh Zuweid, extending northward toward Rafah along the border with Israel and up to the Karam Abu Salem crossing. Fighting intensifies between the gunmen and the joint army-police forces at night. The frequency of attacks has varied from two to five in a single day. In addition, targets have expanded from fixed security checkpoints to mobile patrols. In most operations, the gunmen use four-wheel drive vehicles and combinations of light and heavy weaponry. However, in three recent attacks RPG-7 launchers were used, most likely smuggled from Libya. The G-7 grenade is capable of penetrating armoured vehicles and is generally fired at the doors. On 27 July, operation dubbed "Desert Storm" was launched by the Egyptian army in North Sinai Governorate and will last for 48 hours. Two of Egypt's field armies, as well as the country's Air Force and Navy are reportedly taking part in this large-scale operation. The military are said to be blocking all the roads, bridges and tunnels leading from Northern Sinai to other provinces of Egypt.{{cite web|url=http://rt.com/news/egypt-army-sinai-operation-681/|title=Egypt army launches counter-extremist operation in Sinai — RT News|publisher=RT|accessdate=3 September 2013}} A bomb was placed at a hotel frequented by security officials on 2 August 2013, though it caused no injuries.{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/0/78001/Egypt/0/Bomb-attack-on-Sinai-hotel-leaves-no-casualties.aspx|title=Bomb attack on Sinai hotel leaves no casualties|publisher=Ahram Online|date=2 August 2013|accessdate=6 August 2013}} A security source told the Egyptian newspaper [[Al-Masry Al-Youm]] that a majority of "terrorists" had been arrested as of 3 August 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/news/majority-terrorists-sinai-arrested-source|title=Majority of terrorists in Sinai arrested: source|publisher=Egypt Independent|date=3 August 2013|accessdate=6 August 2013}} 2 mausoleums were bombed on 4 August 2013, though no injuries resulted.{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/0/78327/Egypt/0/Two-mausoleums-bombed-in-north,-central-Sinai.aspx|title=Two mausoleums bombed in north, central Sinai|publisher=Ahram Online|date=5 August 2013|accessdate=6 August 2013}} Twenty-five Egyptian policemen died in an attack in the northern region of Sinai, on 18 August. After militants forced two mini-buses carrying off-duty policemen to stop, ordered the policemen out and forced them to lie on the ground before shooting them.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-202_162-57599074/egypt-says-24-police-killed-in-sinai-when-militants-ambush-buses/|title=Egypt bloodletting rages with Islamic militants killing 25 police in Sinai Peninsula|publisher=CBS News|date=19 August 2013|accessdate=3 September 2013}} The Egyptian military arrested eleven people, including five Hamas members, three local residents and three foreign nationals, for their alleged involvement in the killings.{{cite web|last=Miller|first=Elhanan|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/five-hamas-members-arrested-over-egyptian-police-massacre/|title=Five Hamas members arrested over Egyptian police massacre|publisher=Times of Israel|date=28 August 2013|accessdate=3 September 2013}} The person who committed the murders confessed on 1 September 2013.{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/80504.aspx|title=Top Sinai militant confesses murder of 25 policemen: Security source|publisher=Ahram Online|date=3 September 2013|accessdate=3 September 2013}} Military spokesperson Ahmed Ali said that Egyptian security forces recent operations in Sinai, from 5 July to 23 August, resulted in: 78 suspected militants killed, including 32 foreigners; 116 people injured; and 203 people arrested, including 48 foreigners, for their alleged involvement in attacks on security checkpoints in the peninsula. Additionally 343 tunnels on the border between Egypt and Gaza at Rafah have been destroyed.{{cite news|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/79750/Egypt/Politics-/Egypt-killed--militants-in-recent-operations-in-Si.aspx|title=Egypt 'killed 78 militants' in recent operations in Sinai|publisher=English.ahram.org.eg|date=23 August 2013|accessdate=3 September 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/78559.aspx|title=Egypt army says 60 'terrorists' killed in Sinai in a month|publisher=Ahram Online|date=7 August 2013|accessdate=7 August 2013}} ==== September ==== On 3 September, fifteen Islamist militants were killed in an attack by military helicopters.{{cite web|title=Rocket attack kills 15 militants in Sinai: Egyptian state TV|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/09/03/us-egypt-protests-sinai-idUSBRE9820F820130903|publisher=Reuters|date=3 September 2013|accessdate=4 September 2013}} On 7 September, the Egyptian army launched a new operation in the region. The operation involved tanks and at least six Apache helicopters. The army have been jamming communications to thwart militant coordination.{{cite news|title=9 Militants Are Reported Killed in Egyptian Army Raid in Sinai|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/08/world/middleeast/militants-are-reported-killed-in-egyptian-military-operations-in-sinai.html|publisher=New York Times|date=7 September 2013|accessdate=10 September 2013}} The army combed through areas near the Gaza Strip, including locations used by militants suspect in the killing and abduction of Egyptian soldiers over the past year. In the three days of operations, since 7 September, one officer, two soldiers and 29 militants were killed, and 39 militants were arrested.{{cite news|title=Suicide bombings strike Egyptian military in border town in Sinai, killing 9 |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=221271718 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20131002031330/http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=221271718 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2 October 2013 |agency=Associated Press |date=11 September 2013 |accessdate=1 October 2013 }}{{cite news|title=Egyptian tanks, helicopters push through Sinai|url=https://news.yahoo.com/egyptian-tanks-helicopters-push-sinai-133452774.html|agency=Associated Press|date=9 September 2013|accessdate=10 September 2013}} On 11 September, suicide bomber targeted Egyptian military intelligence headquarters in Rafah, bringing down the structure, at the same time a car bomb had rammed an army checkpoint. In the simultaneous attack at least nine soldiers were killed. ==== December ==== On 24 December 16 were killed and over 134 injured in a huge bomb which hit the Daqahliya Security Directorate in [[Mansoura]], in the worst attack on a government site since the ouster of Morsi in July. [[Ansar Bait al-Maqdis]], a Sinai-based group, claimed responsibility for the attack. The group deemed Egyptian troops infidels because they answer to a "secular government", warning them to desert or face death.{{cite news|title=Al-Qaida-linked group claims Egypt police attack|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/world/al-qaida-linked-group-claims-egypt-police-attack-article-1.1558088|date=25 December 2013|accessdate=18 July 2014|work=Associated Pres}}{{cite news|title=Sinai's Ansar Bait Al-Maqdis claim responsibility for Egypt's Mansoura blast|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/89992/Egypt/Politics-/Sinais-Ansar-Beit-AlMaqdis-claim-responsibility-fo.aspx|date=25 December 2013|work=Ahram Online}} ==== January ==== ====2014 helicopter downing==== On 26 January, militants shot down an army Mi-17 helicopter in North Sinai, killing all five of its crew members. The weapon the insurgents used was an infrared-homing, surface-to-air missile from the Russian-made Igla family. This was the first time in Egyptian history that an armed nonstate actor dropped a state's military helicopter by a missile.{{cite web|url=https://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/egypt/2015-11-08/sinais-stubborn-insurgency|title=Sinai's Stubborn Insurgency|first1=Omar|last1=Ashour|first2=Omar|last2=Ashour|date=8 November 2015|publisher=|accessdate=26 June 2017|via=www.foreignaffairs.com}} [[Ansar Bait al-Maqdis]] claimed responsibility for this attack as well as series of escalating attacks on police and soldiers.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/27/world/middleeast/militants-down-egyptian-helicopter-killing-5-soldiers.html?_r=0|title=Militants Down Egyptian Helicopter, Killing 5 Soldiers|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=26 January 2014}} Earlier that morning masked men in an SUV attacked a bus carrying soldiers in Sinai, killing at least three and injuring at least 11. ==== February ==== On 3 February, in what was described as the biggest operation in the Egyptian army's ongoing offensive against militants in the Sinai, 30 suspected militants were killed and another 15 injured in a series of airstrikes and another 16 were arrested.{{cite news|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/93405.aspx|title=Military airstrikes kill 30 militants in North Sinai: media reports|newspaper=Ahram Online|date=3 February 2014|accessdate=4 February 2014}} =====2014 Taba bus bombing===== {{main|2014 Taba bus bombing}} On 16 February 2014, a [[2014 Taba bus bombing|bomb exploded]] on or under a tour bus of a South Korean church group in the Egyptian city of [[Taba, Egypt|Taba]], which borders the [[Gulf of Aqaba]] and [[Eilat, Israel]]. The bombing killed 4 people – 3 South Koreans and the Egyptian bus driver – and injured 17 others.{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-02-16/egypt-bus-blast-in-sinai-peninsula-leaves-korean-tourists-dead.html |title=Egypt Bus Blast in Sinai Peninsula Kills Korean Tourists |newspaper=Bloomberg News |date=16 February 2014}} According to ''[[The New York Times]]'', the bombing could "offer worrying new evidence that militants who have been attacking Egypt's security forces for months were broadening their campaign against civilians."{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/17/world/middleeast/bus-bombing-kills-tourists-in-sinai-egypt.html?_r=0 |title=Bombing of Tourist Bus Kills at Least Three in Sinai |newspaper=The New York Times |date=16 February 2014}} ==== October ==== =====October 2014 Sinai attacks===== {{main|October 2014 Sinai attacks}} On 24 October 2014, 31 army and police soldiers were killed in [[October 2014 Sinai attacks|two separate attacks]] in North Sinai. The attack was the largest ever since the start of the war on terror in Sinai. As a result of the attack, president [[Abdel Fattah el-Sisi]] declared a state of emergency in the governorate after meeting with the National Defence Council for several hours. The state of emergency was to last for three months and to include a daily curfew from 5{{nbsp}}pm to 7{{nbsp}}am until further notice.{{Cite news|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/113857.aspx|title=State of Emergency declared in parts of North Sinai after attack kills 31 soldiers|date=24 October 2014|work=Ahram Online|accessdate=8 December 2014}} ==== November ==== On 10 November 2014, Ansar Bait al-Maqdis pledged allegiance to the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] (ISIL) forming the [[Sinai Province (Militant Group)|Sinai Province]] group with a confusingly similar name to two Egyptian regional governments.{{cite news|title=Fresh statement claims Ansar Bayt Al-Maqdis has allied with IS|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/115162/Egypt/Politics-/Fresh-statement-claims-Ansar-Bayt-AlMaqdis-has-all.aspx|accessdate=10 November 2014|publisher=Ahram Online|date=10 November 2014}} On 14 November 2014, ISIL published a video online that included footage of the group carrying out the [[October 2014 Sinai attacks]].{{cite news|title=ISIS Releases Graphic Propaganda Video For Ansar Bait al-Maqdis|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/isis-releases-graphic-propaganda-video-ansar-bait-al-maqdis-1724188|accessdate=16 November 2014|date=14 November 2014|work=International Business times}} ===2015=== During 2015, the intensity and the scale of insurgent attacks expanded. ====January==== On 12 January 2015, Sinai Province kidnapped a police officer while traveling in North Sinai and took him to an unknown location. On the following day on 13 January 2015, Egyptian military spokesperson announced the discovery of the dead body of the officer after launching a search operation. He also said that during the operation 10 militants were killed, while two others were arrested.{{cite news|title=Kidnapped police captain in Sinai found dead: Army|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/120181/Egypt/Politics-/Kidnapped-police-captain-in-Sinai-found-dead-Army.aspx|accessdate=26 January 2015|date=13 January 2015}} On 26 January 2015, Sinai Province published a video online that included the kidnapping and execution of the police officer kidnapped on 12 January.{{cite news|title=Ansar Beit Al-Maqdis releases video of "policeman's execution"|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/121404/Egypt/Politics-/Ansar-Beit-AlMaqdis-releases-video-of-policemans-e.aspx|accessdate=26 January 2015|publisher=Ahram Online|date=26 January 2015}} =====January 2015 Sinai attacks===== {{main|January 2015 Sinai attacks}} On 29 January 2015, militants from the Sinai Province militant group launched a series of attacks on army and police bases in [[Arish]] using car bombs and mortars.{{cite news|title=At least 32 killed in Egypt as militants attack army and police targets in Sinai|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jan/29/egypt-army-police-sinai-el-arish-sheikh-zuwayed-rafah|accessdate=30 January 2015|agency=The Guardian|date=29 January 2015}} The attacks, which occurred in more than six different locations, resulted in 32 confirmed deaths including army personnel and civilians.{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/30/world/middleeast/bombings-of-security-facilities-in-sinai-kill-at-least-26.html | title=Bomb Attacks at Security Sites in Sinai Kill at Least 26 | work=New York Times | date=30 January 2015 | accessdate=30 January 2015 | author=Kirkpatrick, David}} ======Security response====== It was reported that on 6 February 2015 Egyptian security forces attacked the Sinai Province group, killing 47 Islamic militants in Northern Sinai.{{cite news|title=Egyptian military kills 47 militants in the Sinai|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/02/07/us-egypt-violence-idUSKBN0LA0XO20150207?feedType=RSS&feedName=worldNews|accessdate=6 February 2015|publisher=Reuters|date=6 February 2015}} ====March==== On 10 March 2015, a suicide attack on a police barracks using a water tanker was stopped after security forces opened fire on the water tanker causing it to explode before it could get into the barracks. One civilian near the scene was killed and two others wounded in the blast, alongside dozens of wounded policemen.{{cite news|title=Bombs kill two, wound dozens in Egypt's North Sinai|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/03/10/us-egypt-violence-idUSKBN0M60DK20150310|accessdate=10 March 2015|publisher=Reuters|date=10 March 2015}} ====April==== On 2 April 2015, an attack on an army checkpoint resulted in the death of 15 soldiers, 2 civilians and 15 attackers. As a response to the attack, the Egyptian army launched an operation the following day allegedly killing 100 militants.{{cite news|title=Ansar Beit Al-Maqdis claims Thursday Sinai attacks|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/126816/Egypt/Politics-/Ansar-Beit-AlMaqdis-claims-Thursday-Sinai-attacks.aspx|accessdate=3 April 2015|publisher=Ahram Online|date=3 April 2015}}{{cite news|title=15 suspected militants killed in North Sinai raids - state agency|url=http://en.aswatmasriya.com/news/view.aspx?id=4018835c-2869-4475-a4f5-0c749c852af9|accessdate=3 April 2015|publisher=Aswat Masriya|date=3 April 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://presstv.ir/Detail/2015/04/03/404564/Egypt-kills-100-terrorists-in-Sinai|title=PressTV-Egypt kills 100 terrorists in Sinai|work=presstv.ir}} On 8 April 2015, eleven civilians were killed in Sheikh Zuweid when an unidentified rocket-propelled grenade hit their homes.{{cite news|title=Egypt army killed 29 suspected militants in North Sinai this week|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/0/127300/Egypt/0/Egypt-army-killed--suspected-militants-in-North-Si.aspx|accessdate=12 April 2015|publisher=Ahram Online|date=8 April 2015}} On 12 April 2015, 6 soldiers were killed when their armoured vehicle was bombed in North Sinai. On the same day, a separate attack on a police station in Arish resulted in the death of 5 policemen and 1 civilian. The attack on the station was carried out by a suicide bomber using a bomb-laden vehicle. Militant group Ansar Beit Al-Maqdis has claimed responsibility for the attacks.{{cite news|title=UPDATE 3: At least 6 dead, including one civilian, in Arish suicide bomb attack|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/127477/Egypt/Politics-/UPDATE--At-least--dead,-including-one-civilian,-in.aspx|accessdate=12 April 2015|publisher=Ahram Online|date=12 April 2015}} On 27 April 2015, members from Al-Tarabin tribe in North Sinai launched an attack on Ansar Bayt al-Maqdis positions in Rafah.{{cite news|title=Al-Tarabeen tribe launches offensive against ISIS hideouts in Sinai|url=http://www.el-balad.com/1505756|accessdate=27 April 2015|publisher=Sada El Balad|date=27 April 2015}} The attack came after Ansar Bayt al-Maqdis gunmen fatally shot a member of Al-Tarabin tribe in Berth village in southern Rafah, North Sinai, after he refused to take their warning statements ordering them not to deal with the Egyptian military.{{cite news|title=Rafah Bedouin killed, another abducted after Ansar Bayt al-Maqdis warns tribe|url=http://www.thecairopost.com/news/147783/news/rafah-bedouin-killed-another-abducted-after-ansar-bayt-al-maqdis-warns-tribe|accessdate=27 April 2015|publisher=The Cairo Post|date=27 April 2015}} ====May==== On 16 May 2015, three Egyptian judges and their driver were killed when gunmen opened fire on their vehicle in North Sinai. The attack came hours after a Cairo court issued a preliminary death sentence against former president Mohamed Morsi and 105 other defendants on a range of charges, including murder.{{cite news|title=3 judges, driver killed in gun attack in Egypt's North Sinai|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/130401/Egypt/Politics-/-judges,-driver-killed-in-gun-attack-in-Egypts-Nor.aspx|accessdate=16 May 2015|publisher=Ahram Online|date=16 May 2015}} ====June==== On 9 June 2015, militants fired rockets at the direction of an airport in Sinai used by the multinational peacekeeping forces.{{cite news|title=Sinai Province fires rockets towards airport used by multinational peacekeepers|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/sinai-province-fires-rockets-towards-airport-used-by-multinational-peacekeepers.aspx?pageID=238&nID=83747&NewsCatID=352|accessdate=10 June 2015|publisher=Hurriyet Daily News|date=10 June 2015}} ====July==== =====July 2015 Sinai attacks===== {{main|July 2015 Sinai attacks}} On 1 July 2015, Sinai Province militants launched one of the largest attacks ever, since the insurgency begun in 2011, on multiple [[Egyptian Armed Forces|Egyptian army]] checkpoints in the [[Sinai Peninsula]], killing 21 soldiers. The attack also targeted Sheikh Zuweid police station. Reinforcements from the Second Army Zone stationed in Ismailia have been deployed to Sheikh Zuweid, and F-16 fighter jets were spotted targeting militants in the city. Militants have reportedly killed several civilians who refused to allow them onto their rooftops to target security forces.{{cite news|title=LIVE UPDATES: Largest attack on restive Sinai leaves dozens dead|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/134218/Egypt/Politics-/LIVE-UPDATES-Largest-attack-on-restive-Sinai-leave.aspx|accessdate=1 July 2015|publisher=Ahram Online|date=1 July 2015}} An army statement claimed the killing of more than 100 militants from the attacking force. The militant death toll increased in the following days, due to Egyptian military operations in the region, reaching 241 killed. On 4 July 2015, a shell bomb struck a house in Sheikh Zuweid, killing a woman and her two children. On the same day, a roadside bomb targeting army and police vehicles killed a five-year-old child in [[Rafah]].{{cite news |title=Civilians killed in Egypt's Sinai battles |url=http://mwcnews.net/news/middle-east/52723-egypts-sinai-battles.html |website=Media with Conscience (MWC) News |date=4 July 2015 |accessdate=6 July 2015 }} On 15 July 2015, twenty militants were killed as security forces repelled an attack on a security checkpoint in North Sinai.{{cite news|title=20 militants killed in attack on security checkpoint in North Sinai: Reports|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/135439/Egypt/Politics-/-militants-killed-in-attack-on-security-checkpoint.aspx|accessdate=16 July 2015|publisher=Ahram Online|date=15 July 2015}} On 16 July 2015, Sinai Province militants attacked an Egyptian navy patrol ship near the border with Israel and the Gaza Strip. The patrol ship was hit by a guided missile. The Egyptian military confirmed the incident and said in a statement that there are no fatalities among the vessel's crew. The attack is considered the first maritime attack of the Islamic State and its allied militant groups.{{cite news|title=Naval Terror: ISIS says it hits Egyptian patrol ship near Mediterranean coast|url=http://www.rt.com/news/310053-Egypt-ISIS-terrorism-Sinai/|accessdate=16 July 2015|publisher=Ahram Online|date=16 July 2015}} On 23 July 2015, an officer and three soldiers were killed and three others were wounded when an improvised roadside bomb hit their armoured vehicle in a village near the town of Rafah.{{cite news|title=UPDATED: IS claims responsibility for North Sinai bombing that killed 4 Egyptian troops|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/136026/Egypt/Politics-/UPDATED-IS-claims-responsibility-for-North-Sinai-b.aspx|accessdate=23 July 2015|publisher=Ahram Online|date=23 July 2015}} On 24 July 2015, the Egyptian army said it has killed 12 terrorists and destroyed two warehouses storing explosive materials.{{cite news|title=Egypt's army says it killed 12 'terrorists' in North Sinai|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/136112/Egypt/Politics-/Egypt%E2%80%99s-army-says-it-killed--%E2%80%98terrorists%E2%80%99-in-North.aspx|accessdate=24 July 2015|publisher=Ahram Online|date=24 July 2015}} On 31 July 2015, the Egyptian military bombed areas of the North Sinai towns of al-Arish and Sheikh Zuweid, killing 20 suspected militants.{{cite news|title=20 suspected militants killed in North Sinai shelling - military sources|url=http://en.aswatmasriya.com/news/view.aspx?id=bfacb4aa-10d3-480c-9057-5b2f9ee9e73f|accessdate=31 July 2015|publisher=Aswat Masriya|date=31 July 2015}} ====August==== On 1 August 2015, Egyptian army forces surrounded the home of a leading figure of the Sinai-based militant group Ansar Bayt al-Maqdis, in the town of Sheikh Zuweid, before shooting him dead. ==== September ==== On 3 September 2015, four American and two Fijian Multinational Force and Observers troops were wounded in an attack involving two IEDs.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-egypt-sinai-peacekeepers/sinai-blasts-injure-six-peacekeepers-including-four-americans-pentagon-idUSKCN0R404G20150904|title=Sinai blasts injure six peacekeepers, including four Americans: Pentagon|date=4 September 2015|publisher=|access-date=7 November 2017|via=Reuters}}{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2015/09/04/four-u-s-troops-two-international-peacekeepers-wounded-in-sinai-blasts/|title=Four U.S. troops, two international peacekeepers wounded in Sinai blasts|first=Dan|last=Lamothe|date=4 September 2015|publisher=|access-date=7 November 2017|via=www.WashingtonPost.com}} =====Operation Martyr's Right===== {{main|Operation Martyr's Right}} On 8 September 2015, the Egyptian military launched a major operation code-named "The Martyr's Right". The operation is the largest and most comprehensive operation aimed at rooting out and killing terrorists since July's immediate response to militant attacks. The operation targeted sites in Rafah, Arish, and Sheikh Zuweid, all towns in the northern areas of the peninsula.{{cite news|title=The Martyr's Right is Egypt's largest military action in North Sinai in months: Sources|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/0/139972/Egypt/0/The-Martyrs-Right-is-Egypts-largest-military-actio.aspx|access-date=12 September 2015|publisher=Ahram Online|date=8 September 2015}} 535 militants were killed in September 2015.{{cite news|title=Egypt says killed 55 militants in Sinai, two soldiers killed|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/09/15/us-egypt-militants-casualties-idUSKCN0RF2OU20150915|access-date=16 September 2015|publisher=Reuters|date=15 September 2015}} On 13 September 2015, a Fijian soldier attached to the Multinational Force and Observers was wounded by small arms fire.{{cite web|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/284153/after-fiji-soldier-wounded-in-sinai,-others-prepare-for-deployment|title=After Fiji soldier wounded in Sinai, others prepare for deployment|date=14 September 2015|website=RadioNZ.co.nz|access-date=7 November 2017}} ==== October ==== =====Downing of Russian passenger plane===== {{main|Metrojet Flight 9268}} [[File:Flowers for Metrojet flight 9268 victims.JPG|thumbnail|Flowers and children's toys at the [[Pulkovo Airport]] entrance. The sign at the back says "To the victims of A321 plane crash".]] On 31 October 2015, a [[Metrojet Flight 9268|Russian passenger jet]] disintegrated above the northern Sinai, killing all 224 aboard.{{Cite web| title = Inside Egypt's Blacked-Out War With ISIS-Affiliated Militants |publisher= TIME| access-date = 5 September 2016| url = http://time.com/4157435/isis-isil-egypt-sinai/}} The Islamic State's Sinai Province claimed responsibility for the incident. Russian, Egyptian, and western investigators concluded that the plane was brought down by a bomb.{{Cite web| title = In Reversal, Egypt Says Terrorists Downed Russian Jet Over Sinai|publisher=The New York Times| accessdate = 5 September 2016| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/25/world/middleeast/in-reversal-egypt-says-terrorists-downed-russian-jet-o.html}} ==== December ==== On 8 December, a bomb in [[Rafah]] killed four soldiers and injured four others.{{Cite web|title = PressTV-Egypt Sinai bombing kills 4 soldiers|url = http://www.presstv.ir/Detail/2015/12/08/440836/Egypt-Sinai-Rafah-Daesh-ISIS-Wilayat-Sinai--|website = www.presstv.ir|accessdate = 10 December 2015}} ===2016=== Insurgent attacks increased in early 2016, nearly doubling between the last quarter of 2015 and the second quarter of 2016.{{cite web|url=http://timep.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/ESW-QR-2016-Q2-REPORT.pdf|publisher=[[Tahrir Institute for Middle East Policy]]|title=Egypt Security Watch Quarterly Report: April–June 2016|accessdate=5 September 2016}} However, according to ''[[The Times of Israel]]'', the numbers of attacks and casualties was declining by August 2016.{{Cite web| last = Issacharoff| first = Avi| title = Sinai attacks decline as Egypt's fight against IS yields results| publisher = The Times of Israel| accessdate = 5 September 2016| url = http://www.timesofisrael.com/sinai-attacks-decline-as-egypts-fight-against-is-yields-results/}} ==== March ==== On 19 March, an attack on a checkpoint in [[Arish]] killed 13 policemen.{{Cite web| title = Egypt: 'IS attack' kills 13 policemen in Sinai |publisher=BBC News| accessdate = 5 September 2016| url = https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-35854404}} ==== April ==== Another attack on 7 April killed 15 soldiers and two civilians.{{Cite news| issn = 0040-781X| last = Schwartz| first = Yardena| title = Israel Patrols Its Southern Border as ISIS Lurks in the Sinai Peninsula| work = Time| accessdate = 5 September 2016| date = 10 May 2016| url = http://time.com/4322544/israel-patrols-its-southern-border-as-isis-lurk-in-the-sinai-peninsula/}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-egypt-violence/seven-killed-15-injured-in-sinai-blasts-idUSKCN0X50CT|title=Seven killed, 15 injured in Sinai blasts|date= 2016-04-08|work=Reuters|accessdate=2017-12-24}} ==== May ==== In May, Egyptian security forces launched an air attack on Jabal Halal, a region with an extensive cave system that was a major insurgent stronghold. According to the Egyptian military, 88 militants were killed and many supply caches were destroyed. ==== June ==== On 28 June, A series of air strikes killed 30 ISIS fighters and injured 50 others.{{Cite news|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/over-30-gunmen-said-killed-in-egyptian-strikes-in-sinai/|title=Over 30 gunmen said killed in Egyptian strikes in Sinai|access-date=2017-12-24|language=en-US}} ==== August ==== Then, on 4 August, the army claimed to have killed the leader of Sinai Province, Abu Duaa al-Ansari.{{Cite web| title = Egypt Claims To Have Killed A Top ISIS Leader In Sinai| publisher= Vocativ| accessdate = 5 September 2016| date = 17 August 2016| url = http://www.vocativ.com/351630/egypt-claims-to-have-killed-sinai-isis-branch-leader/}} Independent sources were unable to verify this claim, or even the existence of al-Ansari.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2016/08/06/confusion-immortal-leader-sinai-province/|publisher=Daily News Egypt|title=Confusion Over the Immortal Leader of Sinai Province|date=6 August 2016|author=Taha Sakr|accessdate=5 September 2016}} Previous reports had described [[Abu Osama al-Masri]] as the leader. ==== September ==== The army reported another 40 militants killed by airstrikes in September.{{Cite web|publisher=Sputnik News| title = Egyptian Air Force Kill Over 40 Militants in North Sinai - Reports| accessdate = 5 September 2016| url = http://sputniknews.com/middleeast/20160904/1044957356/egypt-sinai-militants.html}} ==== October ==== On 14 October a total 12 soldiers and 15 militants were killed.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-egypt-insurgency-idUSKBN12E14Q|title=A suspected ISIL attack on a security checkpoint in North Sinai Governorate, Egypt, leaves at least 12 Egyptian military personnel and 15 terrorists dead|date=14 October 2016|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=16 October 2016}} On 17 October several clashes in North Sinai left 3 soldiers and 18 insurgents dead.{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/245926/Egypt/Politics-/Three-Egyptian-soldiers-killed-during-air,-ground-.aspx|title=Three Egyptian soldiers killed during air, ground raids on Sinai militants: Army - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online|website=english.ahram.org.eg}} On 30 October a military operation in North Sinai left 4 soldiers and 6 insurgents dead.{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/246886/Egypt/Politics-/Four-Egyptian-army-personnel-killed-in-North-Sinai.aspx|title=Four Egyptian army personnel killed in North Sinai: Armed forces - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online|website=english.ahram.org.eg}} ==== November ==== On 5 November Egyptian soldiers killed at least 11 terrorist.{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/247364/Egypt/Politics-/-militants-killed-in-North-Sinai-military-operatio.aspx|title=11 militants killed in North Sinai military operation: Army spokesman - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online|website=english.ahram.org.eg}} On 10 November army soldiers killed at least 6 insurgents.{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/248784/Egypt/Politics-/Six-militants-killed-in-North-Sinai-military-opera.aspx|title=Six militants killed in North Sinai military operation: Army Spokesperson - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online|website=english.ahram.org.eg}} ===2017=== ==== January ==== On 9 January 2017, an attack by several gunmen and a truck bomb on a police checkpoint in El-Arish causing at least 13 deaths and 22 injuries, according to official sources.{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/egypt-suicide-attack-bomber-truck-explosives-kill-sinai-security-post-isis-latest-a7517136.html|title=Suicide bomb kills at least 10 in Egypt|date=9 January 2017|work=The Independent|access-date=28 March 2017|language=en-GB}} One of the attackers, drove a stolen rubbish truck loaded with explosive at the security checkpoint, as gunmen opened fire on police forces. ==== April ==== ===== Palm Sunday church bombings ===== {{Main|2017 Palm Sunday church bombings}} On February 2017, ISIS produced a video calling for attacks against Christians.{{cite web |url=https://www.memri.org/reports/isis-egypt-openly-betting-bigotry-winning-strategy |title=ISIS Egypt Is Openly Betting On Bigotry As A Winning Strategy |last=Fernandez |first= Alberto M. |date=22 February 2017 |number=MEMRI Daily Brief No.120|website=MEMRI |publisher= |access-date= |quote=}}{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/Mokhtar_Awad/status/833417561148686342 |title= |last=Awad |first=Mokhtar |date=19 February 2017 |website=Twitter |publisher=|access-date= |quote=}}{{cite news |last=Petkar |first= Sofia |date=21 February 2017 |title='God gave orders to kill every infidel' ISIS vows to massacre Christians in chilling video |url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/world/770216/ISIS-Christians-massacre-video-released-Egypt |newspaper=Express |location= |access-date= }}{{cite web |url=https://www.memri.org/jttm/new-video-isis-threatens-increase-attacks-copts |title= In New Video, ISIS Threatens To Increase Attacks On Copts |last=|first= |date=20 February 2017 |website=MEMRI |publisher= |access-date= |quote=}} On April ISIS attacked several churches in Egypt Known as [[Palm Sunday church bombings]]. The attacks killed over 40 people.{{cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/least-4-killed-20-injured-blast-near-church-081051661.html|title=Palm Sunday bombings of Egyptian Coptic churches kill 44|website=yahoo.com|accessdate=26 June 2017}} ==== July ==== In July, a militant raid on an army checkpoint resulted in the deaths of at least 23 soldiers. The checkpoint was looted for weapons and ammunition before the attackers fled the scene.{{cite news|title=At least 23 Egyptian soldiers killed in attack on Sinai checkpoint|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/jul/07/egyptian-soldiers-killed-in-attack-on-sinai-checkpoint|accessdate=17 July 2017|work=The Guardian|date=7 July 2017}} Later that month an attack targeting [[police]] killed 5 officers and wounded 11 in the city of [[el-Arish]]. A later [[Improvised explosive device|roadside bomb]] south of the city wounded a further 6 officers. The attacks came the same day officials claimed the [[Egyptian Air Force]] had killed at least 30 militants in strikes on a gathering.{{cite news|title=Militants kill 5 police in attacks in Egypt's Sinai|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/militants-kill-police-complex-attack-egypts-sinai-48679899|accessdate=17 July 2017|work=ABC News|date=17 July 2017|language=en}} ==== September ==== In September officers were again attacked in el-Arish, with 18 killed and 7 wounded in an assault involving roadside bombs and small arms fire.{{cite news|last1=Sweilam|first1=Ashraf|last2=Hendawi|first2=Hamza|title=Militants attack convoy in Egypt's Sinai, kill 18 police|url=http://www.spokesman.com/stories/2017/sep/11/militants-attack-convoy-in-egypts-sinai-kill-18-po/|accessdate=12 September 2017|work=Spokesman.com|language=en}} ==== November ==== On November 24, 2017, the [[Sufism|Sufi]] al-Rawda mosque in the town of [[Bir al-Abed]], [[North Sinai Governorate]], [[Egypt]] was [[Bir al-Abed attack|attacked by around forty gunmen]] during [[Jumu'ah|Friday prayers]]. The gun and bomb attack killed at least 235 people and injured more than 120, making it the deadliest terrorist attack in Egyptian history and the second deadliest attack in 2017, after the [[14 October 2017 Mogadishu bombings]].{{Cite news|url=http://storymaps.esri.com/stories/terrorist-attacks/?year=2017|title=Annual Terrorist Attacks|last=Maps|first=Esri Story|work=Esri|access-date=2017-12-24|language=en}} Other reports of the attack assert that over 300 deaths occurred.Najjar, Farah. (25 March 2018). "Sinai Peninsula: Sisi's offensive continues despite promises." [https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/03/sinai-peninsula-sisi-offensive-continues-promises-180324103104936.html Al Jazeera English website] Retrieved 25 March 2018. ==== December ==== On December 19, 2017 [[El Arish International Airport]] was attacked in an attempt to assassinate the Minister of Interior [[Magdi Abdel-Ghaffar]] and the minister of defense [[Sedki Sobhy]]. The assassination attempt failed and one officer was killed and two were injured.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-egypt-security-claim/islamic-state-claims-air-base-attack-in-egypts-north-sinai-idUSKBN1EE1SA|title=Islamic State claims air base attack in Egypt's North Sinai|date=2017-12-20|work=Reuters|accessdate=2017-12-24}} ISIS used [[kornet]] anti-tank missile in the attack.{{Cite news|url=http://www.israeldefense.co.il/en/node/32314|title=The Missile Attack on El Arish Airport|access-date=2017-12-24|language=en}} Next day a new clash started near the airport where 5 ISIS militants were killed and an army captain was killed.{{Cite news|url=https://www.haaretz.com/middle-east-news/egypt/1.830179|title=Egyptian Forces Clash With ISIS Militants Near Sinai Airport|last=Reuters|date=2017-12-20|work=Haaretz|accessdate=2017-12-24|language=en}} ====2018==== On 8 October 2018 Egyptian military declared in an operation they have killed 52 Islamist militants. Three Egyptian soldiers were also killed.[http://www.arabnews.com/node/1384406/middle-east Egypt army says 52 suspected militants killed in Sinai] ==Areas of insurgency== According to Reuters, as of 2013, Ansar Bait al-Maqdis was in control of about a third of the villages in Sinai.{{cite news|title=Special Report: How Cairo is taking the fight to Sinai militants|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/02/05/us-egypt-sinai-militants-specialreport-idUSKBN0L80XM20150205|accessdate=27 April 2015|agency=Reuters|date=27 April 2015}} Now, daily clashes with militants in North Sinai are reported by the army.{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/world/middle-east/bombs-kill-two-in-egypts-sinai-peninsula|title=Bombs kill two in Egypt's Sinai Peninsula|work=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]|date=10 March 2015}} The insurgency has not spread to south Sinai, where there are tourist hubs. In the northeastern part of the peninsula, checkpoints have often been established by militants as the army lack the power to stop them. The militants have captured and assassinated policemen there.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jan/29/egypt-army-police-sinai-el-arish-sheikh-zuwayed-rafah|title=At least 32 killed in Egypt as militants attack army and police targets in Sinai|work=[[theguardian.com]]|date=30 January 2015}} ===Outside of Sinai=== {{main|Insurgency in Egypt (2013–present)}} On 24 December 2013, sixteen people were killed and over a hundred people injured in a huge bomb which hit the Daqahliya Security Directorate in [[Mansoura]]. Ansar Bait al-Maqdis claimed responsibility for the attack. On 5 August 2014, 5 policemen were killed in an attack on a police car on Matrouh road by armed militants.{{cite news|title=5 police personnel, 4 militants killed in clashes on Matrouh road|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/107803/Egypt/Politics-/-police-personnel,--militants-killed-in-clashes-on.aspx|accessdate=16 November 2014|date=5 August 2014}} On 28 November 2014, the militant group Sinai Province claimed responsibility for the killing of 2 army personnel in Cairo and Qaliubiya.{{cite news|title='State of Sinai' claim attacks as part of 'Islamic Youth Uprising'|url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2014/11/29/state-sinai-claim-attacks-part-islamic-youth-uprising/|accessdate=30 November 2014|agency=Daily News Egypt|date=28 November 2014}}{{cite news|title=2 army officers killed, 3 conscripts injured in drive-by shootings|url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2014/11/28/2-army-officers-killed-3-conscripts-injured-drive-shootings/|accessdate=30 November 2014|date=28 November 2014}} On 1 December 2014, Sinai Province claimed responsibility for killing a United States citizen in Egypt's western desert in August 2014.{{cite news|title=Egypt's Ansar Beit Al-Maqdis claims killing of US citizen in Western Desert|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/116915/Egypt/Politics-/Egypts-Ansar-Beit-AlMaqdis-claims-killing-of-US-ci.aspx|accessdate=1 December 2014|date=1 December 2014}} On 21 December 2014, the [[Law enforcement in Egypt|Egyptian police]] raided an Ansar Beit Al-Maqdis cell in the Nile Delta killing 5 members.{{cite news|title=Members of 'terrorist cell' in Sharqiya killed: Egyptian police|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/118544/Egypt/Politics-/Members-of-terrorist-cell-in-Sharqiya-killed-Egypt.aspx|accessdate=21 December 2014|agency=Ahram Online|date=21 December 2014}} On 26 December 2014, two Ansar Bait al-Maqdis militants were killed in a gunfight in El-Salam City, on the eastern outskirts of Cairo.{{cite news|title=UPDATED: Two Ansar Beit El-Maqdis militants killed in gunfight near Cairo|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/118848/Egypt/Politics-/UPDATED-Two-Ansar-Beit-ElMaqdis-militants-killed-i.aspx|accessdate=26 December 2014|agency=Ahram Online|date=26 December 2014}} The Ministry of Interior later identified one of the dead militants as the commander of Ansar Beit El-Maqdis in the Nile Delta. On 11 July 2015, a car-bomb exploded near the Italian consulate in Cairo, killing one person and injuring nine others. None of the Italian staff of the consulate were injured as the establishment was still closed at the time of the explosion. Later, the Islamic State has claimed responsibility for the attack.{{cite news|title=ISIS claims responsibility for blast at Italian consulate in Cairo|url=http://www.rt.com/news/273082-egypt-blast-cairo-blast/|accessdate=16 July 2015|publisher=RT News|date=11 July 2015}} ====In the Gaza Strip==== {{main|Egypt–Gaza barrier|Gaza Strip smuggling tunnels}} {{further|Egypt–Palestine relations|Islamism in the Gaza Strip}} Out of the approximately 15 main militant groups operating in the Sinai desert, the most dominant and active militant groups have close relations with the [[Gaza Strip]].{{cite web|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/egypt-grapples-with-gaza-based-sinai-jihadists/|title=Egypt's ire raised as Hamas harbors Sinai jihadists|publisher=Times Of Israel|date=22 August 2013|accessdate=22 August 2013}} The [[Army of Islam (Gaza Strip)|Army of Islam]], a U.S. designated [[U.S. State Department list of Foreign Terrorist Organizations|terrorist organization]] based in the Gaza Strip, is responsible for training and supplying many militant organizations and jihadist members in Sinai. Mohammed Dormosh, the Army of Islam's leader, is known for his close relationships to the [[Hamas]] leadership. The Army of Islam smuggles members into the Gaza Strip for training, then returns them to the Sinai Peninsula to engage in terrorist and jihadist activities.{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4402384,00.html/|title=Gaza terrorists infiltrate Sinai|publisher=Ynet News|date=7 August 2013|accessdate=22 August 2013}} ==Egyptian response== ===Military tactics=== The disposition of Egyptian forces in the Sinai peninsula is mandated by the [[Camp David Accords]] and monitored by the 1,600 foreign troops that make up the [[Multinational Force and Observers]]. Egypt is permitted only enough military forces in the Sinai to enforce security.http://www.mfa.gov.eg/Lists/Treaties%20DB/Attachments/645/Peace%20Treaty_en.pdf In 2011, Egypt sent an additional 2,500 troops and 250 armored personnel, with helicopters as part of Operation Eagle, a mission to provide security during the power transition from then-recently fallen Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak.{{cite web|url=http://www.bi-me.com/main.php?id=60104&t=1|title=Analysis: Egypt, Gaza and the Sinai Peninsula|publisher=bi-me|date=17 November 2012|access-date=26 November 2013}} Operation Eagle was joined by Operation Sinai in 2012, which came in response to a militant attack against an Egyptian border post 5 August that killed 16 border guards. Together, the two operations increased the total troop count by more than 2,500 added 80 vehicles and at least two attack helicopters. Egypt also was allowed to deploy armed fighter jets to El Arish to assist its ground forces in Sinai.{{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast/Article.aspx?id=280732|title=Security cabinet okays Egypt attack helicopters in Sinai|publisher=The Jerusalem Post|work=Reuters|date=9 August 2012|access-date=9 August 2012|author=Herb Keinon}} Egypt's expanded force structure in Sinai is designed to deny militants sanctuary by bringing more force to bear than the municipal police alone can provide. Many of the new forces are stationed in the northeast of Sinai along the Egyptian border with Gaza. Setting up roadblocks and checkpoints to monitor and inspect traffic transiting the Sinai Peninsula to counter this smuggling. In the [[October 2014 Sinai attacks|October 2014 attacks]], for the first time the militants in Sinai used suicide truck bombs to breach army roadblocks and strongpoints, then followed them with an infantry attack. After the [[October 2014 Sinai attacks|October attacks]], the Egyptian military began using armed drones for the first time since the Sinai insurgency began.{{cite news|title=طائرات بدون طيار تقصف مواقع التكفيريين فى سيناء|url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/News/41368/136/339106/%D9%85%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%A8%D8%B9%D8%A7%D8%AA/%D8%B7%D8%A7%D8%A6%D8%B1%D8%A7%D8%AA-%D8%A8%D8%AF%D9%88%D9%86-%D8%B7%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%B1-%D8%AA%D9%82%D8%B5%D9%81-%D9%85%D9%88%D8%A7%D9%82%D8%B9-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AA%D9%83%D9%81%D9%8A%D8%B1%D9%8A%D9%8A%D9%86-%D9%81%D9%89-%D8%B3%D9%8A%D9%86%D8%A7%D8%A1.aspx|access-date=17 November 2014|agency=Al Ahram|date=17 November 2014|language=Arabic}} And as a measure to counter weapon and militant trafficking between Egypt and Gaza strip, the Egyptian government announced the creation of a buffer zone along the Egypt-Gaza border.{{cite news|title=Egypt to create buffer zone along Gaza border|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/7e91f9d38cd041a4bd9209ebc9361e64/egypt-create-buffer-zone-along-gaza-border|access-date=28 October 2014|date=30 November 2014}} Following the [[January 2015 Sinai attacks|attacks on army and police bases in Arish in early 2015]], the Egyptian President issued a decree to create a unified military command for the east of the Suez Canal to combat terrorism. Led by General Osama Roshdy Askar, it will guide counter-terrorism activities of the Second and Third army.{{cite news|title=Sisi creates unified military command to combat terrorism in Egypt's Sinai|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/121835/Egypt/Politics-/Sisi-forms-new-military-entity-to-combat-terrorism.aspx|accessdate=1 March 2015|agency=Ahram Online|date=31 January 2015}} On 27 April 2015, Egypt's Prime Minister Ibrahim Mahlab issued a decree ordering the isolation and evacuation of new areas in North Sinai's Rafah city, thus expanding the buffer zone.{{cite news|title=More areas of Sinai's Rafah to be evacuated: Egypt PM|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/128818/Egypt/Politics-/More-areas-of-Sinais-Rafah-to-be-evacuated-Egypt-P.aspx|accessdate=27 April 2015|agency=MENA|publisher=Ahram Online|date=27 April 2015}} A shift in the militants strategy appeared in the [[July 2015 Sinai clashes|July 2015 clashes]]. Zack Gold, Middle East analyst, views the battle as a change in strategy from hit and run tactics toward an ISIL-like 'holding' of territory.{{cite news|title=Islamic State affiliate claims deadly attacks in Egypt's Sinai Peninsula|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/egypt/11710055/Militants-launch-deadly-attacks-in-Egypts-Sinai.html|accessdate=2 July 2015|publisher=The Telegraph|date=1 July 2015}} As an effort to limit car-bombs attacks, Egypt's Prime Minister Ibrahim Mahlab issued a decree banning 4X4 vehicles in army-operations zones in Sinai.{{cite news|title=Egyptian cabinet bans use of 4X4 vehicles in army-operations zones in Sinai|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/0/135217/Egypt/0/Egyptian-cabinet-bans-use-of-X-vehicles-in-armyope.aspx|accessdate=16 July 2015|publisher=Ahram Online|date=12 July 2015}} ===Judicial response=== The Egyptian government has used the death penalty to punish those convicted of committing terrorist acts in Sinai. On 26 December 2017, Egypt hanged 15 men convicted of killing nine soldiers during an attack on a military checkpoint in 2013.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/26/world/middleeast/egypt-execution-terrorism.html?rref=collection%2Fsectioncollection%2Fmiddleeast&action=click&contentCollection=middleeast®ion=stream&module=stream_unit&version=latest&contentPlacement=2&pgtype=sectionfront|author=Nour Youssef|title=Egypt Hangs 15 for Terrorism, Stoking Fears Among Islamists|work=The New York Times|date=26 December 2017|access-date=27 December 2017}} ==Israeli involvement== On 16 October 2017, the Islamic State announced that it had fired rockets at Eshkol region in Israel, in response to 'Jewish aircraft' assisting Egyptian security forces.{{Cite news|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/islamic-state-claims-responsibility-for-sinai-rocket-attack-on-israel/|title=Islamic State claims responsibility for Sinai rocket attack on Israel|work=[[The Times of Israel]]|date=16 October 2017}} On 23 May 2018, the Islamic State released a video claiming that Israeli aircraft struck civilian homes in the Sinai and showed Hebrew labels on munitions purportedly found in aftermath of the attack.{{Cite news|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/islamic-state-claims-proof-of-israeli-airstrikes-in-northern-sinai/|title=Islamic State claims 'proof' of Israeli airstrikes in northern Sinai|work=[[The Times of Israel]]|date=16 October 2017}} On 2 February 2018, Lebanese [[Al Akhbar (Lebanon)|Al Akhbar]] reported that in the last several months, Israel had struck targets of the Islamic State in Sinai, including Palestinians who after abandoing the group's strongholds in Syria and Iraq, joined the offshoot in Sinai. As a result of the airstrikes, more around 20 militants of the group were killed.{{Cite news|url=http://www.israelhayom.co.il/article/533931|title=דיווח לבנוני: ישראל חיסלה כ-20 מחבלי דאעש|work=[[Maariv]]|date=6 February 2018}} ==Reactions== ===Israel=== In the two years since 2011, Israel has approved two Egyptian military increases in the Sinai Peninsula above levels set in the [[Camp David Accords]], which mandates that the Sinai must remain demilitarized, with only enough forces in Sinai to enforce security.{{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/Headlines/Article.aspx?id=235499|title=Barak agrees to Egypt deploying troops, vehicles in Sinai|publisher=Jerusalem Post|date=26 August 2011|accessdate=1 October 2012}} Israel did so because it is not in its interest to have unrest in Sinai, whether political protests or militant violence. However, in late 2012, concern began to be raised as Egypt began deploying more force and tanks without coordination from Israel. On 21 August, Israeli Foreign Minister [[Avigdor Lieberman]] said that it is important for Israel to make sure that the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty is upheld, and not to remain silent as Egyptian military forces enter the Sinai. Concern was raised by Israeli officials over Egyptian failure to notify Israel about the deployment of tanks in the Sinai, which violates the peace treaty. Lieberman said, "We must make sure that every detail is upheld, otherwise we'll find ourselves in a slippery slope as far as the peace treaty is concerned."{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4271499,00.html|title=Lieberman: Don't let Egypt get away with violations|publisher=Yedioth Ahronot|date=21 August 2012|accessdate=21 August 2012|author=Somfalvi, Attila}} On the same day, Israeli daily ''Maariv'' reported that Israel sent a message to Egypt via the [[White House]], protesting Egypt's ongoing increase in military presence in the Sinai without coordination from Israel, and telling Egypt that it must remove tanks from the Sinai because their presence violates the [[Camp David Accords|Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty]] of 1979, which states that Sinai Peninsula is to remain demilitarized. The ''Maariv'' report was echoed by an article in ''[[The New York Times]]'', which stated that Israel was "troubled" by the entry of Egyptian tanks into the northern Sinai Peninsula without coordination with Israel and had asked Egypt to withdraw them.{{cite news|last=Kershner|first=Isabel|title=Israel Asks Egypt to Remove Tanks From Sinai|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/22/world/middleeast/israel-asks-egypt-to-remove-tanks-from-sinai.html?ref=middleeast|accessdate=29 August 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=21 August 2012}} Partly due to Egypt's military deploying tanks in the Sinai Peninsula, Israel is increasingly worried about what has long been their most critical regional relationship.{{cite news|last=Rudoren|first=Jodi|title=Developments in Iran and Sinai Deepen Israel's Worries About Egypt|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/23/world/middleeast/israels-worries-about-egypt-deepen.html?ref=egypt&pagewanted=all|accessdate=29 August 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=22 August 2012}} The lack of coordination around their deployment is seen as potentially undermining a peace treaty that has been a cornerstone of Israel's security for decades according to the New York Times. Israel is also concerned that Egypt may use Operation Eagle to build up its military presence in the Sinai, and leave the tanks and armored carriers in the Sinai while not doing much more than symbolic action to eliminate the terrorist threat.{{cite web|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/israel-tells-egypt-to-remove-tanks-from-sinai/|title=After buildup, Israel tells Egypt to remove tanks from Sinai|publisher=The Times of Israel|date=21 August 2012|accessdate=21 August 2012|author=Winer, Stuart}} Israel has not issued a formal complaint, and instead prefers to resolve the issue through quiet contacts, as well as mediation from the U.S., to avoid straining its relationship with Egypt. On 24 August 2012, a senior Egyptian military source said that Egyptian Defense Minister Abdel Fattah el-Sissi and Israeli Defense Minister [[Ehud Barak]] have reached an agreement on the issue of the militarization of the Sinai. ''Al Hayat'' reported that Sissi phoned Barak and said that Egypt was committed to maintaining the peace treaty with Israel.{{cite news|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/barak-and-egyptian-counterpart-reportedly-come-to-terms-over-sinai-offensive/|title=Barak and Egyptian counterpart reportedly come to terms over Sinai offensive|newspaper=The Times of Israel|date=24 August 2012|accessdate=24 August 2012|author=Davidovitch, Joshua}} Sissi also said that the militarization was temporary, and was needed for security and to fight terrorism. However, an Israeli defense official denied that such a conversation took place.{{cite news|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/egypt-tells-israel-military-presence-in-sinai-is-temporary/|title=Egypt tells Israel military presence in Sinai is temporary|newspaper=The Times of Israel|date=25 August 2012|accessdate=26 August 2012}} In late August 2012, Morsi said that the security operations do not threaten anyone, and "there should not be any kind of international or regional concerns at all from the presence of Egyptian security forces". Morsi added that the campaign was in "full respect to international treaties. The Egyptian-Israeli peace deal places limits on Egyptian military deployment in the Sinai. Officials in Israel were concerned about Egypt building up heavy armour in Sinai.{{cite news|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4273813,00.html|title=Morsi's message to Israel: No reason for concern|newspaper=Yedioth Ahronot|date=28 August 2012|accessdate=4 April 2014}} On 8 September 2012, an Israeli official confirmed that coordination exists between Israel and Egypt regarding Operation Eagle. Egyptian Military spokesman Ahmed Mohammed Ali had earlier announced that Egypt has been consulting with Israel regarding its security measures in the Sinai.{{cite news|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/weve-killed-32-criminals-and-arrested-38-in-aftermath-of-sinai-terror-attack-says-egyptian-army/|title=Egypt says it has killed 32 'criminals' and arrested 38 since Sinai terror attack|newspaper=The Times of Israel|date=8 September 2012|accessdate=8 September 2012|author=Shmulovich, Michal}} On 2 July 2015, one day after the attacks on 15{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cUZCbCHqbBk|title=معركة الثأر (مترجم إلى اللغة الإنجليزية) Sinai against terrorism - YouTube|date=5 July 2015|work=YouTube}} [[Egyptian Army]] checkpoints, Israel announced that it was giving [[Egypt]] a "free hand to operate in northern [[Sinai]] against local jihadist groups, voluntarily ignoring an annex to the 1979 Camp David Peace Accords banning the presence of significant Egyptian forces in the area."{{cite web|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/israel-has-given-egyptian-army-free-hand-in-sinai-official-says/|title=Israel giving Egyptian army free hand in Sinai, official says|work=The Times of Israel|accessdate=17 July 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/Middle-East/Report-IDF-to-okay-bolstered-Egyptian-forces-in-Sinai-after-deadly-attacks-407738|title=Report: IDF to okay bolstered Egyptian forces in Sinai after deadly attacks|work=The Jerusalem Post - JPost.com|accessdate=17 July 2015}} Israeli Prime Minister [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] sent condolences to Egypt for the terrorist attacks that rocked that country on 1 July. He further stated that "we are together with Egypt and many other states in the Middle East and the world in the struggle against extreme Islamic terrorism."{{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/Arab-Israeli-Conflict/Netanyahu-We-are-partners-with-Egypt-in-the-fight-against-ISIS-that-has-reached-our-borders-407711|title=Benjamin Netanyahu: We are partners with Egypt in the fight against ISIS that has reached our borders - Arab-Israeli Conflict - Jerusalem Post|work=The Jerusalem Post - JPost.com|accessdate=17 July 2015}} ===United States=== According to [[CNN]], in a move to increase security in the Sinai, help Morsi, and reassure Israel, U.S. Defense Secretary [[Leon Panetta]] offered Egypt classified intelligence-sharing capabilities to help Egypt identify military threats in the area, which he discussed during his recent trips to Egypt and Israel. The technology has been widely used in Iraq and Afghanistan to identify vehicles at great distances. The technology may also be used by the Multinational Force and Observers in Sinai. The United States is also offering increased intelligence sharing, including satellite imagery and drone flights, as well as cellphone intercepts and other communications among militants suspected of plotting attacks.{{cite web|url=http://www.israelhayom.com/site/newsletter_article.php?id=5491|title=CNN: US offers Egyptian army intelligence aid for Sinai battles|publisher=Israel Hayom|work=Israel Hayom; Reuters|date=21 August 2012|accessdate=22 August 2012}} On 22 August 2012, the [[State Department]] urged Egypt to be transparent over Operation Eagle and any security operations in the Sinai. The State Department said that the United States supports Operation Eagle against terrorism, but stressed that Egypt must continue coordination with Israel regarding these operations and military increases in the Sinai, according to the 1979 [[Camp David Accords]].{{cite web|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/us-state-department-urges-egyptian-transparency-over-sinai/|title=Washington calls for Egyptian transparency amid military buildup in Sinai|publisher=The Times of Israel|date=22 August 2012|accessdate=23 August 2012|author1=Winer, Stuart |author2=Ben Zion, Ilan }} The State Department also called on Egypt to fulfill its obligations under the 1979 [[Egypt–Israel Peace Treaty|Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty]] and deal strongly with security threats in the Sinai, while ensuring that "lines of communication stay open."{{cite news|title=US urges Egypt to retake control of Sinai|url=http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast/Article.aspx?id=282253|accessdate=24 August 2012|newspaper=The Jerusalem Post|date=23 August 2012}} On 23 August 2012, [[Secretary of State]] [[Hillary Clinton]], speaking with Egyptian Foreign Minister [[Mohamed Kamel Amr]], urged Amr to maintain lines of communication with Israel, and emphasized the importance of being transparent over the militarization of the Sinai.{{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/DiplomacyAndPolitics/Article.aspx?id=282405|title=Clinton urges Egypt, Israel to talk on Sinai|publisher=The Jerusalem Post|work=Reuters|date=23 August 2012|accessdate=23 August 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120823220456/http://www.jpost.com/DiplomacyAndPolitics/Article.aspx?id=282405|archivedate=23 August 2012|df=dmy-all}} ===Multinational Force and Observers in Sinai=== The [[Multinational Force and Observers]] in Sinai, a 1,650-strong international organization created in 1979 during the Camp David Accords with peacekeeping responsibilities, kept a low profile during the intensification of Operation Eagle in 2012. A representative for the organization said that "we are unable to respond to queries from the media at this time" in response to whether Egypt asked permission to move weaponry into the Sinai, and whether Israel granted it.{{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/DiplomacyAndPolitics/Article.aspx?id=282083|title=Int'l force in Sinai quiet amid concern of Egypt violations|publisher=The Jerusalem Post|date=21 August 2012|accessdate=21 August 2012|author=Keinon, Herb|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120821215113/http://www.jpost.com/DiplomacyAndPolitics/Article.aspx?id=282083|archivedate=21 August 2012|df=dmy-all}} ===Jordan=== The [[Arab Gas Pipeline|Egyptian pipeline]] carrying natural gas to Jordan has been attacked at least 15 times since the start of the uprising in early 2011.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/07/22/us-egypt-pipeline-idUSBRE86L00T20120722|title=Blast rocks Egypt's gas pipeline to Israel, Jordan|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=3 September 2013}} The lack of Egyptian gas hit Jordan budget severely (by JD 1.4 billion or the equivalent of USD 2 billion yearly for the past two years) and they are looking for Egypt to compensate for the lost
