{{Infobox television | show_name = Skopje Fest | image = <!-- include ALT text per [[WP:ALT]] guideline --> | caption = | show_name_2 = | genre = [[Music]], [[entertainment]] | creator = | based_on = | developer = | writer = | director = | creative_director = | presenter = | starring = | judges = | voices = | narrated = | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | endtheme = | composer = | country = [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]] | language = [[Macedonian language|Macedonian]] | num_series = 20 | num_episodes = | list_episodes = | executive_producer = | producer = | editor = | location = | cinematography = | camera = | runtime = | company = | distributor = | channel = [[Macedonian Radio Television|MRT]] | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_run = | first_aired = {{Start date|1969|df=yes}} | last_aired = present | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = | website = | website_title = | production_website = | production_website_title = }} '''Skopje Fest''' ({{lang-mk|Скопје Фест}}) or '''Festival na zabavni melodii Skopje''' (Фестивал на забавни мелодии Скопје) is one of the main musical events in the [[Republic of Macedonia]].
SkopjeFest began in 1968 in the Universal Hall in [[Skopje]], and continued until 1980. In this short time, the festival became one of the biggest music events in [[Yugoslavia]]. Skopjefest was the place where famous Macedonian singers such as [[Slave Dimitrov]], Zafir Hadzimanov, Nina Spirova made their performances together with eminent [[Yugoslavs|Yugoslav]] performers. Audiences enjoyed over 50 songs.
After Macedonia gained its independence peacefully from [[Yugoslavia]], SkopjeFest was revived in 1994, and has since taken over from [[MakFest]] as Macedonia's premier music festival.
The show involves some of Macedonia's finest performers, singing original tracks submitted to MRT (Makedonska Radio Televizija), usually accompanied by the orchestra of MRT (excluding some of its latest editions).
It has also been used as the Macedonian national selections for the [[Eurovision Song Contest]], since the late 1990s. The first Macedonian representative in Eurovision, was Macedonian singer [[Vlado Janevski]] who won SkopjeFest 1998 with the song "Ne Zori Zoro", for the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1998]]. This was Macedonia's first participation in the [[Eurovision Song Contest]]. Ever since, SkopjeFest has been shadowed by many controversial debates regarding the strategies behind the song selections and the lack of transparence concerning the winner. Such allegations are not new to this contest. However, they intensified as the Eurovision participation became a factor. After the decision to make SkopjeFest the National Pre-Selection round for Macedonia's representative to Eurovision, the traditional point award ceremony was eliminated and replaced by the controversial announcement of only the Top 3 places. Neither the points of the jury nor the televoting results are made public.
Up until 2002, SkopjeFest used to be the biggest musical activity in the country. However, it faced financial problems. In 2003, the festival wasn't held in order to save money for the next year when Macedonia was going to particate in the [[Eurovision Song Contest]]. In the meantime, MRT made new criteria for the national selection for the [[Eurovision Song Contest]], the festival returned in 2004 only to celebrate the 60th anniversary of MRT. After that, financial problems increased and it wasn't organised until 2008, again as an ESC national final.
After the first details about selecting the Macedonian participant for the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2012]] were revealed, it was announced that Skopje Fest will continue being held as an independent event without being involved in the Macedonian selection process for the [[Eurovision Song Contest]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Миленковска|first=В.|title=Калиопи на Евросонг, Скопски фестивал во ноември|url=http://vest.com.mk/?ItemID=87C721F6A5784F49933D6F805AA62C17|accessdate=21 November 2011|newspaper=Вест|date=19 November 2011}}</ref> On 15 July 2014, it was announced that Skopje Fest will return as the Macedonian national final for the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2015]].<ref name="Macedonia 2015">{{cite web|title=FYR Macedonia: 2015 Participation Is Confirmed|url=http://eurovoix.com/2014/07/15/fyr-macedonia-2015-participation-is-confirmed/|publisher=Eurovoix|last=Granger|first=Anthony|accessdate=15 July 2014|date=15 July 2014}}</ref>

The '''SoFFin''' (Sonderfonds Finanzmarktstabilisierung - Special Financial Market Stabilization Funds) is a program of the German government with the purpose to stabilize and restore confidence in the financial system. It was created in the middle of the [[Financial crisis of 2007–2010]] on October 17, 2008 by the German Parliament and enacted on October 20, 2008.<ref>http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/0,1518,583739,00.html</ref> As of December 31, 2010 it stopped offering new services but continued managing existing guarantees.
In November 2011, it was announced that it would be revived for potential new issues if necessary.<ref>http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-11-14/germany-to-reactivate-soffin-bank-rescue-fund-asmussen-says.html</ref>
Initially it was established as an agency at the [[Deutsche Bundesbank]] and was supervised by the federal ministry of finance. The fund was managed by Dr. Hannes Rehm (speaker), Dr. Christopher Pleister and Gerhard Strattthaus. Operations were conducted through three tasks
* Providing Liquidity by means of guarantees for specially issued debt by eligible financial institutions * Investing in Equity (recapitalization) * Purchasing securities in [[open market operation]]s
The SoFFin may grant guarantees of up to 400bn euros and recapitalize or purchase assets for an additional 80bn euros.
In January 2011 the SoFFin was reorganized under the then created German Agency for the Stabilization of the Financial Markets

{{Infobox theatre | name = Theatre Royal | image = Theatre Royal front facade, Manchester.jpg | image_size = 240px | image_alt = | caption = Theatre Royal front façade | address = | city = [[Manchester]] | country = England | designation = Grade II | coordinates = {{coord|53.4777|-2.2465|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | architect = {{Plainlist| * John Gould Irwin & Francis Chester <small>(1845)</small> * [[Edward Salomon]] <small>(alteration in 1871)</small> }} | owner = Edwardian London | tenant = | operator = | capacity = | type = Victorian variety theatre | opened = {{Start date|1845}} | reopened = 1875, 1921, 1963, 1972, 1990 | yearsactive = 1845–1921 (as a theatre) | rebuilt s = | closed = | othernames = | production = | currentuse = | patrons = | website = }} The '''Theatre Royal''' in Manchester, England, opened in 1845. Situated next to the [[Free Trade Hall]], it is the oldest surviving theatre in Manchester.<ref name="theatrestrust.org"/><ref name="ManchesterEveningNews20111103"/> It was commissioned by Mancunian businessman [[John Knowles (Manchester)|John Knowles]] who wanted a theatre venue in the city.
The Theatre Royal operated as a theatre from 1845 until 1921, when it closed in the face of growing competition from the [[Palace Theatre, Manchester|Palace Theatre]] and [[Manchester Opera House|Opera House]]. The building has since been converted numerous times for use as a cinema, bingo hall and nightclub. It has been unoccupied since 2009.
==Architecture== The theatre, which stands on an island site on the south side of Peter Street, is constructed in [[sandstone]] [[ashlar]]. It is in two storeys, with an attic, and is in [[Neoclassical architecture|Neoclassical]] style. Around the building, between the upper storey and the attic, is a modillioned [[cornice]].<ref name=nhl>{{NHLE |num= 1246667|desc= Royale Club, Manchester|accessdate= 26 September 2010|mode=cs2|ps=none}}</ref> Its entrance front facing Peter Street is symmetrical with three [[bay (architecture)|bays]], the central bay being wider than the lateral bays. The central bay is in the form of a [[portico]], with [[Corinthian order|Corinthian]] columns and [[pilaster]]s. Its [[entablature]] contains a central semicircular arch breaking through to the [[gable]]. Steps lead up to entrances in each bay. Above the central entrance is a [[pediment]]ed [[niche (architecture)|niche]] containing a statue of [[William Shakespeare]], which is based on the statue by [[Peter Scheemakers]] in [[Westminster Abbey]]. The lateral bays contain windows with balconies in the upper storey.{{sfn|Hartwell|Hyde|Pevsner|2004|p=322}} Along the sides of the theatre are alternating rectangular windows and panels, with a blank semicircular arch above each window. The interior of the theatre has been altered, but retains its 1875 gallery. The theatre was designated as a Grade II [[listed building]] on 3 October 1974.<ref name=nhl/> The authors of the ''[[Pevsner Architectural Guides|Buildings of England]]'' series describe it as a "splendid classical composition in stone, one of the best examples of theatre architecture surviving anywhere in England from the first half of the 19th century".{{sfn|Hartwell|Hyde|Pevsner|2004|p=322}} The [[Theatres Trust]] described it as "unique and architecturally significant", with the façade being "one of the finest examples of theatre architecture to have survived in Britain from the first half of the nineteenth century", stating that it influenced the design of the [[Royal Opera House, London]].<ref name="MEN_8Dec16" />
==Use as a Theatre== Manchester appears to have two previous Theatre Royals before the current building was constructed in 1845. The first opened in [[Spring Gardens, Manchester|Spring Gardens]] on 5 June 1775 and operated on that site until the expiration of the proprietors' lease in 1807.<ref name=Collectanea>{{citation |title=Collectanea relating to Manchester and its neighbourhood, at various periods |volume=2 |year=1867 |publisher=[[Chetham Society]] |page=59 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=acI4AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA58–59}}</ref>
The second Theatre Royal opened in Fountain Street on 12 July 1807 and was destroyed by fire on 7 March 1844.<ref name=Collectanea/> John Knowles took over the management of this second Theatre Royal some time before the fire, at a time when the [[theatre]] in Manchester was at its lowest ebb.<ref>'Index to the report from the Select Committee on Theatrical Licenses and Regulations', 1866, House of Commons Parliamentary Papers, vol. XVI.1, p. 217.</ref> Knowles set up a strong [[Stock company (acting)|stock company]] and proved himself a very capable, though somewhat authoritarian, [[theatre manager]]. However, following the 1844 fire the proprietors of the theatre in Fountain Street refused to rebuild it.
At a public dinner in his honour in July 1844, Knowles was presented a plate "in acknowledgement of his energetic and successful efforts to revive national drama in Manchester".<ref name="John Knowles 1844, p. 5">'Dinner to John Knowles, Jun, Esq', ''The Manchester Guardian'', 17 July 1844, p. 5</ref> Knowles told the gathering that if they could get no one else to build a theatre then he would do it himself. As a result, Knowles bought the [[patent rights]] and set about finding a site for the new theatre.{{sfn|Manchester Central Library|1979|p=18}} Knowles had always been an admirer of theatrical performances and he was anxious to see their renovation in this, his native town. He desired to see the revival of the legitimate drama, and the plays represented in a manner duly worthy of them.<ref name="John Knowles 1844, p. 5"/>
[[Image:(Former) Theatre Royal and (Former) Free Trade Hall, Manchester.jpg|thumb|left|Theatre Royal front facade on the left with the [[Free Trade Hall]].]] Knowles found a new site for his theatre on Peter Street. He demolished the Wellington Inn and Brogden's Horse Bazaar.{{sfn|Parkinson-Bailey|2000|p=87}} Knowles employed Francis Chester and John Gould Irwin as the [[architect]]s for his new theatre.{{sfn|Rudyard|Wyke|1994|p=57}} In preparation for the building of the new Theatre Royal, Knowles and Chester went to London and visited most of the metropolitan theatres, noting their areas, internal forms, [[Acoustics|acoustic capabilities]], etc.<ref>'The New Theatre Royal, Peter-Street', ''The Manchester Guardian'', 2 October 1844, p. 5</ref> With a cost of £23,000, the new Theatre Royal opened to an audience of 2,500.{{sfn|Manchester Central Library|1979|p=19}} Precautionary measures against fire were taken by placing a [[Water tank|tank]] on the roof capable of holding 20,000 gallons of water, which was connected by pipes to the stage and the [[green room]]. Its programme that night included [[Carl Maria von Weber|Weber's]] ''[[Oberon (Weber)|Oberon]]'' overture, [[Douglas Jerrold]]'s "Time works wonders" and an elaborate [[ballet]] spectacle "The Court Ball in 1740". Knowles's schedule of productions was intensive – in one season there were 157 performances at which two and sometimes three plays were performed. The popularity of the theatre grew. [[Charles Dickens]], [[John Leech (caricaturist)|John Leech]] and [[George Cruikshank|George Cruickshank]]{{sfn|Parkinson-Bailey|2000|p=87}} were amongst notable people who appeared at the theatre. The theatre was dedicated to [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]] and Knowles installed a [[Carrara marble]] statue of the playwright above the entrance. It was Manchester's finest outdoor statue.{{sfn|Rudyard|Wyke|1994|p=57}} In 1875, after years of success, Knowles severed his connections with the theatre, disposing of it to a [[limited company]] for £50,000.{{sfn|Manchester Central Library|1979|p=19}}
==Later use== In 1921 the theatre was converted to a [[Movie theater|cinema]] due to competition from the [[Palace Theatre, Manchester]] and the [[Manchester Opera House]]. In 1972 the theatre became a [[bingo hall]], then a [[nightclub]] in 1978,<ref name="MEN_8Dec16" /> at which point various lighting bridges and rigs were added.<ref name="theatrestrust.org" /> It was known successively as the "Discotheque Royale", Infinity then M2 and finally a rename and rebrand to Coliseum due to the trouble caused by the clientele it attracted. The nightclub closed in 2009.<ref name="MEN_8Dec16" />
In 2008 a {{convert|118|m|ft|abbr=on}} 28-storey office and retail tower was proposed, called "Theatre Royal Tower", that would be connected to the back of the original theatre. It was designed by [[Stephenson Bell]] with [[The Benmore Group]] as the developer.<ref name="skyscraper" />
It was announced in 2011 by owners Benmore that the Theatre Royal would receive a £2 million refurbishment to convert the building into a live music venue.<ref name="ManchesterEveningNews20111103">{{cite news |title=Theatre Royal to become live music venue – with £2m refurb |url=http://menmedia.co.uk/manchestereveningnews/news/business/s/1463880_theatre-royal-to-become-live-music-venue---with-2m-refurb |newspaper=Manchester Evening News |date=3 November 2011 |accessdate=20 September 2012}}</ref> Plans to convert the building into a hotel and live music venue never came about.<ref name="MEN_8Dec16" />
Despite the promise of investment, Benmore sold the building in November 2012.<ref name="MC_21Nov12" /> It was purchased by the [[Edwardian Group]], who owned the [[Radisson Blu]] Edwardian hotel adjacent to the theatre in the [[Free Trade Hall]].<ref name="MEN_20Nov12" /> The building could potentially be restored as a theatre or banqueting hall as a complimentary extension for the hotel.<ref name="MC_21Nov12" />
{{Asof|December 2016}} the building remains unused, with the Edwardian Group carrying out feasibility studies for the building. [[Theatres Trust]] has placed the building on its "Theatre Buildings At Risk" reigster.<ref name="MEN_8Dec16" />
The 1845 exterior façade is virtually intact,<ref name="theatrestrust.org" /> and the building retains the balcony from 1875.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} [[Theatres Trust]] has said that the internal conversions for its past usage in various guises appear to have obscured – rather than destroyed  – the interior. The Trust classify the original interior work as "restorable as a theatre".<ref name="theatrestrust.org" />

{{Infobox wrestling event |name=Triplemanía II-C |image=TriplemaniaIIPoster.jpg |caption=The official poster for Triplemanía II featuring the majority of the wrestlers who would work the three shows. |tagline=La Cuenta Final
("The Final Reckoning") |promotion=[[Asistencia Asesoría y Administración]] |date=May 27, 1994{{cite web | url = http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/triple.html#ii-c | title = Asistencia Asesoría y Administración TripleManía | accessdate = 2009-02-19| publisher = ProWrestlingHistory.com}} |attendance=18,000 |venue=[[Plaza de Toros Monumental de Tijuana|El Toreo]] |city=[[Tijuana]], [[Baja California]], [[Mexico]] |lastevent=[[Triplemanía II-B]] |nextevent=[[AAA When Worlds Collide]] |event=[[Triplemanía]] |lastevent2=[[Triplemanía II-B]] |nextevent2=[[Triplemanía III-A]] }} '''Triplemanía II-C''' was a major ''[[lucha libre]]'', or [[professional wrestling]] event [[Asistencia Asesoría y Administración]] (AAA) that took place at the ''[[Plaza de Toros Monumental de Tijuana|El Toreo]]'' [[bullfighting]] arena in [[Tijuana]], [[Baja California]], [[Mexico]] on May 27, 1994. The show was the final of three Triplemanía II shows held in 1994, preceded by [[Triplemanía II-A]] in April and [[Triplemanía II-B]] held 12 days prior. 1994 was the first year AAA held multiple Triplemanía shows in a year, a tradition they would continue through 1997, after which Triplemanía became a single annual event. The annual Triplemanía show(s) are AAA's biggest show of the year, serving as the culmination of major storylines and feature wrestlers from all over the world competing in what has been described as AAA's version of [[WrestleMania]] or their [[Super Bowl]] event.{{cite book|author=Madigan, Dan|title=Mondo Lucha Libre: the bizarre and honorable world of wild Mexican wrestling|publisher=HarperColins Publisher|year=2007|chapter=A family affair|pages=128–132|isbn=978-0-06-085583-3}} The May 27th show was the fourth overall show produced under the Triplemanía banner. The main event match was the culmination of a storyline that AAA had been building for a year, starting at the previous year's [[Triplemanía I]] show. Portraying the [[archetype]]s of "good" and "evil' AAA had created a storyine where the "hero" [[Konnan]] sought revenge against the "villain" [[Jake Roberts|Jake "The Snake" Roberts]]. The two faced off in a ''[[Lucha de Apuestas]]'', or bet match, which is considered the ultimate "feud settler" in ''Lucha Libre''. For the match both competitors bet their hair on the outcome of the match, with the loser being subjected to the humiliation of being shaved bald in the center of the ring. The show also featured a [[steel cage match]] between ''[[Capos (professional wrestling)|Los Hermanos Dinamita]]'' (Spanish for "The Dynamite Brothers"; [[Cien Caras]], [[Máscara Año 2000]] and [[Universo 2000]]) fighting ''[[Los Payasos]]'' ("The Clowns"; Coco Rojo, Coco Verde and Coco Amarillo) in a rematch from [[Triplemanía II-A]] where ''Los Payasos'' won the [[Mexican National Trios Championship]] from ''Los Hermanos Dinamita''. The show was also supposed to feature a match for the [[Mexican National Middleweight Championship]] but the reigning champion [[Octagón]] was not medically cleared to wrestle. ==Production== [[File:Jake "The Snake" Roberts.jpg|left|thumb|[[Jake Roberts]], risked his hair on the outcome of the main event match.]] ===Background=== AAA founder [[Antonio Peña]] had originally envisioned the [[Triplemanía]] series as three shows held over the summer, but for the first year AAA only held 1 show, [[Triplemanía I]]. In 1994 AAA announced that they would hold three Triplemanía shows, building the storylines into its climax at the third and final Triplemanía II show. The first show, [[Triplemanía II-A]] , took place in the outdoor baseball stadium in [[Aguascalientes, Aguascalientes]] on April 26, the second show, [[Triplemanía II-B]], was held at the [[Estadio Olímpico Benito Juárez]] in [[Zapopan, Jalisco]] on May 15 and the third and final Triplemanía II show, Triplemanía II-C, would happen at the ''[[Plaza de Toros Monumental de Tijuana|El Toro]]'' [[bullfighting]] arena in [[Tijuana]], [[Baja California]] on May 27, 1994.{{cite web | url = http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/triple.html#ii-a | title = Asistencia Asesoría y Administración TripleManía | accessdate = 2009-02-19| publisher = ProWrestlingHistory.com}}{{cite web | url = http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/triple.html#ii-b | title = Asistencia Asesoría y Administración TripleManía | accessdate = 2009-02-19| publisher = ProWrestlingHistory.com}} {{clear}} ===Storylines=== The Triplemanía show featured eight [[Professional wrestling match types|professional wrestling matches]] with different wrestlers involved in pre-existing [[Screenplay|scripted]] feuds, [[plot (narrative)|plots]] and [[narrative thread|storylines]]. Wrestlers were portrayed as either [[Heel (professional wrestling)|heels]] (referred to as ''rudos'' in Mexico, those that portray the "bad guys") or [[Face (professional wrestling)|faces]] (''técnicos'' in Mexico, the "good guy" characters) as they followed a series of tension-building events, which culminated in a wrestling match or series of matches. The main event match would be the conclusion of the main storyline of AAA at the time as Peña and the AAA officials had spent over a year laying out the storyline between [[Konnan]] and [[Jake Roberts|Jake "the Snake" Roberts]]. The foundation of the story began a year prior to Triplemanía II-C, at the first ever [[Triplemanía I]], held on April 30, 1993. To start the storyline Roberts was given a spot in the front row, presented as if he had bought a ticket on his own and was just there to watch the show.{{cite news|title=1993 Especial!|work=Box y Lucha Magazine|pages=2–28|id=issue 2214|date=January 7, 1994|language=Spanish}} The main event was a "Retirement match" between Konnan and [[Cien Caras]] where the loser would be forced to retire, which saw Jake Roberts become involved in the match, arguing with Konnan during the second fall and actually distracted him enough to get counted out.{{cite web | url = http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/triple.html#i | title = Asistencia Asesoría y Administración TripleManía | accessdate = 2009-02-19| publisher = ProWrestlingHistory.com}} With the loss Konnan was forced to retire and due to his actions Roberts became the top ''rudo'' of AAA as he was seen as directly responsible for the popular Konnan being forced to retire. For several months AAA booked Roberts in only special appearances, not actually wrestling but making appearances to remind people of what he did to Konnan. After about four months Konnan returned to AAA and together with Peña supposedly petitioned the Mexico City boxing and wrestling commission to get Konnan reinstated. The storyline explanation given was that he was allowed to return to wrestling due to Roberts' interference in the match. AAA built their August 28, 1993 ''La Revencha'' show in the [[Los Angeles Sports Arena]] around Konnan finally getting in the ring with Robets, in a three-way elimination match that also included Cien Caras. Konnan forced Cien Caras to submit, gaining a measure of revenge from their Triplemanía match. Later on Jake "the Snake" Roberts got himself disqualified when ''[[Los Gringos Locos]]'' ([[Eddy Guerrero]] and [[Art Barr|Love Machine]]) interfered in the match.{{cite web | url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/la.html#0893 | title=Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum Sports Arena August 1993 | date=August 28, 1993 | accessdate=July 12, 2015 | publisher=Pro Wrestling History}} On November 12, 1993 Jake Roberts and ''Los Gringos Locos'' defeated Konnan, [[Blue Panther]] and [[Perro Aguayo]] in the main event of AAA"s ''La Lucha del Honor'' event at the Los Angeles Sports Arena. During the match Roberts pinned Konnan in both the second and the third fall.{{cite web | url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/la.html#1193 | title=Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum Sports Arena November 1993 | date=November 12, 1993 | accessdate=July 12, 2015 | publisher=Pro Wrestling History}} Part of Peña booking strategy was to not have the two rivals fight one-on-one right away, building the anticipation to when they finally get in the ring for their first singles match. Roberts kept the advantage, using his partnership with ''Los Gringos Locos'' to have the numbers advantage. AAA kept the two apart until March 12, 1994 where the two finally faced off. They met in a [[steel cage match]] to even the numbers in the main event of AAA's spring Los Angeles Sports Arena show. During the show Konnan finally gained a measure of revenge on Roberts, winning the match by climbing out of the cage, but still had not pinned Roberts.{{cite web | url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/la.html#0394 | title=Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum Sports Arena March 1994 | date=March 12, 1994 | accessdate=July 12, 2015 | publisher=Pro Wrestling History}} The loss to Konnan was used as the impetus to Roberts finally agreeing to put his hair on the line in a ''[[Lucha de Apuesta]]'', or "bet match", which was the ultimate end game for the storyline. The match was scheduled to be the main event of the third Triplemanía II show, with a preview of it taking place at Triplemanía II-B where Konnan, [[Perro Aguayo]] and Cien Caras defeated Jake Roberts, Love Machine and [[Miguel Pérez Jr.]] in the main event. ==Event== The fifth match of the night, a match that was supposed to see [[Octagón]] defend his [[Mexican National Middleweight Championship]] against [[Blue Panther]]. A few days prior to the match Octagón was involved in a car accident, suffering a hand injury. The wrestling boxing commission could not medically clear Octagón to wrestle on the show. Instead he came to the ring with the championship and handed it over to Blue Panther via forfeit, only asking for a rematch once he had recovered from his injury.{{cite news|title=Los Reyes de Mexico: La Historia de Los Campeonatos Nacionales|work=Lucha 2000|id=Especial 21|date=2004-12-20|language=Spanish}} ==Aftermath== Roberts would remain with AAA for several months after losing all his hair, he ended up turning on ''Los Gringos Locos'' and actually teamed up with Konnan only a few months later. defeating the team of Perro Aguayo and [[Vampiro]].{{cite web | url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/la.html#0894 | title=Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum Sports Arena August 1994 | date=August 6, 1994 | accessdate=July 12, 2015 | publisher=Pro Wrestling History}} The ''[[Los Gringos Locos]]'' storyline carried AAA into their subsequent major shows "Night of Champions" and later on their first ever [[pay-per-view]] (PPV) [[AAA When Worlds Collide]] that was driven by the feud between ''a Pareja del Terror'' (Eddy Guerrero and Love Machine) facing off against El Hijo del Santo and Octagón in a ''Luchas de Apuestas'' match where Guerrero and Love Machine ended up losing their hair.{{cite news|title=Historical Cards|work=PWI Presents: 2007 Wrestling Almanak and book of facts|publisher=Kappa Publications|id=2007 Edition|page=160}} 19 days afterwards Love Machine, real name Art Barr, dies of unknown causes.{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.com/WrestlingStarBios/barr_art.html |title=Art Barr: What could have been; Looking back at Love Machine's career|last=Molinaro|first=John|accessdate=2008-10-12|work=Slam! Sports|publisher=[[Canadian Online Explorer]]}} The popularity of Konnan in the wake of his victory over Jake Robers made his turn to the ''rudo'' side months later ever more shocking, with Konnan attacking his longtime friend Perro Aguayo during a match and joining ''Los Gringos Locos'' instead.{{cite web | url=http://www.luchalibreaaa.com/historia/when-worlds-collide.html | title= El evento que comenzo la revolucion mundial | publisher=[[Asistencia Asesoría y Administración]] | accessdate=June 27, 2015 | language=Spanish}} At "When Worlds Collide" Aguayo defeated Konnan in a [[steel cage match]]. Once Octagón had recovered from his hand injury he received a rematch for the championship he never lost in the ring, but on August 4, 1994 Blue Panther successfully defended the title against Octagón. ==Reception== John Molinario, who writes about wrestling for the [[Canadian Online Explorer]], described the show as a "booking masterpiece by Pena" and that it established Antonio Peña as "the best booker in the business."{{cite web | url=http://slam.canoe.com/SlamWrestlingInternational/triplemania.html | title=TripleMania: Mexico's answer to WrestleMania | first=John F. | last=Molinaro | year=2000 | accessdate=June 22, 2015}} Wrestling commentator [[Mike Tenay]], who was in attendance that night, recalled "the great heat for that main event match". ==Results== {{Pro Wrestling results table |results={{cite news|title=1994 Especial!|work=Box y Lucha Magazine|pages=2–28|id=issue 2176|date=January 8, 1995|language=Spanish}} |match1=[[El Hijo del Diablo|Super Amigo]], El Plumo, and Depredator defeated ''La Ola Lila'' ([[May Flowers]], [[Pimpinela Escarlata]], and Rudy Reyna) |stip1=[[Professional wrestling tag team match types#Trios rules (Relevos Australianos)|Best two-out-of-three falls six-man "Lucha Libre rules" tag team match]] |time1=12:37 |match2=Rambo, Magnate and [[Espanto Jr.]] defeated [[Abismo Negro|Winners]], [[Super Caló]] and [[El Solar]] |stip2=Best two-out-of-three falls six-man "Lucha Libre rules" tag team match |time2=13:00 |match3=[[El Torero]], [[Rey Misterio]], and [[Rey Misterio Jr.]] defeated [[Fuerza Guerrera]], [[Fishman (wrestler)|Fishman]], and [[Pirata Morgan]] |stip3=Best two-out-of-three falls six-man "Lucha Libre rules" tag team match |time3=16:19 |match4=[[Super Parka|Volador]], [[Tinieblas Jr.]] and [[Lizmark Jr.]] defeated [[Art Barr|Love Machine]], [[Miguel Pérez Jr.]] and [[Misterioso (wrestler)|Misterioso]] by disqualification |stip4=Best two-out-of-three falls six-man "Lucha Libre rules" tag team match |time4=10:53 |match5=[[Blue Panther]] defeated [[Octagón]] (C) by forfeit |stip5=[[Professional wrestling match types#Variations of singles matches|Singles match]] for the [[Mexican National Middleweight Championship]]{{cite book|author=Royal Duncan and Gary Will|title=Wrestling Title Histories|publisher=Archeus Communications|chapter=Mexico: National Middleweight Championship|page=392|year=2000|isbn=0-9698161-5-4}} |time5=N/A |match6=[[Perro Aguayo]], [[Lizmark]], [[El Hijo del Santo]], and [[Máscara Sagrada]] defeated [[La Parka]], [[Psicosis]], [[Victor Mar Manuel|Black Cat]] and [[El Satánico]] * Fall One: Lizmark pinned El Satánico (1-0) * Fall Two: Black Cat won by submission (1-1) * Fall Three: Máscara Sagrada pinned El Satánico (2-1) |stip6=[[Professional wrestling tag team match types#Trios rules (Relevos Australianos)|Best two-out-of-three falls eight-man "Atómicos" tag team match]] |time6=20:23 |match7=''[[Capos (professional wrestling)|Los Hermanos Dinamita]]'' ([[Cien Caras]], [[Máscara Año 2000]] and [[Universo 2000]]) defeated ''[[Los Payasos]]'' (Coco Rojo, Coco Verde and Coco Amarillo) |stip7=[[Professional wrestling match types#Cages|Steel Cage Match]] – Los Hermanos Dinamita won when Cien Caras was the last of his team to leave escape the cage |time7=09:44 |match8=[[Konnan]] defeated [[Jake Roberts]] (with [[The Warlord (wrestler)|The Warlord]]) * Fall One: Konnan pinned Jake Roberts (1-0) * Fall two: Konnan pinned Jake Roberts (2-0) |stip8=[[Professional wrestling match types#Two out of three falls match|Best two-out-of-three falls]] ''[[Lucha de Apuesta]]'', "Hair vs. Hair" match. As a result, Jake Roberts had his head shaved. |time8=  }} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Portal|Professional wrestling}} ==External links== *[http://www.luchalibreaaa.com/eventos-magnos/triplemania/item/87-tripleman%C3%ADa-ii-la-cuenta-final.html Triplemanía II at LuchaLibreAAA.com] {{AAAShows}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Triplemania 02c}} [[Category:1994 in professional wrestling]] [[Category:Triplemanía]] [[Category:1994 in Mexico]] [[Category:Events in Mexico]] [[Category:May 1994 events]] [[es:Triplemanía II]]

The '''Umm Hajul controversy''' was one of many cases of fratricide committed during the [[Gulf War|Persian Gulf War]]. After [[United States|American]] forces accidentally opened fire on their own men, a [[cover-up]] was attempted. A plot element of the movie ''[[Courage Under Fire]]'' was based on this particular incident.{{Citation needed|date=September 2007}}
==Incident== In the predawn hours of February 27, 1991, an armored personnel carrier of the [[1st Armored Division (United States)|1st Armored Division]] broke down near the airfield of Umm Hajul. The five operators of the vehicle, U.S. Army engineers, found themselves stranded in the desert when [[M1 Abrams|M1A1]] tank and [[Bradley Fighting Vehicle]] units of the [[3rd Armored Cavalry Regiment (United States)|3rd Armored Cavalry Regiment]] approached from the north. Specialist Craig Walker tried signaling to the approaching forces by switching his [[night vision goggles]] on and off. The armored cavalry troop had been told the airfield was defended by 500+ Iraqi soldiers, and to expect stiff resistance. The troop commander fired warning shots in the air after requesting permission to do so from his squadron commander. Some of the cavalry troopers saw returned fire, but whether this came from the engineers is doubtful. The cavalry troop vehicles opened fire on the engineers with high-explosive rounds, mistaking their vehicle for an enemy position. The result of the high-explosive rounds set off demolition charges within the engineers' armored personnel carrier. The situation progressed for about seven minutes, with the troop commander calling cease fire after two volleys, thinking the "enemy forces" were contained and waiting for them to surrender. The squadron commander then arrived on the scene in his [[Bradley Fighting Vehicle]] and opened fire when he thought one of the engineers (still believed to be Iraqis) was trying to escape. When the shooting was over, one engineer was wounded and another, Corporal Lance Fielder of Tennessee, was dead from [[coaxial]] [[machinegun]] fire.
==Coverup== Shortly after the incident, false reports were filed, stating that the 3rd Cavalry took an estimated 50 Iraqi prisoners in the assault. Three [[Bronze Star Medal|Bronze Stars]] were awarded on the basis of misleading statements and representations, as well.<ref name="GAO">[http://www.gao.gov/archive/1995/os95010.pdf United States Government Accountability Office Report, page 92]</ref> The squadron commander was the son-in-law of a famous Vietnam-era general, and his brothers-in-law were also general officers. He did not face repercussions and was selected for promotion to colonel. Both the cavalry troop commander and the lieutenant in charge of the engineers at the airfield were given career-ending evaluations and forced out of the Army. This was particularly ironic, since the lieutenant was completely not culpable. Many discrepancies uncovered in three army investigations were overlooked or ignored, and several lower-ranking soldiers and officers were threatened or coerced into remaining silent.
==Investigation== U.S. Senator [[Fred Thompson]] of Tennessee initiated a Congressional investigation into this incident, in which Corporal Lance Fielder of Nashville, Tennessee had died. The investigation resulted in the forced retirement of the squadron commander of the unit that fired shots at Fielder and others, his reduction in rank to major, and revocation of medals.<ref name="Lawrimore">Lawrimore, Erin. [http://dlc.lib.utk.edu/f/fa/fulltext/2113.html "Biography/History"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111001220518/http://dlc.lib.utk.edu/f/fa/fulltext/2113.html |date=2011-10-01 }}, University of Tennessee Special Collections Library (2005).</ref>
==References== * http://www.gulfweb.org/tracings/friesen.html * https://web.archive.org/web/20091027013441/http://geocities.com/Pentagon/Quarters/2061/ * https://www.usnews.com/usnews/news/articles/030317/17war.htm <references />

[[File:Devant OMS 1.jpg|thumb|Wladimir Tchertkoff in front of the [[WHO]] building, asking for a modification of the WHO-IAEA agreement, 26 April 2007]] [[File:20110426-IWHO-15-WTchertkoff-d.jpg|thumb|26 Avril 2011]] '''Wladimir Tchertkoff''' is an [[Italy|Italian]] [[journalist]].
He released with Emanuela Andreoli in 2003 the film ''The Sacrifice'', a documentary on the [[Chernobyl liquidators|liquidators]] of the [[Chernobyl]] nuclear power plant. This film received an award from the [[Île-de-France (region)|Île-de-France]] council for the best scientific and environment documentary in November 2004.
He has also received the award of the best documentary of the Festival of Scientific Movies of [[Oullins]], France.
Tchertkoff is the author of ''Le Crime de Tchernobyl, le Goulag nucléaire'' (''The Crime of Chernobyl, the Nuclear Goulag'') published by Actes Sud, Paris.
He is also one of the founders of the organisation ''Children of Chernobyl Belarus''.

{{Infobox event | title = World Youth Day 1985 | image = | image_size = | caption = | date = {{start date|1985|03|30}} – {{end date|1985|03|31}} | time = | type = Youth festival | theme = Christus pax nostra | venue = | place = [[Rome]], [[Italy]] | coordinates = | organisers = [[Catholic Church]] | participants = [[Pope John Paul II]] | website = }} '''World Youth Day 1985''' was a meeting on the occasion of the [[International Youth Year]] held in [[Rome]] on March 30th and 31st 1985<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vatican.va/gmg/years/gmg_1986_po.html|title=I Jornada Mundial da Juventude 1986|website=www.vatican.va|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>and it was the second great international meeting promoted by the [[Catholic Church]] and later named [[World Youth Day]]. This was considered the birth of these events, which would begin to be called of this way on the next year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.antsj.org/antillas/?p=872|title=Nuncio Apostólico presidirá celebración de la Jornada Mundial de la Juventud 2014 – Jesuitas|website=www.antsj.org|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>
After the [[World Youth Day 1984|Youth Jubilee]] celebrated in Rome the year before on the occasion of the [[Jubilee (Christianity)|Holy Year]], [[Pope John Paul II]] organized a youth gathering for [[Palm Sunday]] in 1985<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ricerca.repubblica.it/repubblica/archivio/repubblica/1985/03/26/150-mila-giovani-dal-papa-per-la.html?ref=search|title=150 MILA GIOVANI DAL PAPA PER LA FESTA DELLE PALME - la Repubblica.it|publisher=|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref> coinciding with the International Youth Year proclaimed by the [[United Nations|UN]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.un.org/es/events/youthday/background.shtml|title=Día Internacional de la Juventud, 12 de agosto|website=www.un.org|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vatican.va/roman_curia/pontifical_councils/laity/Colonia2005/rc_pc_laity_doc_20030805_cross-history-gmg_sp.html|title=JMJ 2005 - La peregrinación de la Cruz de los Jóvenes (1984-2014)|website=www.vatican.va|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>
==Before the event== Before the young people arrived in Rome, the Pope issued on December 8, 1984, a message for the World Day of Peace devoted to the young. Then John Paul II invited the youth to [[Palm Sunday]] to Rome for the World Youth Meeting. The Pope chose Palm Sunday as the date of the meeting because in the previous year, just on Palm Sunday, the [[Catholic Church]] celebrated the Jubilee of the Youth, celebrated on the occasion of the Holy Year 1983/1984 (1950 anniversary of the death and resurrection of [[Jesus Christ]]).
==The program== ===Saturday 30 March=== The Pope met the young Catholics for the first time in [[Archbasilica of St. John Lateran]] at 5:00 pm. The slogan of this great meeting were the words: May you know how to realize the hope that is in you ([[First Epistle of Peter|1 Peter]] 3:15).
During this meeting the [[Ecclesiastical letter|apostolic letter]] "To the young people of the world"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://w2.vatican.va/content/john-paul-ii/es/apost_letters/1985/documents/hf_jp-ii_apl_31031985_dilecti-amici.html|title=Dilecti Amici, a los jóvenes del mundo con ocasión del Año internacional de la juventud (31 de marzo de 1985) - Juan Pablo II|website=w2.vatican.va|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>, written by the Pope for the occasion, was presented firstly to those present. During the following night, there was the possibility for young people to watch in [[Eucharistic adoration|eucharistic adoration]] at some churches in the city.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ricerca.repubblica.it/repubblica/archivio/repubblica/1985/03/31/un-terzo-millennio-di-pace-vogliamo-grano.html?ref=search|title='UN TERZO MILLENNIO DI PACE VOGLIAMO GRANO, NON CANNONI' - la Repubblica.it|publisher=|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>
===Sunday, March 31=== The following morning, starting at 6:00 WYJ participants formed three parades, which joined at [[Via della Conciliazione]] to reach [[St. Peter's Square]] together - where the final [[Mass (liturgy)|mass]] would be celebrated.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://agensir.it/chiesa/2016/03/18/trentuno-anni-di-gmg-una-chiesa-amica-dei-giovani/|title=Trentuno anni di Gmg, una Chiesa amica dei giovani - AgenSIR|date=18 March 2016|publisher=|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>The sources attest in the morning the presence of about 250,000<ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071211155616/http://www.wjt2005.de/index.php@id=161&si=4.htm|title=Sito web ufficiale della XX GMG 2005: Storia delle Giornate Mondiali della Gioventù|date=11 December 2007|publisher=|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.aciprensa.com/jornadas/jmj2005/historia.php|title=XX Jornada Mundial de la Juventud 2005 :: ACI Prensa|website=www.aciprensa.com|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>/ 300,000 <ref>[Source [[Agenzia Nazionale Stampa Associata|ANSA]], reported in The Revolution in a Day, Pino Vicentini, [[Avvenire]], Friday 11 August 2000.]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.laici.va/content/laici/es/sezioni/giovani/storia-delle-gmg.html|title=Historia de las JMJ|website=www.laici.va|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>people from 70 countries, mostly Italians; but there were about twenty thousand [[Spain|Spaniards]] and five thousand pilgrims from Eastern European countries (primarily [[Poland]], [[Yugoslavia]] and [[Hungary]]). Young people from [[Alaska]], [[Lebanon]] were also present in Rome, as also from [[Africa]] and the [[Far East]]. Also noteworthy are the presence of other [[Christianity|Christian confessions]] (especially [[England|English]] [[Protestantism|Protestants]]), and even non-Christians (including four hundred [[Japan|Japanese]] [[Buddhism|Buddhists]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ricerca.repubblica.it/repubblica/archivio/repubblica/1985/03/30/centocinquantamila-giovani-per-le-strade-di-roma.html?ref=search|title=CENTOCINQUANTAMILA GIOVANI PER LE STRADE DI ROMA IN NOME DEL PAPA E DE - la Repubblica.it|publisher=|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>
==The event== Although it is not a real WYJ (it is considered a sort of "zero edition"), this meeting has some traits that will characterize all future international events of WYD: for example, participants are given a "pilgrim's bag" and a cap with the logo of the day; for hospitality to pilgrims a network of accommodation facilities in the area is activated; an anthem is composed for the occasion.
==The anthem== The song "Resta qui com noi" by the musical group Gen Rosso (texts by V. Ciprì and music by B. Enderle) was composed for the gathering and inaugurated the tradition of adopting an official anthem for each World Youth Day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.genrosso.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=84&Itemid=98&lang=en|title=Gen Rosso|website=www.genrosso.com|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goyaproducciones.com/blog/historia-e-himnos-de-la-jornada-mundial-de-la-juventud-jmj/|title=goyaproducciones.com|publisher=|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>
==The establishment of WYDs== Given the success of the day, the Pope on next December 20 officially proclaimed the establishment of the [[World Youth Day|World Youth Days]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vatican.va/gmg/documents/gmg_chronicle-wyd_20020325_sp.html|title=EL CAMINO DE LAS JORNADAS MUNDIALES DE LA JUVENTUD|website=www.vatican.va|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>, which will be held every year in all the [[Diocese|dioceses]] of the world on Palm Sunday (in 1986 it would be called the alternation on two-year cycle diocesan editions and world editions in a city selected by the [[Pontifical Council for the Laity]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.es/sociedad/abci-elige-ciudad-jornada-mundial-juventud-puja-discreta-entre-paises-201608011414_noticia.html|title=Así se elige la ciudad de la Jornada Mundial de la Juventud: una puja discreta entre países|publisher=|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vatican.va/roman_curia/pontifical_councils/laity/laity_sp/pubblicazioni/rc_pc_laity_doc_20050101_notiziario-11-pc-laici_sp.html|title=Pontificio Consejo para los Laicos|website=www.vatican.va|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref> John Paul II after World Youth Meeting in Rome decided to announce World Youth Day in 1986.
